Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minnesota
sec.p: Background: Recent studies suggest that multiple genes involved in the glutamate-glutamine cycle are associated with mood disorders including the genes encoding excitatory amino acid transporter 2 (EAAT2) and metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5). It is increasingly recognized that comorbidities in bipolar disorder (BD) may more narrowly define the phenotype, which in turn may allow more focused study of epigenetic regulation. This study was conducted to quantify clinical correlates and DNA methylation in BD comorbid with alcohol use disorder (AUD), nicotine use disorder (NUD), and binge eating disorder (BED).

Methods: In this IRB-approved study, 639 participants underwent structured diagnostic interview confirming BD, completed questionnaires for demographic and illness-related variables, and provided a DNA sample. Bipolar subjects were divided in five groups: BD+no comorbidity, BD+NUD, BD+AUD, BD+NUD+AUD, and BD+BED. Participants from the Mayo Clinic Community Biobank served as healthy controls. DNA was extracted from peripheral blood lymphocytes. Bisulfite conversion and methylation-sensitive high resolution melt polymerase chain reaction (HRM PCR) were used to compare SLC1A2 (encoding for EAAT2) and GRM5 (encoding for mGluR5) gene promoters. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey’s post-hoc test for multiple comparison was used for analysis.

Results: SLC1A2 promoter methylation analysis was completed in 32 controls and 106 BD subjects. By ANOVA, there was a significant difference in SLC1A2 promoter methylation between groups (p=0.0019); by post-hoc, Tukey’s multiple comparison, the BD+NUD and BD+BED subgroups showed reduced methylation compared with BD+no comorbidity (p<0.05). GRM5 promoter methylation analysis was completed in 16 controls and 57 BD subjects. By ANOVA, there was a significant difference in GRM5 promoter methylation between groups (p=0.0276); by post-hoc, Tukey’s multiple comparison, the BD+NUD+AUD subgroup showed reduced methylation compared with controls and BD+no comorbidity (p<0.05).

Conclusions: DNA methylation is differentially expressed for two important glutamate-glutamine system genes (SLC1A2 and GRM5). For both genes, comorbid addiction to nicotine and alcohol had significant impact on the level of promoter methylation. This finding is consistent with previously published reports showing that nicotine decreases gene promoter methylation via reduction in DNA methyltranspherase 1 (DNMT1) expression. We also observed that BED comorbidity reduces SLC1A2 promoter methylation, which requires a functional study to reveal an implication of the hypo methylation in BED phenotype in BD patients. Limitations of this study are relatively small sample size and single technique used to assess promoter methylation status. To overcome these shortcomings, we are currently increasing the sample size and mapping the methylation sites using direct sequencing. Also, postmortem human brain studies of SLC1A2 and GRM5 promoters are warranted. Promoter methylation analysis of candidate genes for BD from peripheral tissues has the potential for future development of both diagnostic and treatment response biomarkers. Moreover, precise clinical phenotyping remains essential for identifying comorbidities present in patients with BD.
Keywords: epigenetics, bipolar disorder, glutamate, addiction.
Disclosure: Dr. Veldic. Funding from Mayo Foundation.

sec.title: T206. The Role of Genetic Variation across IL-1 beta, IL-2, IL-6 and BDNF in Antipsychotic-induced Weight Gain
Daniel Mueller*, Trehani Fonseka, Arun Tiwari, Vanessa Goncalves, Jeffrey Lieberman, Herbert Meltzer, Benjamin Goldstein, James Kennedy, Sidney Kennedy
University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
sec.p: Background: Antipsychotic medications are widely used across major psychiatric disorders. However, the marked observed inter-individual variability with respect to response and side effects often require lengthy treatment trials until the right medication is found for the right patient. This variability is thought to largely depend on genetic factors where effects are supposedly larger and compared to disease genetics. We have identified several important gene variants in the past years investigating the genetics of antipsychotic-induced weight gain (AIWG). AIWG is a severe and common side effect often leading to patient non-compliance and increased morbidity and mortality due to metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular events. Beyond these negative effects for the patients, medical conditions caused by AIWG lead to increased health care utilization and costs. Genetic predictors would be extremely helpful to identify subjects at risk prior to antipsychotic exposure. Antipsychotics with high weight gain-inducing propensities influence the expression of immune and neurotrophin genes, which have been independently related to obesity indices. Thus, we investigated whether variants in the genes encoding interleukin (IL)-1 beta, IL-2, and IL-6, and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) Val66Met are associated with antipsychotic-induced weight gain (AIWG).

Methods: One hundred and eighty-eight participants, 18 to 60 years of age, with a Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Third Edition, Revised (DSM-III-TR) or Fourth Edition (DSM-IV) diagnosis of chronic schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder were included. Participants were primarily of European or African descent, with ethnicity ascertained using self-reported ancestry over three generations. The sample consisted mainly of individuals exposed to olanzapine (OLZ) or clozapine (CLZ) for their first time. Nineteen polymorphisms were genotyped using Taqman® assays in 188 schizophrenia patients on antipsychotic treatment for up to fourteen weeks. Mean weight change (%) from baseline was compared across genotypic groups using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA). Baseline weight and duration of treatment were entered as covariates. Unphased (Dudbridge, 2008) version 3.1.5 was used to investigate haplotype and allelic effects. Epistatic effects between cytokine polymorphisms and BDNF Val66Met were tested using Model-Based Multifactor Dimensionality Reduction.

Results: In European patients, IL-1 beta rs16944*GA (p=0.013, p[corrected]=0.182), IL-1 beta□□rs1143634*G (p=0.001, p[corrected]=0.014), and BDNF Val66Met (Val/Val, p=0.004, p[corrected]=0.056) were associated with greater AIWG, as were IL-1 beta rs4849127*A (p=0.049, p[corrected]=0.784), and IL-1 beta□rs16944*GA (p=0.012, p[corrected]=0.192) in African Americans. BDNF Val66Met interacted with both IL-1 beta rs13032029 (Val/Met+TT, p[perm]=0.029), and IL-6□rs2069837 (Val/Val+AA, p[perm]=0.021) in Europeans, in addition to IL-1 beta rs16944 (Val/Val+GA, p[perm]=0.006) in African Americans. Haplotypic analyses identified a significant haplotype on the IL-1□ gene between rs1143643, rs1143634, rs3136558 (p<0.001) among patients of African ancestry on CLZ or OLZ. Epistatic effects were modelled between variant sites across each of IL-1 beta, IL-2, and IL-6 and the BDNF Val66Met locus for an association with weight change (%) from baseline. In patients of European ancestry on CLZ or OLZ, an interaction was observed between IL-1 beta rs13032029 and BDNF Val66Met (beta=-7.63, Wald=9.70, Permutation P=0.029). Carriers of the TT genotype at IL-1 beta rs13032029 and the Val/Met genotype at BDNF Val66Met were identified as low risk for AIWG compared to individuals with any other genotypic combination at these loci.

Conclusions: In summary, our data extend the current literature by showing that variability at IL-1 beta SNPs rs4849127, rs16944, and rs1143634, and BDNF Val66Met can both individually and, in some cases, synergistically predict AIWG outcomes in AP-treated patients with chronic schizophrenia. Taken together, there is appreciable evidence to support the influence of cytokine genetic variation on AIWG. However, further studies are needed to confirm the predictive utility of these immunogenetic biomarkers and more clearly elucidate the underlying functional mechanisms that support a cytokine model of AIWG.
Keywords: pharmacogenetics, weight gain, cytokines, antipsychotics.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T207. Genetics of Education and Cognition: A Cogent Follow-up Analysis of Overlapping Variants

Joey Trampush*, Todd Lencz, Emma Knowles, Gail Davies, Thomas Espeseth, Ina Giegling, Panos Roussos, Katherine Burdick, Gary Donohoe, Aiden Corvin, Neil Pendleton, Panos Bitsios, Dan Rujescu, Jari Lahti, Stephanie Le Hellard, Matthew Keller, Ole Andreassen, Daniel Weinberger, Ian Deary, David Glahn, Anil Malhotra
Zucker Hillside Hospital, Glen Oaks, New York
sec.p: Background: A recent genome-wide association study (GWAS) of educational attainment in>125,000 people reported three single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were associated with completing college (rs11584700 and rs4851266) and years of schooling (rs9320913; Rietveld et al., 2013). In the current study, we hypothesized these variants should be linked to cognition. To examine this putative relationship, we analyzed dense cognitive data from>21,000 independent subjects in the Cognitive Genomics Consortium (COGENT), an international collaboration formed to conduct genome-wide analyses of cognition in healthy individuals with preexisting GWAS and neuropsychological data (Lencz et al., 2014).

Methods: The initial findings from COGENT Phase 1, a ∼1M SNP meta-GWAS of general cognitive ability (“g”) in ∼5,000 individuals collected across 9 sites, were published recently (Lencz et al., 2014). We mined for p-values of the three educational attainment SNPs and their close proxies in the COGENT1 database. SNPs with p-values<.05 were examined for replication in new COGENT samples obtained in the ongoing second wave of data collection. Eleven COGENT2 studies comprised of ∼16,000 subjects were available for replication analyses. All 20 COGENT1-2 samples were genotyped on dense Illumina or Affymetrix SNP microarrays. All subjects were Caucasian of European ancestry (as confirmed by analysis of genetic data), and the first 20 multidimensional scaling genetic components were used as covariates to further control for subtle population stratification effects. All subjects had to complete at least one neuropsychological measure across at least three domains of cognitive ability (e.g., memory, processing speed and executive functioning) in order to derive a composite g factor based on principal components analysis. Sex, age, age2, sex × age, and sex × age2 were regressed out of the composite g factor prior to analysis and the standardized residuals were analyzed. SNP meta-analysis of g was done in the R MetABEL package and Metasoft.

Results: No SNP or proxy previously associated with completing college was significant in COGENT1. However, rs1906252, a proxy SNP (R2=.91) for the chromosome 6 variant rs9320913 associated with years of schooling, had a significant association with g in COGENT1 (P=1.01e-02). rs1906252 is included on many commercial microarrays and was available for analysis in seven COGENT2 samples, and we imputed rs1906252 and rs9320913 in four additional samples using Impute2 and the latest 1000 Genomes reference panels. The overall meta-analysis of rs1906252 in the 11 independent COGENT2 studies (N=16,188) was also significant (pooled χ2=7.71, P=5.5e-03). Combined, the 20 COGENT1-2 samples (N∼21,192) evidenced a robust association between rs1906252 and g (pooled χ2=11.99, P=5.3e-04; Fig.1 & Table 1). Functionally, rs1906252 is about 700kb from the nearest annotated gene, but it is in an intron of a long intergenic non-coding RNA (lincRNA) that is expressed in human brain (uncharacterized LOC101927335; ENSG00000271860).

Conclusions: In the Cognitive Genomics Consortium, we confirmed our hypothesis of a link between loci that contribute to educational attainment and cognitive function by twice replicating an association between general cognitive ability and a genome-wide significant locus related to years of schooling across ∼21,000 individuals. To date, few other studies have reported consistent neurogenetic findings in adequately powered samples, which render the current findings unique in this regard. Further, this study provides new insights regarding the genetics of education and cognition, which can guide future neurobiological experimentation.
Keywords: GWAS, cognition, educational attainment, genetics.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T208. Whole Genome Sequencing Study of Multiply-affected Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder Families from the Portuguese Island Population

Benke Kelly, Brion Maher, Tim Bigdeli, James Knowles, Helena Medeiros, Janet Sobell, Elizabeth Bevilacqua, Jennifer Moran, James Nemesh, Giulio Genovese, Robert Handsaker, Colm O'Dushlaine, Michele Pato, Steven McCarroll, Ayman Fanous*
Washington VA Medical Center/Georgetown University, Centreville, Virginia
sec.p: Background: Although genome-wide association studies of bipolar disorder (BIP) and schizophrenia (SZ) have identified allelic associations with many common variants, they are unable to identify rare variation contributing to the heritability of these disorders. Such variation might be found using whole genome sequencing (WGS) methods in families with several affected members.

Methods: The current analysis was performed on a sample of 17 individuals from 4 bipolar families (# affected/# unaffected were: 2/4; 4/1; 2/0; 4/0) and a sample of 18 individuals from 4 schizophrenia families (1/3; 4/1; 3/2; 3/1), all from the Portuguese Islands. Sequencing was performed using the Illumina HiSeq2000. After applying quality and variant filters (including MAF<0.02 or not identified in the 1000g and NHLBI datasets), we considered SNV and INDEL variants present in all cases, and when possible, eliminated variants that were present in unaffected family members. For coding regions, Provean and SIFT were employed to classify a variant as deleterious. For noncoding regions, classification as an active enhancer or promoter was done in ANNOVAR. Discovered variants were followed up in two samples using Fisher’s exact test: (1) 7 unrelated Portuguese BIP cases and 31 controls, and (2) 220 SZ cases and 185 controls from the Genomic Psychiatry Cohort (GPC). Using the RVsharing package in R, we determined the probability of observing the number of perfectly segregating variants discovered in each family, among the set of variants that were under potential consideration before applying our segregation filters.

Results: For SZ, we identified 308 coding variants in 268 genes and 1238 noncoding variants nearby or in the introns of 1119 genes. For BIP, we identified 351 coding variants in 310 genes and 592 variants intronic or nearby to 522 genes. For six families, we observed a greater number of discovered variants than would be expected by chance. Notably, a number of discovered variants segregated with illness in more than one and up to five families. Our findings do not appear to be skewed toward large size genes. Very few of the discovered variants had P<0.10 in one of the unrelated case-controls sets (16 coding SNVs, 7 noncoding SNVs and 9 noncoding INDELs). Genic burden tests did not improve power. Of the discovered variants with suggestive significance in the follow-up samples, many occur nearby a suggestive or genome-wide significant finding in SZ or BIP PGC meta-analyses according to the SLEP database.

Conclusions: Using WGS of BIP and SZ families for discovery and two independent samples for follow-up, we identified several rare variants of potential etiological relevance. Of particular interest are variants in the CMYA5 and CACNA1C genes, long identified as candidates for SZ. Other genes of interest near PGC findings include JAG2, FRMD4A, CDC25C and KIAA1432. Our results in this handful of PIC families suggest that rare variation in familial cases of psychiatric disorders do indeed exist, though many false positive hits are likely, and some of the GWA hits previously identified in large scale genome-wide meta-analyses may be tagging regions where important rare variation occurs. Future efforts to combine across family samples should improve power.
Keywords: schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, whole-genome, sequencing.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T209. Exploring the Interplay Between COMT, BDNF and AKT1 and Cannabis Consumption in Psychotic Disorders

Katherine Aitchison*, Yabing Wang, Brodie A. Heywood, Beatriz C. Carvalho Henriques, David Rossolatos, Darren Bugbee, Alexandra Loverock, Carol Bolt, Aleksandra Dimitrijevic, Georgina Macintyre, Philip Tibbo, Scot E Purdon
University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
sec.p: Background: Cannabis use in adolescence is a known risk factor for the development of psychotic disorders. Clinical and preclinical genetic studies provide increasing evidence that genes related to dopamine signaling and neuroprotection are implicated in the cannabis-psychosis association. Genes in such emerging data include COMT, BDNF, and AKT1 (Decoster et al., 2012; van Winkel et al., 2011; Di Forti et al., 2012; for a review see O’Tuathaigh et al., 2014). Arseneault et al (2002) found that individuals using cannabis at ages 15 and 18 years had higher rates of psychotic symptoms at age 26 years compared with non-users.

Methods: In this study, we are seeking to explore the role of markers in the above candidate genes and cannabis use in a sample of approximately 240 patients with psychosis recruited in Edmonton and Halifax, Canada. Data on cannabis use and other relevant variables have been collected. DNA has been extracted from salivary samples by the Oragene kit method. The markers are rs4680 (Val158Met) in COMT, rs2494732 in AKT1, and rs6265 (Val66Met) in BDNF. Genotyping has been conducted using a variety of SNP methods, with inter-method cross-validation.

Results: For COMT, the genotyping call rate was 100%, the genotypic distributions were in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium and there was 100% concordance between different SNP methodologies (TaqMan and SNaPshot). Genotyping for BDNF and AKT1 is in progress. In the clinical data, psychosis was associated with age of regular use of cannabis ≤19 years. Our dependent variable was age at diagnosis, which was log-transformed as it was skewed. ANOVAs were then conducted versus age, gender, diagnosis, medication status at baseline, and recruitment centre. The results of linear regression analysis with gender, age at regular use of cannabis, and COMT genotype as predictors, and the dependent as log age of diagnosis showed that gender and age at regular use of cannabis were significant predictors of age at diagnosis (p=0.042 and p=0.035 respectively) while COMT genotype was not significant in this preliminary analysis of this sample. However, graphical review of this data reveals that this may be at this stage a sample size issue; it would appear that the COMT Val158Val genotype may be associated with younger age of diagnosis in those who began regular cannabis use at ≤ 19 years.

Conclusions: In summary, we found an association between age at diagnosis, gender, and age at first regular use of cannabis. There was no significant effect of the COMT rs4680 SNP in this preliminary analysis. Further analysis will include restricting the diagnosis to schizophrenia spectrum disorders. Moreover, although the patients were recruited as Caucasians, it is possible that there is a degree of as yet undetected admixture in terms of ancestry. Ancestry informative markers are being employed in order to factor this in to the analysis. Acknowledgements: This study was funded by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR): NPAS3 variants in schizophrenia and other psychoses. KJA holds an Alberta Centennial Addiction and Mental Health Research Chair, funded by the Government of Alberta, Canada. Genotyping of COMT was conducted by The Applied Genomics Core (TAGC; University of Alberta) and by the Aitchison laboratory.
Keywords: Pharmacogenetics, Cannabis, Psychosis, COMT.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T210. Genetic Moderators of Cardiovascular Side Effects of ADHD Treatment
Erika Nurmi*, James McGough, Karyn Mallya, Gerhard Hellemann, James McCracken
University of California Los Angeles, Los Angeles, California
sec.p: Background: Common side effects of standard attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) pharmacotherapy include changes in cardiovascular (CV) profiles, complicating treatment and representing a source of serious adverse events including rare mortality. A recent study of over 700,000 subjects in the Denmark health registry found that individuals exposed to stimulants had a higher risk of CV events (HR 1.83), especially children (HR 2.20). The ability to identify those at risk could help guide safe clinical treatment matching.

Methods: We hypothesized that genetic variation may contribute to the variability in CV side effects of ADHD medications. During both acute (8 weeks) and long-term (18 months) treatment phases with the stimulant dexmethylphenidate (d-MPH), the alpha-agonist guanfacine, and a combination of both medications, we collected regular CV measures in the NIMH Translational Research to Enhance Cognitive Control (TRECC) sample of 180 children and adolescents with ADHD. Blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) were recorded at each of up to 24 visits, and serial EKGs were performed at 5 time points to assess medication-related cardiac changes, including QTc interval prolongation predisposing to cardiac arrhythmia. We tagged common genetic variation across drug targets and pathways involved in medication response and side effects, including monoaminergic, cholinergic, and glutamatergic transmitter systems, regulators of energy balance, and mediators of growth and plasticity. Genetic variation at 120 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) was examined for association with treatment-induced CV changes.

Results: All treatments were associated with short-term CV changes. As expected, stimulant treatment increased and guanfacine exposure decreased HR and BP, while combination treatment produced the least change in these measures. Over the course of long-term treatment with each of the three regimens, CV measures returned to baseline. The guanfacine group experienced lower tolerability and greater dropout than the d-MPH group. When guanfacine and d-MPH were administered concomitantly, the dropout rate was comparable to the d-MPH group. Despite clinical concerns regarding potential QTc prolongation with the combined use of guanfacine and d-MPH, combination treatment resulted in less QTc prolongation than d-MPH alone. No genetic influences on QTc prolongation were observed. Four alpha 7 cholinergic receptor markers (CHRNA7 rs8028396, rs7170028, rs2651417, rs12915695), one cannabinoid receptor 3’UTR SNP (CNR1 rs806368), and one functional promoter/5’UTR variant in the norepinephrine transporter (SLC6A2 rs2242446) were significantly associated with treatment-dependent changes in HR and BP in both the complete dataset and the Caucasian subset, minimizing confounding effects of ethnicity (Bonferroni corrected significance p<0.0004). A SLC6A2 promoter SNP in strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs2242446 was similarly associated with HR in a prior report. Findings at CNR1 and CHRNA7 are novel. These three genes are biologically relevant candidates given their expression in cardiac and vascular tissue and role in hemodynamic regulation.

Conclusions: Medication-induced CV changes normalize over time with long-term treatment. Combination stimulant and alpha-agonist treatment may alleviate many of the CV side effects of d-MPH or guanfacine monotherapy. Three plausible genes emerged as moderators of medication effects on CV function. These results survive correction for multiple testing; however, replication in independent datasets is warranted. Differential responses to treatment suggest that medication choice may be guided by genetic information in order to avoid serious adverse effects.
Keywords: pharmacogenomics, ADHD, methylphenidate, guanfacine.

Disclosure: Dr. McGough reports receiving research grants from NeuroSigma, Shionogi Pharma, Alexza and Supernus Pharmaceuticals. He serves on the advisory board for Shionogi, Shire, Noven, and NextWave and is a consultant for MedImmune. Dr. McCracken reports receiving consulting fees from Roche; he also reports research support from Roche and Seaside Therapeutics.

sec.title: T211. Analysis of HTR2A Methylation in Four Different Tissues: Association with Suicidal Behaviour
Vincenzo De Luca*, Ali Bani Fatemi, Michelle Matmari, Arthur Koga
University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
sec.p: Background: Suicide in schizophrenia is a relevant clinical problem. Up to 5% of patients with schizophrenia commit suicide. Several studies have pointed out the role of serotonin as key neurotransmitter in the etiology of suicidal behavior. The serotonin 2A receptor gene (HTR2A) has been investigated in many association studies, however there are few investigations that explored the methylation of HTR2A in suicidality. The aim of this contribution is to test the association of HTR2A methylation level with suicide in four different tissues.

Methods: We analyzed through pyrosequencing, the methyltion of five CpG sites in the exon I of HTR2A in ten suicide attempters and ten non-attempters with diagnosis of schizophrenia. DNA was extracted from blood, saliva and cheek swab in the same subjects, therefore the methylation profile was available for three different tissues. We also tested the same CpG sites in ten suicide victims and ten non suicide controls.

Results: The analysis in the attempters did not show significant difference in attempters and non-attempters (p>0.05), however the methylation level was higher than 90% in the three different peripheral tissues. The methylation in the brain was lower than 50%.

Conclusions: The analysis of HTR2A exon I showed that DNA from saliva or buccal cells does not provide a methylation profile more similar to brain tissue. The five CpG sites investigated did not show association with the suicide phenotype. Further investigations should analyze the methylation of serotonin receptors considering lifetime stress in suicidal behavior.
Keywords: suicide, schizophrenia, methylation, serotonin.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T212. Evidence for Influence of the Interaction Between CHRNA5 and Childhood Adversity on Alcohol Self-administration and Related Traits in a Sample of Nonsmoking Drinkers
Jia Yan*, Melanie Schwandt, Bethany Stangl, Colin Hodgkinson, David Goldman, Daniel Hommer, David Ted George, Reza Momenan, Lorenzo Leggio, Kenneth Kendler, Markus Heilig, Vijay Ramchandani
National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland
sec.p: Background: Multiple studies of substance use disorders including nicotine and alcohol dependence have reported association of nicotinic receptor genes in dependence and related phenotypes. In particular, a missense single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the gene encoding the α5 subunit of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (CHRNA5), rs16969968, has been identified as a risk variant for substance use disorder across several independent samples. Additionally, childhood adversity, which is a significant risk factor for alcohol consumption and problems, and previously shown to be associated with alcohol-related traits in our sample, has been shown in another study to interact with rs16969968 to influence nicotine dependence within a sample of smokers. Here, we investigated the impact of rs16969968 and its interaction with childhood trauma on alcohol-related phenotypes in a sample of nonsmokers.

Methods: The sample in this study consisted of 350 volunteers who participated in alcohol studies at the Laboratory of Clinical and Translational Studies of the NIAAA. Participants included inpatient treatment-seeking individuals, individuals with alcohol dependence not seeking treatment, and nondependent drinkers. Each participant underwent a phenotypic assessment and screening visit during which a battery of assessments were obtained. A subset of the sample participated in an intravenous alcohol self-administration (IV-ASA) session using the Computer-Assisted Self-administration of Ethanol (CASE) paradigm (n=70), wherein participants press a button to self-administer alcohol via IV-infusion, providing greater control over brain exposure to alcohol than oral administration. In light of studies suggesting differences in directions of effect of rs16969968 on nicotine dependence compared with other substances, we limited analyses of alcohol phenotypes to non-smokers. Rs16969968 was genotyped using the Illumina OmniExpress Array. Ancestry informative marker (AIM) scores were generated to correct for admixture in the sample using STRUCTURE analysis of 2500 markers genotyped on the array. Because of substantial minor allele frequency differences across populations, we limited analyses to the European American subset and used the Europe AIM score as a covariate. The association between rs16969968 and its interaction with childhood trauma and alcohol consumption and problems was assessed using linear and logistic models with additional sex and age covariates. Rs16969968 was characterized using a dominant model based on the presence of the A allele or absence of the A allele. Childhood adversity was measured using the total score from the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ), which assesses childhood history of emotional, sexual, and physical abuse and emotional and physical neglect. Alcohol-related traits included consumption measured using the Timeline Followback method, alcohol response measured by the Self-Reported Effects of Alcohol (SRE), and both consumption and problems measured by the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), as well as peak and average breath alcohol concentration reached during the IV-ASA session.

Results: Significant main effects for rs16969968 were found for several alcohol self-administration phenotypes in the CASE sample, including the peak and average breath alcohol concentration (BrAC) reached during the laboratory session, the time at which the peak BrAC was met, total ethanol infused, the last BrAC of the session, and rewards earned during the first 30 minutes of the session (p<0.05). A significant interaction between A-allele status and CTQ total score was found to be associated with peak BrAC reached, last BrAC, and whether or not the participant had a binge exposure during the session (reached a BrAC of 80mg% or greater) (p<0.05). No main effects were observed for other phenotypes; however, a significant interaction was found for the SRE first five drinks and heaviest drinking phase measures (p<0.05). For all interactions, individuals with the A allele displayed a steeper slope in the linear relationship between CTQ and alcohol phenotype.

Conclusions: This study showed that the relationship between childhood trauma exposure and drinking outcomes measured in a laboratory IV-ASA paradigm and level of response to alcohol was moderated by genetic variation in CHRNA5 in this sample of social and heavy drinkers. Individuals with the A allele showed a stronger association between childhood trauma scores and alcohol self-administration compared with GG homozygotes. These findings are consistent with other reports of the interaction between childhood trauma and rs16969968 on substance use. Additional functional studies on the mechanisms by which this variant interacts with childhood trauma to influence alcohol consumption are warranted.
Keywords: CHRNA5, Childhood trauma, Gene environment interaction, Alcohol consumption.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T213. Characterization of Transcriptome-wide RNA-editing in Brain in Normal Subjects and in Patients with Schizophrenia
Joo Heon Shin*, Taeyoung Hwang, Dewey Kim, Amanda Price, Nina Rajpurohit, Thomas Hyde, Joel Kleinman, Daniel Weinberger
Lieber Institute for Brain Development, Baltimore, Maryland
sec.p: Background: The RNA-editing, mainly A-to-I, is the co/post-transcriptional modification of single nucleotides in RNA, which has possibilities to affect RNA functions through various ways such as a codon change or a splicing perturbation. It is well known that some important genes in brain functions, for example, glutamate receptors (GRIA2/3) or serotonin receptors (5-HT2CR) undergo RNA-editing for their physiological roles. Also, RNA editing has been reported to be involved in psychiatric diseases, especially schizophrenia. However, its genome-wide profiles are not well understood in human brain tissues. In order to characterize schizophrenia-specific RNA-editing sites in a genome-wide way, we applied next-generation sequencing technologies to normal and schizophrenic human brain tissues in the study.

Methods: We analyzed RNA sequencing data from post-mortem dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) of 438 brain samples (254 Control and 184 Schizophrenia) for potential RNA editing sites. RNA-seq reads were achieved by Poly-A selection without strand specific protocols followed by high-throughput sequencing. After sequencing runs on the HiSeq 2000, the Illumina Real Time Analysis (RTA) module to perform image analysis, base calling, and the BCL Converter (CASAVA v1.8.2) were used to generate the sequence reads. The sequencing depth is 100bp paired-end 80-100 mappable sequencing reads which are aligned back to the human transcriptome by BWA v0.7.3a, with default parameters. The resulting alignment files were processed by samtools (v0.1.18) and picard (v1.88) to sort and mark duplicated reads, respectively. RNA-editing sites were identified from variant calls by GATK (v2.4.9) after filtering out possible sequencing or alignment errors and genomic variants with dbSNP_137. Selected cases also underwent DNA sequencing for validation of editing calls.

Results: We characterized RNA-editing sites in normal and schizophrenic samples during brain development from fetal life to age 90. More than 50,000 reliable RNA editing sites were identified. As well as confirming the previously well-known editing sites, we identified many codon-changing sites, particularly enriched in ion channel genes. We did not find significant RNA-editing rate differences genome wide between normal and schizophrenic samples although there are some sites showing mild rate differences. Also, we observed several developmentally varying RNA-editing trajectories in the normal lifespan series. Projecting the schizophrenia associated RNA-editing trajectories over normal brain developmental RNA-editing space, we find that schizophrenic RNA-editing changes pre- and post-natally are involved in neural development. We are further validating some novel RNA-editing sites with longer read sequencing and Sanger-sequencing.

Conclusions: We describe the characterization of potential RNA editing sites in normal and schizophrenia brains. There have been discussion about the possible association of RNA-editing with schizophrenia. Here, we investigated this possibility with a large number of human brain tissues in a genome-wide context and showed that there is no evidence that RNA-editing is globally involved in schizophrenia (with high RNA-editing ratio changes). However, we show that there might be potential schizophrenic-related sites with low RNA-editing ratio changes. Our study provides not only a global understanding of RNA-editing in normal and schizophrenic human brain tissues but a systematic evaluation of its relevance to schizophrenia.
Keywords: RNA-editing, Schziophrenia, Brain development, DLPFC.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T214. Neuronal Morphology and Function in Differentiating Human Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells (iPSCs) from Individuals with 15q11.2 Deletions
Dhanjit Kumar Das, Kodavali Chowdari, Leonard D'Aiuto, Cemil Celik, Joel Wood, Vishwajit L. Nimgaonkar*
University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
sec.p: Background: Copy number variants at 15q11.2 are associated with intellectual disability, autism and schizophrenia (SZ). This region, spanning BP1-BP2 is part of the Angelman/Prader-Willi region and encodes CYFIP, NIPA1, NIPA2 and TUBGCP5. From animal models, all four genes are important for brain morphogenesis. As these genes have not been investigated in human neurodevelopment, we have analyzed gene expression and neuronal morphology in differentiating induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) from individuals with the 15q11.2 deletion.

Methods: The proband and his mother, both bearing a deletion at chr 15q11.2 were compared with an unrelated control without deletion. The proband was also diagnosed with SZ, but not his mother. The deletions were identified using qPCR and array-CGH. Fibroblasts derived from skin biopsies were reprogrammed conventionally with Sendai viral vector expressing transcription factors Sox2, c-Myc, Klf4 and Oct4. Following quality control, the iPSCs were differentiated into neural rosettes and neuronal progenitor cells (NPCs) and then to glutamatergic neurons. Gene expression was analyzed using Taqman qPCR assays and normalized against beta actin. Since CYFIP interacts with FMRP, its expression was also analyzed. The transcription of these genes was analyzed in relation to control values (fold changes, FC). To evaluate dendritic spine morphology, iPSCs derived neurons were transfected with pEGFP vector and immunostained with human anti-Cyfip monoclonal antibody, followed by confocal microscopy.

Results: Reduced expression of all 4 genes was noted in fibroblasts (FC: 0.2-0.3). The expression levels were higher in iPSCs than in fibroblasts, but were still reduced in comparison with control values: CYFIP (FC: 0.78), NIPA2 (0.67), TUBGC5 (0.59). Expression increased further in NPCs, but the expression of NIPA1 was remarkably variable. NIPA1 and CYFIP expressions are correlated with the expression of FMRP across all three cell types (Pearson’s correlations: 0.95 and 0.81; p=0.004 and 0.051, respectively). Further, immunostaining indicated that CYFIP is localized to dendritic spines, concordant with animal data. Reduced numbers as well as density of dendritic spine were noticed in deletion cell lines compared to controls.

Conclusions: Reduced expression of CYFIP, NIPA2 and TUBGC5 (but not NIPA1) was observed in all cell types examined, suggesting compensatory mechanisms for NIPA1. The expression of NIPA1 and CYFIP is correlated with FMRP, suggesting functional relationships. Consistent with animal models, reduced number and complexity of dendritic spine was observed in iPSCs derived neurons. Differentiating iPSCs can serve as useful models to understand human dendritic spines in the chr 15q11.2 deletion syndrome.
Keywords: iPSC, dendritic spine, CNV, intellectual disability.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T215. A Feasibility Study Evaluating Differential Proteomic Expression in Mood Disorders
Mark Frye*, Doo-Sup Choi, Simon Kung, Marin Veldic, Brian Palmer, Paul Croarkin, Malik Nassan, William Bobo, Greg Jenkins, Katherine Moore, Osama Abulseoud, Sue Tye, Scott Feeder, Joanna Biernacka
Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minnesota
sec.p: Background: Biomarkers could potentially enhance the diagnostic assessment and treatment recommendations in mood disorders.

Methods: Patients with unipolar (UP) or bipolar (BP) depression and age/gender matched controls were recruited. Clinical assessments included: Structured Diagnostic Interview for DSM-IV-TR, Inventory for Depressive Symptoms (IDS), and the Young Mania Rating Scale. One 7.5 cc tube of blood was drawn into serum separator for proteomic multiplex analyses utilizing the DiscoveryMAPTM. 288 samples (52 UP, 49 BPII, 46 BPI, 144 Controls) were randomized to 4 plates where 300 proteins were measured. Protein measurements with ≥ 95% of samples above lower level of quantification were included in the analyses. Rank transformed proteins were tested for differences between diagnostic groups adjusted for randomization plate and clinical variables (gender, age, BMI, fasting, smoking status, alcohol use, history of suicide attempts, and years of education). Due to the large number of proteins tested, multiple testing was addressed using Bonferroni or Holm’s stepdown procedure.

Results: Eight analytes showed group differences that ranged from p=0.001–p=0.04. The difference between BP I and controls in 7/8 analytes showed statistically significant differences ranging from p=8.50E-05 – p=0.01. Further predictive modeling for discriminating groups will be presented.

Conclusions: These preliminary results, while small and not adjusted for medication state, do suggest feasibility in testing for proteomic differences in mood disorders vs healthy controls and in particular suggest potential utility for bipolar I depression.
Keywords: biomarker, depression, proteomics, platform.
Disclosure: This study was funded by Myriad Genetics.

sec.title: T216. Identifying Polymer-forming SAM Domains Involved in Neurotransmission and Psychiatric illness
Alejandro Meruelo*, James Bowie
University of California at San Diego, San Diego, California
sec.p: Background: Sterile alpha motif (SAM) domains are common protein modules in eukaryotic cells. It has not been possible to assign functions to uncharacterized SAM domains because they have been found to participate in diverse functions ranging from protein-protein interactions to RNA binding. Many of these associated proteins play a role in psychiatric disorders.

Methods: Here we computationally identify likely members of the subclass of SAM domains that form polymers. Sequences were virtually threaded onto known polymer structures and then evaluated for compatibility with the polymer.

Results: We find that known SAM polymers score better than the vast majority of known non-polymers: 100% (7 of 7) of known polymers and only 8% of known non-polymers (1 of 12) score above a defined threshold value. Of 2901 SAM family members, we found 694 that score above the threshold and are likely polymers, including SAM domains from the proteins Bicaudal-C, Liprin-beta, Synaptotagmin-3, and Shank3. We also predict some SAM domains form non-polymers, including Caskin-2 ANKS1B, and SAMD4.

Conclusions: Bicaudal-C is a homolog of BicC that plays a protective role against Major Depressive Disorder. Liprins are divided into two classes, liprin-alpha that are involved in organizing the active zone of neural synapses and liprin-beta that interact directly with liprin-alpha proteins. Synaptotagmin-3 mediates the slow-component of neurotransmitter release. Shank3 is a protein thought to play a role related in delayed speech, intellectual disability, and developmental delay in those with 22q13.3 deletion syndrome as well as autism spectrum disorder. Caskin-2 is a protein that plays a role in X-linked mental retardation. ANKS1B is a protein that plays a role in normal brain development and the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease given its known interaction with amyloid beta protein precursor. ANKS1B may also be involved in mediating effects of atypical antipsychotics (olanzapine and risperidone) in schizophrenia to target negative symptoms. SAMD4 is a homolog of Smaug, an RNA-binding SAM. It is associated with weight loss and in neuronal dendrites within mRNA silencing foci that disassemble in response to the neurotransmitter N-methyl-D-aspartate.
Keywords: Schizophrenia, Depression, Alzheimer’s disease, X-linked Mental Retardation.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T217. Neuroimaging Evidence of Neuroinflammation in Chronic Schizophrenia
Martha Shenton*, Marek Kubicki, Ofer Pasternak
Brigham & Women's Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts
sec.p: Background: Schizophrenia has been considered a deteriorating disease, in which the majority of neurodegenerative changes occur in its early stages. In a previous study we demonstrated, using a novel diffusion MRI analysis called free-water imaging, that the early stages of schizophrenia are more likely associated with a neuroinflammatory response and less so with a white matter deterioration or a demyelination process. What is not known is how neuroinflammation and white matter deterioration change along the progression of the disorder. The aim of this study is to compare the extent of free-water imaging abnormalities in chronic subjects with what was previously observed for subjects at their first psychotic episode.

Methods: We applied a measure of free-water, developed by Pasternak in our laboratory, to a population of 29 patients diagnosed with chronic schizophrenia subjects and compare them with 25 group matching controls.

Results: Patients diagnosed with chronic schizophrenia show a limited extent of abnormal increase in the volume of extracellular space, likely indicative of a less extensive neuroinflammatory response, relative to patients at the onset of schizophrenia. At the same time, the chronic patients evinced a greater extent of reduced fractional anisotropy in and surrounding tissue, compared to our previous study, suggesting increased white matter deterioration that coincides with progression of the disease.

Conclusions: Our findings thus substantiate the role of neuroinflammation in the earlier stages of the disorder, and the effect of neurodegeneration that is worse in the more chronic phase of the disease.
Keywords: schizophrenia, diffusion tensor imaging, neuroinflammation, neurodegeneration.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T218. Assessment of Craving Using Virtual Reality in Cannabis Users with Schizophrenia
Heidi Wehring*, Stephen Heishman, Robert McMahon, Hailey Turner, Kelli Sullivan, Bernard Fischer, Laura Rowland, Patrick Bordnick, Henry Holcomb, Ann Kearns, Fang Liu, Deanna Kelly
University of Maryland Medical School, Baltimore, Maryland
sec.p: Background: Cannabis use is prevalent in schizophrenia and has been associated with low treatment adherence, leading to increased symptoms and higher rehospitalization risk. Reasons for the increased prevalence are not known; however, theories have suggested cannabis use may be associated with symptom onset as well as a form of self-treatment. Cue-elicited craving for marijuana activates the reward neurocircuitry associated with addiction, and cannabis seems similar to other illicit drugs in their effects on biological and psychosocial parameters. Craving has been reported weeks to years after last drug use, and is a prominent withdrawal symptom. Persons with schizophrenia may have abnormal dopamine-mediated responses to rewarding stimuli, presumably due to deficits in function of mesolimbic circuitry. Virtual reality (VR) has recently been used in the general population to elicit craving. Establishing and validating a model of cue-elicited responsivity such as virtual reality will allow future investigations of craving, and ultimately designs for studying the efficacy of anti-craving interventions for cannabis users with schizophrenia.

Methods: Fourteen persons with DSM-IV diagnosis of schizophrenia and cannabis use completed this study. Participants were between the ages of 18-55, with a lifetime history of at least 50 cannabis uses and average use of at least once monthly and a stable antipsychotic regimen. Persons with active diagnoses of substance abuse (besides cannabis or nicotine) within the past month or dependence within the past 6 months, positive urine toxicology, pregnancy, or history of head injury/seizure, or severe motion sickness were excluded. Participants were assessed on cannabis use, triggers for use, and symptoms. The study used a comparison-controlled, within-subject design. All participants underwent baseline assessment and acclimation period and then participated in an experiment in which four cues were presented in separate rooms in the VR program (Virtually BetterTM). These included two cannabis cues (a paraphernalia room and a social interaction room) and two neutral cues in four rooms, each of three minutes in length. At baseline and after each cue room, participants completed the Marijuana Craving Questionnaire-Short Form (MCQ-SF), the Marijuana Craving Visual Analog Scale (MCAS), and the Mood Form. Physiological measures were assessed throughout the experimental session. The Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) and Schedule for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms (SANS) were used as measures to monitor potential changes in symptoms of schizophrenia. The Realism and Presence Questionnaire was used to assess the virtual reality experience.

Results: Participants were primarily male (93%) and Black (71%). Average age was 31.4 years (s.d. 8.1) and education level was 10.9 years (1.9). Average age at first marijuana use was 14.2 years (2.4), average current frequency of use was between less than one joint per day to 2-3 joints daily, averaging $140 spent on drugs in the past month. Average duration of longest cannabis use was 10.4 (6.10) years. Peak cannabis use (lifetime) was at least 2-3 joints/day for 93% of the sample. Using a 100-point visual analog scale, craving changed from 40.4 (26.9) after the first neutral cue to 55.3 (34.1) after the paraphernalia room (df=12, t=-2.45, p=0.03) and 53.9 (32.1) (df=12, t=-2.-01, p=0.07) after the social interaction room. A trend for increased craving on the MCQ-SF total was found for the paraphernalia experience: 43.9 (19.03) at baseline to 48.5 (18.9) (estimate 4.6, s.e.m., 2.4, df=11.8, t=1.9, p=0.08) after paraphernalia. 64% (9/14) of participants stated that the exposure “somewhat” to “completely” simulated a real life experience.

Conclusions: The results of this pilot study indicate that virtual reality environments may be safely used in participants with schizophrenia, and that overall participants reported moderate immersion and presence in the environment. Craving data suggest that participants with schizophrenia may experience differences in craving patterns and this may impact the use of differing types of cue-elicited craving for studies.
Keywords: cannabis, craving, schizophrenia, virtual reality.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T219. A Method to Assess the Generalizability of Clinical Trials Results: Application to the Treatment of Substance Use Disorders
Aimee Campbell, Melanie Wall, Mark Olfson, Shuai Wang, Edward Nunes, Carlos Blanco*
Columbia University, New York, New York
sec.p: Background: Increased emphasis on evidence-based, personalized and precision medicine has brought to the fore the importance of assessing the generalizability of clinical trial results to relevant populations. If participants in clinical trials differ substantially from the target population, estimates of treatment effects derived from the trials may have limited applicability in clinical practice. Advances in the application of propensity scores, which are statistical methods to address the comparability of different groups, permit assessment of the generalizability of findings in observational studies. However, to date, no clinical trial in psychiatry has applied this method to examine the generalizability of its results at the national level. The goal of this study was to evaluate a recent clinical trial of substance abuse treatment to estimate differences between the sample recruited for the study and a nationally representative sample of the target population.

Methods: We used logistic regression models to estimate the probability that participants in a recently published clinical trial for the treatment of substance use disorders would have been randomly drawn from a nationally representative sample of US adults. The clinical trial, with the goal to examine the effectiveness of 12 weeks of the Therapeutic Education System (TES; web-based behavioral intervention for substance use disorders) versus treatment-as-usual, consisted of adult men and women (N=507) entering 10 outpatient addiction treatment programs across the US. The general population sample consisted of Wave 1 of the National Epidemiological Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions (NESARC). We used the inverse of those probabilities to derived propensity scores of having participated in the trial. The propensity scores were then used as to reweight the clinical sample and obtain estimates of the effectiveness of TES. To obtain a range of estimates of effectiveness, we conducted these analyses in four different target samples: a) individuals with substance use in the previous year; b) individuals with substance use disorder (SUD) in the previous year; c) individuals with substance dependence in the previous year; and d) individuals with an SUD who had sought treatment in the previous year.

Results: Prior to reweighting the sample, the OR of response to TES versus treatment-as-usual was 1.62 (95% CI=1.12-2.35), as previously reported.18 After reweighting the sample to be representative of those with substance use in the last year, the OR was 1.33 (95% CI=0.34-5.26). Corresponding ORs were obtained after reweighting the sample to be representative of individuals with a substance use disorder (1.16 (95% CI=0.40-3.37)), substance dependence (1.88 (95% CI=0.72-4.6)) and treatment seeking for a substance use disorder in the last year (1.64 (95% CI=0.82-3.27)).

Conclusions: After reweighting the clinical trial sample by the propensity score weights, the distribution of its covariates was similar to those in the representative samples. The resulting point estimates of the intervention all fell within the confidence interval of the original clinical trial, but the associated 95% confidence intervals of the four nationally representative samples were substantially wider than the confidence interval from the clinical trial. These wider confidence intervals reflect the increased uncertainty associated with extrapolating results from a select sample to a national representative sample. More broadly, our study exemplifies a novel approach to estimating the population generalizability of clinical trial results and may help to refine clinical trial methods, estimate population-level effects of interventions, and advance personalized and precision medicine. Trial Registration: clincialtrials.gov Identifier: NCT01104805.
Keywords: Generalizability, Propensity scores, Clinical Trial, Substance-related disorders.
Disclosure: Supported by grants DA019606 (Dr. Blanco) and U10 DA013035 (Dr. Nunes).

sec.title: T220. Age-dependent Effects of Ethanol on Glutamate Dynamics in the Prefrontal Cortex of Awake Rats Using Microelectrode Amperometry
Asa Konradsson-Geuken*, Devesh Mishra, Nicholas R. Harrison, Carolina B. Gonzales, Bjorn Schilstrom
Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden
sec.p: Background: Brain development and maturation continues during adolescence until adulthood in humans. There are continuous morphological and functional alterations within the brain, modulated by external psychosocial, environmental, cultural, economic and biological factors that shape the individuals' behavior as an adult. Synaptic pruning is one such remodelling mechanism occuring in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) during adolescence leading to dramatic changes in the number of synapses. Excitatory glutamatergic N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors play a critical role in processes involved in synapse strengthening or removal. Therefore, the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate, activating the NMDA receptor, likely plays an important role in normal brain development. Ethanol consumption during adolescence has been suggested to interfere with maturational processes and can have detrimental effects on overall brain development. In particular, the development of the PFC which, among other functions, imparts an inhibitory control over behaviors like risk-taking and ethanol over-consumption, may be drastically impaired and may predispose the individual (adolescent) to the risk of developing ethanol addiction later in life.

Methods: In this study, we investigated glutamate dynamics with a second-by-second time resolution in the PFC of freely moving animals, using enzyme-based microelectrode amperometry. We analyzed the effects of an intraperitoneal ethanol injection (1g/kg) on cortical glutamate levels in adolescent (pre-pubertal and pubertal) and adult rats.

Results: Interestingly, basal glutamate levels decreased significantly with age. We also observed spontaneous glutamate release i.e. glutamate transients throughout the recordings. The frequency (transients/hour) and amplitude (μM) of transients were significantly higher in adolescent animals compared to those of adults. In adolescent rats, the frequency and amplitude of glutamate transients were significantly decreased within the first hour following ethanol injection. The transients slowly recovered and in the third hour after the ethanol injection there was even a tendency to a rebound increase in the frequency of glutamate transients. In control animals receiving saline injection there were no significant changes in either frequency or amplitude of glutamate transients.

Conclusions: Our observed differences in basal glutamate levels as well as glutamate transients between adolescent and adult animals support the notion that significant changes in cortical glutamatergic neurotransmission occur during development. Also, as we observe a reduction of transient frequency and amplitude in the intact brain our data suggest that in addition to postsynaptic NMDA receptor inhibition, ethanol may reduce firing rate of afferent glutamate input. Inhibitory effects of ethanol on glutamate transmission in the adolescent prefrontal cortex may disturb its mauration (e.g.pruning) and thereby contribute to increased susceptibility of an individual to develop addiction later in life.
Keywords: Ethanol, Adolescent, Prefrntal cortex, Glutamate.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T221. Sparse Generalized Functional Linear Models for Predicting Treatment Resistance with Longitudinal Data
Yashu Liu, Zhi Nie, Qingqin Li, Vaibhav Narayan, Husseini Manji*, Jieping Ye, Gayle Wittenberg
Janssen Research & Development LLC of Johnson & Johnson, Titusville, New Jersey
sec.p: Background: Major depressive disorder is a dynamic illness in which symptoms evolve over time, both naturally and in the context of treatment. Longitudinal patient data, specifically information collected more frequently than the typical interval between patient visits, is expected to improve the ability to detect changes in a patient’s disease, and enable better patient-decision-making. The increased availability of these data needs to be matched with improved analytic methods. Here we propose a novel sparse generalized functional linear model, designed to enable high-dimensional learning with longitudinal feature selection. To test this method, longitudinal data available from the first antidepressant treatment (Level 1) in the Sequenced Treatment Alternatives to Relieve Depression (STAR*D) is used to predict remission status in response to a second antidepressant treatment (Level 2).

Methods: Level 1 longitudinal variables used for prediction were comprised of 202 features collected at each patient visit, and included the 16-item Clinician version of the Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (QIDS-C16) and Frequency, Intensity, and Burden of Side Effects Ratings (FIBSER) Scale. The B-spline basis function was chosen for the proposed sparse functional logistic regression model. We evaluate the model based on the performance of the classifiers built to discriminate the remission cohort (N=240; the 16-item Self-Report version of the Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology, QIDS-SR16<=5) from the non-remission cohort (N=356) at the end of Level 2. We further classify a sub-group of non-remission samples whose QIDS-SR16>=11 (N=161) to explore the relationship between extreme phenotype (i.e. higher depressive symptoms) and predictability. To evaluate model performance, we compare our model with those using Random Forest and Sparse Logistic Regression. Presented results were obtained from 5-fold cross-validation.

Results: Sparse functional logistic regression outperformed both Random Forest and Sparse logistic regression for each classification task. In a comparison of level 2 remission vs. non-remission, the model had an accuracy=70.3+/- 1.9%, sensitivity=73.3+/- 6.9%, and specificity=68.27+/- 3.1%. For patients with high depressive symptoms at the end of level 2, the model had an accuracy=77.1+/- 4.5%, sensitivity=77.9+/- 3.8%, and specificity=75.8+/- 10.4%. Top performing longitudinal features were Side Effect Frequency, Side Effect Burden, Heart-Related Side Effects, QIDS Suicidial Ideation, QIDS Energy/Fatigability, and the QIDS-C total score. Interestingly, the relative importance of each functional coefficient evolves over time.

Conclusions: Extensive and thorough experiments show that the proposed sparse functional regression method achieves significantly higher accuracy than existing approaches and is able to identify predictive and interpretable longitudinal features. The ability to perform prediction from longitudinal data analysis is growing in importance with the advent of new mobile and wearable technologies, as well as the increasing use and accessibility of electronic medical records. Coupled with improved analytic methods, these will enable a shift towards ‘disease interception’ via earlier prediction of therapeutic response or lack of response, and prevention of relapses and recurrences.
Keywords: Treatment Resistance, Predictive Models, Antidepressant, Major Depressive Disorder.
Disclosure: Authors Qingqin Li, Vaihbav Narayan, Husseini Manji, and Gayle Wittenberg are employees of Janssen R&D, LLC; Jieping Ye is a consultant to Janssen R&D, LLC.

sec.title: T222. Social Cognition, Social Competence, and Negative Symptoms: Influences on Real World Social Outcomes
Marc Kalin*, Philip Harvey, Sara Kaplan, Amy Pinkham, David Penn
University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, Miami, Florida
sec.p: Background: Social deficits are common in people with schizophrenia and the treatment of social skills deficits has been a long-time treatment strategy. Recently there has been a huge increase in interest in social cognition as both a determinant of social deficits and as a treatment target on its own. However, negative (i.e., deficit) symptoms also appear to contribute substantially to social dysfunction. Our previous research as suggested that negative symptoms account for considerably more variance in social outcomes than social skills, raising the question as to whether a systematic assessment of social cognition would improve the prediction of these everyday social outcomes by factors other than amotivation and other negative symptoms.

Methods: In this study, we examined the differential prediction of social outcomes measured by the Specific Levels of Functioning (SLOF) by negative symptoms (PANSS factor analysis derived), social skills measured with a performance based assessment of social competence (Social Skills Performance Assessment), and 6 different social cognition measures examining emotion recognition, theory of mind, and attributions and trust in 198 patients with schizophrenia These 6 measures were selected as the best social cognition outcomes measures to date in terms of psychometrics with a systematic RAND panel procedure. Social outcomes were rated by a high contact clinician who was unaware of the rest of the data collected. We used regression models to examine the influences of social cognition on social competence as well as as the overall prediction of social outcomes with social cognition, social competence, and negative symptoms.

Results: The combination of social cognition, social competence, and negative symptoms accounted for 30% of the variance in social outcomes. In addition, social cognition accounted for 20% of the variance in social competence, with two different emotion recognition tests, but not theory of mind measures, predicting social competence. When we used a step-wise model to identify the individual negative symptoms and social competence domains that predicted social outcomes, we found that active social avoidance was the best predictor of social deficits (12% variance, p<.001), followed by social competence (8%, p<.001), emotion recognition (Bell-Lysaker emotion Recognition test: 5%, p<.01), and blunted affect (5%, p<.01). When we examined social cognition variables alone, the overall variance accounted for was unchanged, suggesting that social cognition does not overlap with negative symptoms, at least in terms of their joint relationships with social outcomes.

Conclusions: These data suggest that negative symptoms exert a substantial influence on social outcomes and that social skills and competence also exert smaller, but independent influences. As would be expected, deficits in social cognition, particularly emotion recognition, are associated with impairments in social skills. Treating negative symptoms appears to be a possible path for improving social outcomes and one that may have a larger impact than interventions aimed at either social cognition or social competence alone.
Keywords: Social Cognition, Negative Symptoms, Social Competence, Social Deficits.

Disclosure: Philip D. Harvey: Consultant to: Abbvie, Boeheringer-Ingelheim, Forest Labs, Forum Pharma, Genentech, Lundbeck, Otsuka America, Roche, Sanofi,Sunovion Marc Kalin: No financial disclosures Sara Kaplan: No financial disclosures Amy Pinkham: No financial disclosures David Penn: No financial disclosures.

sec.title: T223. Gut Microbiota Distributions in Patients with Anxious and Non-anxious Depressive Mood Presentations
Brittany Mason*, Andrew Y. Koh, Madhukar H. Trivedi
University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, Texas
sec.p: Background: Attempts to develop companion diagnostics in depression and validate relevant biomarkers have been hampered due to diagnostic uncertainty about sub-types. Clarifying the underlying physiology within disorder sub-types will help determine clinically applicable biomarkers. The gut-brain axis directly links the peripheral gut to brain via vagal innervation and hormonal communication. Important internal cues come from either direct threat (e.g., a toxin) or perceived threat (e.g., sensation of unease), and some of these important cues come from the gut. Important modulators of this axis are the gut microbiota, the diverse biological community of bacteria which lines the gut and actively contributes to physiological regulation, with pre-clinical models showing both anxiogenic and anxiolytic properties based on microbiota distribution.

Methods: The present study characterizes the gut microbiome of subjects with MDD using bacterial group qPCR, and compares the bacterial populations to symptomatic presentation in order to evaluate whether particular gut bacteria can distinguish psychiatric presentation.

Results: Analysis of the gut microbiome of patients with current MDD with and without anxious presentation revealed altered microflora, and is the first human study to indicate those with anxious presentation have reduced pro-inflammatory bacteria Enterobacteriaceae (Mann-Whitney, p=0.01) and have reduced anti-inflammatory bacteria C. leptum (Mann-Whitney, p=0.02).

Conclusions: These data highlight an interesting physiological marker which segregates with the presentation of anxiety symptomatology that may be used to further clarify patient presentation. Further exploration of the contribution of additional bacterial subtypes is underway.
Keywords: Depression, Anxiety, Gut Microbiome, Biomarkers.

Disclosure: Madhukar H. Trivedi is or has been an advisor/consultant to: Abbott Laboratories, Inc., Abdi Ibrahim, Akzo (Organon Pharmaceuticals Inc.), Alkermes, AstraZeneca, Axon Advisors, Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Cephalon, Inc., Cerecor, Concert Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Eli Lilly & Company, Evotec, Fabre Kramer Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Forest Pharmaceuticals, GlaxoSmithKline, Janssen Global Services, LLC, Janssen Pharmaceutica Products, LP, Johnson & Johnson PRD, Libby, Lundbeck, Meade Johnson, MedAvante, Medtronic, Merck, Mitsubishi Tanabe Pharma Development America, Inc., Naurex, Neuronetics, Otsuka Pharmaceuticals, Pamlab, Parke-Davis Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Pfizer Inc., PgxHealth, Phoenix Marketing Solutions, Rexahn Pharmaceuticals, Ridge Diagnostics, Roche Products Ltd., Sepracor, SHIRE Development, Sierra, SK Life and Science, Sunovion, Takeda, Tal Medical/Puretech Venture, Targacept, Transcept, VantagePoint, Vivus, and Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories. In addition, he has received research support from: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), Corcept Therapeutics, Inc., Cyberonics, Inc., National Alliance for Research in Schizophrenia and Depression, National Institute of Mental Health, National Institute on Drug Abuse, Novartis, Pharmacia & Upjohn, Predix Pharmaceuticals (Epix), and Solvay Pharmaceuticals, Inc.

sec.title: T224. Optical Clearance and Neuroimaging of Intact Neural Circuits in Ex Vivo Mouse Brain
Eric Chang*, Miklos Argyelan, Toni-Shay Chandon, Ryan Zhang, Manisha Aggarwal, Susumu Mori, Anil Malhotra
Zucker Hillside Hospital, Glen Oaks, New York
sec.p: Background: Recent technological developments in the imaging and analysis of brain tissues have provided unprecedented high-resolution views of neural circuits at both microscopic and macroscopic scales. New biochemical protocols such as CLARITY and SeeDB render brain tissue optically transparent while preserving the underlying neural circuitry and allow researchers to study how brain areas, neurons, and fiber bundles connect to one another. This is an especially useful development for translational psychiatry as many disorders, such as schizophrenia, do not exhibit obvious neuropathology and are hypothesized to be dysfunctions of connectivity.

Methods: We optically cleared mouse brains from C57BL/6J and Thy1-YFP-H mice (The Jackson Labs) using either the SeeDB or CLARITY protocols. For SeeDB, mice were transcardially perfused with paraformaldehyde (PFA), brains were extracted, and 2-3 mm blocks of tissue were processed according to the protocol. For CLARITY, mice were transcardially perfused with a PFA-hydrogel solution and then the brains were extracted. The hydrogel brain was polymerized and the brain was cleared in an electrophoretic clearing chamber (ETC) for several days. After ETC clearing, brains were incubated in primary antibodies followed by a fluorescent secondary antibody (Alexa Fluor 488 or 633, Life Technologies). For fluorescence imaging, cleared and labeled tissue samples were imaged on an Olympus Fluoview FV1200 multi-photon microscope with Mai Tai DeepSee laser (Spectra Physics). For DTI, we scanned PFA-fixed mouse brains ex vivo in an 11.7 T magnetic resonance (MR) scanner. Brains were scanned in a PBS-Magnevist solution during 16-22 hr acquisition sessions. Following MR scanning, samples were processed with either SeeDB or CLARITY clearing protocols and subsequently imaged on the multi-photon microscope.

Results: We were able to optically clear whole mouse brains, half-brains, and 2-3 mm tissue blocks using CLARITY (n=10 mice). Using antibodies to target tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) and myelin basic protein (MBP), we were able to image through whole and half-brain samples up to a depth of 3 mm and visualize large areas of dopamine-containing neurons (TH) or myelin-positivity (MBP). With SeeDB, we were not able to clear whole adult mouse brains, but could clear 2 mm tissue blocks with excellent preservation of the YFP signal in Thy1-YFP mice (n=12 mice). In the MR scanned brains (n=4 mice), the MR scanning procedure did not appear to affect subsequent clearing protocols. In comparing DTI images processed with TrackVis software against fluorescence images analyzed using Imaris software (Bitplane), we were able to compare several white matter bundles for potential correlative metrics. For the fornix and lateral septum structures; TrackVis 2-seed track counts (1629), voxel counts (5723), fitted FA (0.48±0.15) vs. Imaris mean pixel intensities (68.004), intensity range (16-254), volume (2010.36 μm3), and mean path length (3008.1±96.2 μm). We are in the process of quantifying other parameters within the MR signal, such as 3-D fractional anisotropy (FA) and mean diffusivity (MD) maps in order to compare these against 3-D fluorescence signals that are either endogenously present in genetically engineered animals or have been stained using antibody-based techniques.

Conclusions: With the ability to examine large intact brain samples, we can gain insight into the structural connectivity and organization of the brain in both health and disease. These technological advances will allow us to investigate, with high-resolution, the neural circuitry on mesoscopic (neuronal populations) and macroscopic scales to better understand how connectivity may be altered in schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders. We can also use these biochemical and neuroimaging tools to study how anti-psychotic drugs can potentially modify specific neuronal populations or white matter tracts.
Keywords: mouse brain, CLARITY, SeeDB, neural circuits.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T225. Geographical Momentary Assessment: Predicting Mood and Craving from Real-time Neighborhood Surroundings
Kenzie L. Preston*, Matthew Tyburski, Karran A. Phillips, Michelle L. Jobes, Debra Furr-Holden, David H. Epstein
National Institute on Drug Abuse, National Institutes of Health, Baltimore, Maryland
sec.p: Background: Mobile, real-time substance abuse interventions could be based on live predictions of changes in mood and craving. Although there are smartphone apps intended to help people in recovery from substance addiction, none of these apps offers real-time warnings of an imminent risk of craving or lapse on the basis of the user’s current behavior or travels. In a Geographical Momentary Assessment (GMA) study with real-time self-report (Ecological Momentary Assessment, EMA) and location (GPS) data, we found that the strength of the relationships between neighborhood characteristics and participants’ mood and craving increased with inclusion of GPS track data from up to about 5 hrs prior to each self-report. Here we tested whether GPS track data could predict the contents of self-reports into the future, as a live intervention would need to do.

Methods: We collected GPS data and EMA ratings of mood, stress, and drug craving for 16 weeks in 27 methadone-maintained polydrug users. Participants’ tracks were calculated for the 12 hrs before each EMA entry. Physical disorder encountered in participants’ tracks were calculated from observer-rated Neighborhood Inventory for Environmental Typology scores (NIfEty; Furr-Holden). We used a randomForest machine-learning model to predict EMA responses (stress, heroin craving, and negative and positive mood). Five hours of track data were used; only random prompts that were preceded by at least 6.5 hours of GPS data were included, so that a consistent time-series could be used to predict into the future. The randomForest model was calibrated with 600 trees and 7 nodes for each of the future-prediction models. In the absence of a priori knowledge of what proportion of the data to use for training and what proportion to reserve for validation, we tested models developed with training/validation splits of 50/50%, 60/40%, 70/30%, 80/20% and 90/10%. Thus, five randomForest models were trained for each of the four EMA outcome measures at each of the three temporal delays (predicting responses 30, 60, or 90 minutes into the future). For the models predicting stress and heroin craving (classification models with only five levels of response), we used weighted kappas to describe the accuracy of the models. For the models predicting positive and negative mood (linear-regression models), we used the R from the randomForest procedure to describe the accuracy of the models.

Results: We matched 3,711 randomly prompted EMA entries to locations; 743 EMA entries met the criteria for inclusion in the analyses. Future-predicting model accuracy was very high for prediction of positive and negative mood scores (R values typically 0.70 to 0.97), moderate for prediction of stress (kappas typically 0.50 to 0.65), and low for prediction of heroin craving (kappas typically 0.20 to 0.35). For example, for the 90% training/10% validation data split training model, kappas/R values for training/validation were as follows: stress 0.52/0.65; heroin craving 0.24/0.45; negative mood 0.92/0.79; positive mood 0.97/0.89.

Conclusions: These results provide initial support for use of GPS tracks as part of an algorithm to predict, intervene in, and perhaps prevent, changes in mood and stress. A caveat to this finding is that these models used aggregated data from all 27 participants in the pilot study, rather than predicting the future for any one participant, as a live intervention would require. We are addressing that issue in a larger trial.
Keywords: ecological momentary assessment, craving, stress, environment.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T226. Preventing Anxiety and Depression in Older Racial/Ethnic Minority Adults: The Case for Health Promotion
Daniel Jimenez*, Stephen Bartels, Margarita Alegria, Charles Reynolds, Philip Harvey
University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, Miami, Florida
sec.p: Background: Depressive and anxiety disorders are among the most common, disabling, and costliest disorders in old age. The identification of people at greatest risk for common mental disorders (depression and anxiety) and the development of timely and empirically based interventions to prevent these mental disorders are major public health challenges. Available treatments are difficult to access and only partially satisfactory in reducing symptom burden, sustaining remission, and averting years lived with disability. These factors underscore the need for interventions focused on prevention that are both effective and scalable. One promising approach is the use of lay community health workers (CHWs) to deliver simple, scalable interventions. The use of CHWs is an important means of task shifting to enable more efficient utilization of scarce mental health resources. Latino older adults are an important and appropriate group in whom to develop and test innovative, culturally adapted approaches for prevention of common mental disorders. They are the largest and fastest growing segment of the older adult population. Moreover, high prevalence of common mental disorders combined with mental health service use disparities makes older Latinos a high-risk population for whom scalable preventive interventions could have great public health impact. In addition, older Latinos are at increased risk for diabetes, obesity, reduced physical activity, and mortality. Cultural beliefs about the causes of mental illness and stigma about help seeking may further contribute to Latinos’ limited access and low utilization of mental health care.

Methods: This study is an exploratory, randomized controlled pilot trial. Our trial tests the feasibility and potential effectiveness of Happy Older Latinos are Active (HOLA), a health promotion intervention, led by a CHW, to prevent depression and anxiety in at-risk older Latinos.
