A total of 60 older Latinos (aged 60+) will be randomized to receive HOLA or culturally tailored psychoeducational material. HOLA was designed to address depression and anxiety symptoms as well as physical and psychosocial functioning. It will achieve this goal through two related mechanisms, Behavioral Activation (BA) and Social Learning Theory (SLT). HOLA uses a BA approach to engage in a physical activity routine as well as a pleasant events schedule to preempt incident and recurrent episodes of major depression and anxiety disorders and to reduce symptom severity among older Latinos with minor and subthreshold depression and anxiety. To complement this process, we used the constructs of observational learning, reinforcement, and enhanced self-efficacy postulated in SLT. The relationship between the participants and the CHW capitalizes on the personal relationship to motivate, model, and maintain health behavior change. The CHW holds the individuals accountable and individuals hold themselves accountable to the group, providing extra motivation to engage in the intervention.

Results: The primary outcomes are preemption of incident and recurrent major depression, generalized anxiety, or social phobia and reduction in depression and anxiety symptom severity. Secondary outcomes include changes in physical functioning, sedentary behaviors, social engagement, and self-efficacy.

Conclusions: The results of this study could have implications for other high risk, highly disadvantaged populations. The development of a health promotion intervention designed to prevent common mental disorders could be a means of addressing multiple disparities (e.g. mental health outcomes, mental health service use, stigma) among racial/ethnic minority elderly. Older African-Americans have low rates of mental health service use, experience high stigma and have high rates of co-morbidities. Older Asian Americans also report high stigma and believe that mental illness is a result of medical illness. Older non-Latino Whites have low rates of treatment initiation. All of these groups could benefit from the proposed health promotion intervention in the service of preventing common and disabling mental disorders.
Keywords: prevention, health promotion, racial/ethnic minority elderly, mood and anxiety disorders.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T227. Modeling Anorexia Nervosa Using Human iPS Cells
Vikas Duvvuri*, Priscilla Negraes, Fernanda Cugola, Roberto Herai, Alysson Muotri
University of California at San Diego, La Jolla, California
sec.p: Background: Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a highly heritable, neurodevelopmental disorder affecting primarily women with post-pubertal onset. Psychiatric disorders like AN are most likely syndromes with multiple genetic contributions. Patients face consequences such as high morbidity, mortality and no treatments to reverse symptoms. Genes contribute significantly to neurobiological vulnerabilities and studies have implicated a network of risk-conferring genes involved in dopamine neurotransmission. Additionally, functional neuroimaging studies reveal a dysfunctional dopaminergic (DA) reward circuit in AN. Human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) provide experimental access to the disease-risk conferring genetic complement facilitating both hypothesis-based and discovery-oriented studies. In this context, in order to model this human disease and shed light on eating disorders, we aimed to establish iPSCs from AN patients and healthy controls.

Methods: Skin fibroblasts of 6 AN patients and 2 controls were transduced with four retroviral reprogramming vectors (Sox2, Oct4, c-Myc and Klf4) as described elsewhere. iPS colonies were manually picked, expanded and characterized. The ability of the clones to differentiate into three germ layers in vitro was tested by generating embryoid bodies (EBs) in suspension in the absence of growth factors.

Results: The G-banding analysis showed that iPS cell clones derived had maintained the karyotype exhibited by fibroblasts. The characterization of these hiPSCs showed that we could successfully re-establish the pluripotent state at the molecular and cellular levels, since they were almost indistinguishable from hESC lines. Additionally, in our RNA-seq analysis we observed that iPS cells from AN patients exhibit genes that are significantly differentially expressed compared to control cells. Moreover, these cells could be differentiated into cortical neurons with no difference from unaffected counterparts. We are currently obtaining DA-enriched cultures in order to evaluate if there are significant alterations in this system among AN patients as suggested previously.

Conclusions: The establishment of AN-specific iPS and neural cell types will enable the investigation of AN-specific neural gene expression profiles and provide a route to studying the effects of risk-conferring genetic variations on molecular pathways and cellular networks. The differential expression already observed in AN-derived hiPS cells showed by transcriptome analysis highlights the feasibility of applying iPSC technology to unveil risk conferring genetic mechanisms related to eating disorders and to further characterize predisposing neurodevelopmental events.
Keywords: iPS, anorexia nervosa, genetic modeling, neurodevelopment.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T228. The Development of Wireless Deep Brain Stimulation: Preclinical Assessment for the Treatment of Alcoholism
Sheketha Hauser*, Henry Mei, Gabriel Albors, William Truitt, Pedro Irazoqui, Zachary Rodd
Indiana University School of Medicine, Indianapolis, Indiana
sec.p: Background: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is currently utilized for the treatment of numerous illnesses. The possibility that DBS could be used for the treatment of addiction has been raised in recent years. Tethered systems have limited utility under certain experimental models/procedures. The current experiments detailed the development of a wireless DBS system and the utility of wireless DBS for the treatment of alcoholism.

Methods: Recently we have experimented with tethered as well as multiple wireless DBS systems including RF powering. In the last 3 months we have developed a novel state-of-the-art system assembled from off-the-shelf electronic components. The wireless DBS system utilizes resonantly coupled filter energy transfer (RCFET) technology. By combining band-pass filter (BPF) concepts with magnetic resonance coupling (MRC), wireless stimulation of implanted electrodes can be readily achieved. Collected data has indicated that RCFET can stimulate electrodes and other relay devices through up to 10 cm of tissue. Experiments have tested whether DBS stimulation of the nucleus accumbens shell (AcbSh) can reduce alcohol consumption in alcohol-preferring (P) rats.

Results: 100 μA of DBS current variably reduced EtOH consumption, with a 35% and 43% decrease on Days 2 and 3, respectively, but with no significant effect on Days 1, 4, and 5. 200 μA of DBS current consistently reduced EtOH consumption in a delayed fashion, with a>45% decrease on Days 3-6. There was no effect of DBS on water consumption and EtOH consumption returned to baseline levels following the termination of DBS treatment. We have also examined the effects of DBS stimulation in the AcbSh on gene expression within this structure. Breifly, rats received 10 daily 1 hr periods of DBS stimulation into the AcbSh (shame control), and then the expression of G-couple receptors in the AcbSh was assessed using Taqman arrays.

Conclusions: The data indicate that unilateral high frequency stimulation of the AcbSh will reduce EtOH intake. That data indicate that the wireless DBS system is efficient at stimulating specific brain regions. The results also provided further evidence that the AcbSh is a neuroanatomical substrate for reinforcing effects of alcohol and may be a target for surgical intervention for addiction.
Keywords: Deep Brain Stimulation, Alcohol, Alcohol preferring P rats, Nucleus Accumbens.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T229. Examining Specific Circuits in Animal Models to Inform Neuromodulation Strategies for OCD Patients
Susanne Ahmari*, Timothy Spellman, Neria Douglass, Mazen Khierbek, Karl Deisseroth, Blair Simpson, Joshua Gordon, Rene Hen
University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
sec.p: Background: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a chronic, severe mental illness that affects 2-3% of people worldwide. Approximately half of all patients see minimal or partial benefit with available treatments, and up to 10% of patients are treatment-resistant with symptoms so severe that they are potential surgical candidates. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is being investigated as a surgical therapy in this treatment-resistant OCD population. Though DBS in the ventral capsule/ventral striatum (VC/VS) shows great promise, the underlying mechanism of action is unknown. Even in patients with an excellent treatment response, effects are only maintained via constant stimulation– symptoms typically relapse shortly after the stimulator is turned off. Lack of sustained symptom relief could be explained by the fact that DBS targeted to the VC/VS broadly stimulates cortical projections, striatal cell bodies, and fibers of passage, and is therefore not optimal for generating plasticity and reprogramming dysfunctional circuits. Conversely, it is possible that specific stimulation of particular cell subtypes could lead to more lasting changes in symptoms via plasticity changes. We have evidence that stimulation of specific OFC-VMS projections leads to pathologic plasticity changes, and are now testing whether optogenetic technology can be used to trigger beneficial plasticity in mouse model systems relevant to OCD.

Methods: A Cre-inducible channelrhodopsin (ChR2) or control YFP adenoviral vector was injected unilaterally into OFC of EMX-Cre transgenic mice, yielding specific ChR2 or YFP expression in cortical glutamatergic neurons. (OFC)-ventromedial striatum (VMS) projections were then stimulated via 473nm light delivered either through chronically implanted ferrules (behavioral experiments) or through stereo-optrodes implanted in VMS (awake-behaving electrophysiology experiments). Behavior (grooming, locomotion, anxiety-like behavior) and firing rates were examined in the open field 5 minutes before, during, and after stimulation [473nm, 1-5mW, 10Hz, 10msec pulse width]. Mice were then placed in a novel cage for 1 hour, and behavior was again assessed for 5 minutes. In electrophysiology experiments 0.1Hz 473nm probe pulses were presented to assess evoked firing rates. Effects of chronic stimulation on performance in a T-maze reversal-learning paradigm were also assessed. Statistical significance was determined using t-tests or analysis of variance (ANOVA), followed by post-hoc tests when applicable, using α=0.05.

Results: Though acute orbitofrontal cortex (OFC)-ventromedial striatum (VMS) stimulation did not produce repetitive behaviors, repeated hyperactivation over multiple days generated a progressive increase in grooming, a mouse behavior related to OCD (p<.02). Surprisingly, increased grooming was sustained up to 2 weeks after stimulation cessation (p<.03). In vivo recordings demonstrated that this behavioral plasticity was temporally coupled with OFC-VMS circuit plasticity shown by a progressive increase in light-evoked firing of postsynaptic VMS cells (p<.001). Further evidence for persistent electrophysiologic and behavioral changes following brief but repeated daily stimulation comes from preliminary studies demonstrating sustained decreases in striatal theta power, as well as experiments demonstrating impaired reversal learning. Ongoing experiments are testing whether repeated stimulation of OFC-VMS projections leads to plasticity and symptom reversal in transgenic OCD model systems.

Conclusions: We have demonstrated that brief but repeated optogenetic stimulation of specific cell-types can lead to persistent behavioral changes that are correlated with underlying neural plasticity. To date, we have investigated how altering neuronal firing patterns leads to persistent abnormal behaviors. However, we also expect that cell-type-specific plasticity mechanisms can be harnessed to normalize pathologic behaviors and network activity in transgenic mouse models of OCD; we are currently testing this hypothesis. These studies will provide pre-clinical proof of concept as to whether cell-type specific neuromodulation strategies could lead to sustained benefits in patients.
Keywords: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder, optogenetics, orbitofrontal cortex, striatum.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T230. Generation of Cell-specific, Retrograde Canine Adenoviral Vectors for Neural Circuit Dissection
Larry Zweifel*, Richard Palmiter, Eric Kremer
University of Washington, Seattle, Washington
sec.p: Background: Determining the precise function of neural circuit connections for the regulation of behavior is a key to furthering our understanding of the role of these connections in neuropsychopharmacology. Effective mapping of functional neural circuit connectivity requires the ability to selectively isolate a population of neurons based on discrete projections. Over the past decade numerous viral and genetic-based tools have been developed, facilitating new discoveries and reaffirming previous assertions. Anterograde and retrograde viral vectors and transport proteins now allow investigators to deliver effector genes or proteins of interest to neurons making specific connections. Each of these approaches is endowed with tremendous potential and successes are well documented. However, each of the existing approaches has distinct, and sometimes overlapping, pitfalls. In general the more tools that are made available for researchers to define the functional significance of a given neural circuit connection the more likely the right combination of approaches can be employed to address specific questions relating to neuropsychopharmacology. Canine adenovirus (CAV) is a retrogradely transducing viral vector that has been successfully used to deliver fluorescent proteins for circuit tracing and Cre recombinase for projection-specific manipulation. The benefits of CAV are that it is non-toxic, capable of transducing a wide range of neuronal cell types, and can be amplified and purified with relative ease from viral vector stocks. Although these existing CAV vectors have facilitated important discoveries the overall potential of this system has not been fully exploited. Here we report the generation of several new Cre-conditional CAV vectors that will allow for both projection specific and cell-type selective gene manipulation. With the large number of cell-specific Cre mouse and rat lines now available these new tools will be broadly useful for investigators to determine the role of specific neural connections in the regulation of behavior.

Methods: To generate retrograde, cell-selective CAV vectors we took advantage of existing Cre recombinase-based strategies to generate conditional CAV vectors. CAV vectors were generated by transfection into dog kidney cells expressing the essential E1 coding region of CAV allowing for viral amplification in cell culture. Viral vectors were subsequently purified using established procedures. To determine the effectiveness of this strategy we first generated CAV vectors containing the double loxP sequences flanking the forward open reading frame (DFO) of the fluorescent protein ZsGreen that will turn off in the presence of Cre (CAV2-DFO-ZsGreen) and the inverted open reading frame (DIO) that will turn on in the presence of Cre (CAV2-DIO-ZsGreen). Utilizing an alternate strategy we generated a CAV vector containing the optically activated ion channel ChR2 in the DIO configuration downstream of green fluorescent protein (GFP) and an internal ribosomal entry site (IRES) allowing for direct visualization of the viral vector during initial amplification in cell culture (CAV2-GFP-IRES-DIO-ChR2).

Results: Performing viral vector injections into the core region of the nucleus accumbens of mice expressing Cre recombinase under the endogenous dopamine transporter locus (Dat-Cre) we demonstrate that less than one percent of dopamine neurons in the VTA that project to the nucleus accumbens express ZsGreen when injected with the CAV2-DFO-ZsGreen, whereas several non-dopamine neurons robustly express the fluorescent reporter; thus demonstrating the effective “turning off’ of the transgene by Cre in dopamine neurons. In contrast, when Dat-Cre mice are injected with CAV2-DIO-ZsGreen into the core of the nucleus accumbens dopamine neurons projecting to this region were brightly fluorescent, whereas no non-dopamine neurons are detected; thus demonstrating the effective “turning on” of the transgene. Comparison of CAV2-DIO-ZsGreen and CAV2-DFO-ZsGreen to injections of fluorescent retrobeads into the nucleus accumbens reveals that the majority of neurons in the VTA that project to this region are retrogradely labelled. Finally, we demonstrate that injection of CAV2- GFP-IRES-DIO-ChR2 into the core of the nucleus accumbens results in expression of optically activated ChR2 in dopamine neurons of the VTA; as demonstrated with whole-cell patch clamp.

Conclusions: We have developed several new conditional CAV vectors for neural circuit dissection. We are now generating a suite of conditional CAV vectors that will be of broad use to investigators in the fields of neuropsychopharmacology.
Keywords: Circuits, Gene manipulation, canine adenovirus.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T231. Specificity of Task-active Modulation of Hippocampal Glutamate in Response to Associative Learning: A Preliminary 1H Functional Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Study
Jeffrey Stanley*, Ashley Burgess, Dalal Khatib, Karthik Ramaseshan, Noa Ofen, David R. Rosenberg, Vaibhav A. Diwadkar
Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan
sec.p: Background: Glutamate (Glu) plays a major role as an excitatory neurotransmitter in the cerebral cortex as well as in the hippocampus in which the latter is particularly rich in glutamatergic neurons. This issue is of translational relevance in disorders such as schizophrenia (SZ), in which hypo-glutamatergia (and NMDA hypo-function) have been proposed as a leading pathophysiological pathway. This hypothesis has functional implications: A task-active state during hippocampal specific tasks may result in Glu modulation that is dysfunctional. Thus, understanding of the neurochemical dynamics in the hippocampus can elucidate our understanding of SZ. However, to achieve this, it is imperative to characterize the Glu signal in a selective (to the hippocampus) task-active state. Though, it is suggested that only a small portion of the total observed Glu level by proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H MRS) is directly involved in the Glu-glutamine excitatory neurotransmission, there is 1H functional MRS (fMRS) evidence of increased Glu level in response to a visual stimulation task. Here we provide the first known evidence of selective Glu modulation in the hippocampus during associative learning but not working memory (WM). This fMRS technique can transform the assessment of SZ and other pathologies related to Glu dysfunction.

Methods: A total of 9 healthy, young adults (6M+3F; mean age 25.6±2.1yrs) participated in 2 separate 1H fMRS tasks on a 3T system. In each, 22 individual consecutive single-voxel, short-TE 1H spectra with a 54s and 56s temporal resolution (associative learning and WM), localized in the right head/body of the hippocampus (voxel:1.7x3.0x1.2cm or 6.12 cm3, PRESS, 16 avg., TR=3.38s and 3.5s, TE=23ms) were collected. The learning task previously assessed in SZ using fMRI (Wadehra et al., 2013) involved epochs of encoding (9 unique object-location pairs) and cued-retrieval (of those associated memoranda). Eight encoding-retrieval cycles were employed to allow learning to asymptote. During the WM (2-Back) task, participants indicated when a letter in the sequence was the same as one presented two items previously. Rest epochs (30s) were interspersed between task blocks. Six epochs of a finger-tapping paradigm (of varying frequency), which were interspersed with rest epochs (27s and 20s), were introduced prior to the onset of both tasks to provide a non-learning and non-memory baseline condition against which to quantitate the 1H fMRS. The analysis focused on assessing changes in hippocampal Glu and other key metabolites over the entire temporal course of the task relative to the baseline condition (and not the modulation of signals between task/rest epochs) and therefore, the 22 1H spectra per task was divided into 5 temporal segments (i.e., a baseline segment with the first 6 1H spectra followed by 4 equally spaced segments of 4 1H spectra in each). In each segment, the 1H spectra were averaged resulting in a single high-quality spectrum. LC Model was used for spectral quantification and the % change in metabolite level (Glu, NAA, PCr+Cr, GPC+PC and myo-inositol) in each segment relative to baseline was statistically analyzed using the repeated measure GEE approach with segment as the main term.

Results: Performance wise, results showed progressive improvement in associative learning (p=.042) [e.g., 1st vs 2nd segment (p=<.0001), 2nd vs 3rd (p=.081) and 3rd vs 4th (p=.010)]. The 2-Back performance, which did not involved a learning component, remained high across the task epochs without significant differences across the 4 segments (p=.23). Though the segment term for Glu failed to reach significance (p=0.12) for the learning task, post-hoc analyses showed significant increases in hippocampal Glu during the 1st, 2nd and 3rd segments relative to baseline (6.4%, 15.4% and 13.9%; all p<.0001). The PCr+Cr also failed to reach significance during the learning task (p=.17); however, post-hoc analyses showed significant increases in hippocampal PCr+Cr during the 1st, 2nd and 3rd segments relative to baseline (4.6%, 6.5% and 8.2%; all p<.0065). In contrast, there were no significant differences in 1H metabolite levels in any of the 4 segments relative to baseline in the hippocampus during WM.

Conclusions: These preliminary results provide the first ever evidence of neurochemical dynamics of the in vivo Glu signal in the hippocampus. Heightened Glu signal was observed in the hippocampus during associative learning followed by decreasing levels in response to learning proficiency (i.e., not significantly elevated during the 4th segment). In addition to Glu, PCr+Cr showed increased levels during the learning task, which suggests that neurochemical dynamics is not limited to only Glu but also metabolites associated to high-energy phosphate metabolism. 1H fMRS during the WM task (i.e., a predominantly PFC task) did not show any significant differences in hippocampal Glu compared to the baseline condition. The specificity of the Glu response to the associative learning task, suggests that 1H fMRS is highly discriminative and can be of substantive translational relevance in the in vivo characterization of SZ related psychopathology. The application to SZ is a significant focus of our ongoing studies.
Keywords: glutamate, hippocampus, function, MRS.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T232. Targeting Activated Microglia in the Brain by Delivering Antibodies via Nanoparticles
Gordana Vitaliano*, Tatyana Kramer, Abinaya Shanmugavadivu, Franco Vitaliano, John Neumeyer, Martin Teicher
Harvard Medical School, McLean Hospital, Belmont, Massachusetts
sec.p: Background: Positron emission tomography has provided important evidence for microglial activation in neuropsychiatric disorders. Antibodies (Abs) have been developed that can suppress microglial activation and prevent neurodegeneration. However, antibodies cannot easily cross an intact blood-brain-barrier (BBB) or diffuse within brain tissue. Only 0.1% of plasma Abs enter the central nervous system (CNS) naturally via diffusion through a compromised BBB, or via BBB saturation, and CNS concentrations may still be insufficient for therapeutic efficacy. Our goal was to develop a novel nanotechnology method for noninvasive high-efficiency delivery of antibodies to the CNS.

Methods: Monoclonal CD11bAbs for labeling microglia were PEGylated. Maleimide-PEG–CD11bAbs were then conjugated to clathrin triskelia (CTs) through cysteine residues. The size and uniformity of the nanoprobe was determined by dynamic light scattering. An animal model of schizophrenia was used for in vivo studies. Sprague Dawley rats received intraperitoneally 10 mg/kg of MK-801. Control animals received saline. CD11bAb-CT nanoprobes, or Abs without CTs, were delivered intranasally in rats 3 days after MK-801 administration to target activated microglia. Animals were sacrificed 3 hours after intranasal administration, and immunohistochemistry, immunofluorescent and stereological analyses were performed. Brain distribution of C14-radiolabled CD11b-Ab-nanoprobes was quantitatively assessed in rats 3 hours after intranasal administration. Different brain regions were removed, weighed, dissolved and their radioactivity measured with scintillation counting methods.

Results: One molecule of CD11bAb was attached per clathrin triskelion, and low doses (64 μg/kg) of these small (42 nm) nanoparticles were delivered intranasally in rats. Three hours later CD11bAb-nanoprobes were found only in the rat brain regions with activated microglia: retrosplenial cortex, hippocampus, entorhinal and piriform cortex. CD11b-Abs delivered without clathrin intranasally did not enter the brain. Fluorescent and light microscopic examination of these brain regions confirmed specific targeting of microglia with CD11bAb-nanoprobes. Statistical analyses with repeated measures ANOVA showed that microglial densities in hippocampus (e.g., dentate gyrus F(1,4)=110.85, p<0.0005) and retrosplenial cortex (F(1,4)=75.58, p<0.001) were markedly higher in animals that received MK801 compared to controls. The highest concentrations of CD11bAb-nanoprobes were detected in hippocampus (5±0.5 fmol/mg or 4.7% ID/g) and retrosplenial cortex (4.8±1.8 fmol/mg) of MK801 treated animals. Nanoprobes were not detected in regions lacking activated microglial cells (e.g., cerebellum). Confocal laser microscopy confirmed integrity of the nanoparticles in the rat brain, as clathrin and CD11bAb fluorescence co-localized in the rat brain.

Conclusions: Our results demonstrate that engineered clathrin nanoparticles enabled CD11b-Abs to effectively bypass a BBB intranasally, and to target MK-801 activated microglial cells within specific brain regions, using much lower doses than reported in previous BBB technologies studies. Hence, clathrin appears to provide a highly efficient nanoplatform for targeted delivery of antibodies to the CNS. This nanotechnology strategy may lead to development of new CNS theranostics for imaging of molecular changes in neuropsychiatric disorders, for monitoring disease progression and recovery, and for efficiently treating CNS disorders through targeted delivery of specific antibodies.
Keywords: clathrin nanotechnology, CD11b antibody, activated microglia, brain imaging.

Disclosure: GV and FV own equity in ExQor Technologies, Inc., the company that owns patent rights to the bioengineered clathrin protein nanotechnology (patents #7216038, #7219017, #7219018, #7393924).

sec.title: T233. Laser Capture Microdissection - Targeted Mass Spectrometry for Cortical Layer Specific Multiplexed Protein Quantification in Postmortem Human Brain Tissue
Matthew L. MacDonald*, Melanie Grubisha, Dominique Arion, Nathan Yates, David A. Lewis, Robert A. Sweet
University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Western Psychiatric Institute & Clinic, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
sec.p: Background: Cytoarchitectonic abnormalities, such as reduced dendritic spine density, have been reproducibly observed in layer 3 of multiple brain areas in schizophrenia. These alterations are widely believed to underlie deficits in cortical function and schizophrenia symptoms. While genetic and pharmacologic studies have identified synaptic singling pathways linked to disease, the molecular pathology of these cytoarchitectonic alterations remains unknown. Laser capture microdissection is routinely paired with microarray and qPCR to investigate cell type specific alterations in mRNA expression. However cell body changes in mRNA expression may not be reflected in protein levels at neuronal processes and synapses. The goal of this study is to develop and validate a laser capture microdissection – targeted mass spectrometry approach for multiplexed protein quantification in specific cortical layers of human postmortem brain tissue.

Methods: Experiment 1: Samples of layer 3 sections of increasing volume (1.6E7, 3.2E7, and 4.6E7 μm3) were prepared from a single section of postmortem dorsolateral prefrontal cortex tissue. Protein was extracted from these samples and mixed with 10 μg of a lysine 13C6 stable isotope labeled neuronal proteome standard. 288 peptides from 160 proteins were quantified by Liquid Chromatography – Selected Reaction Monitoring (LC-SRM) mass spectrometry on a TSQ Quantiva triple stage quadrupole mass spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) with a nanoACQUITY UPLC system (Waters) and a picochip column (New Objective). Experiment 2: three dorsolateral prefrontal cortex slides were prepared from the same individual. 5E7 μm3 of tissue was dissected from layers 3 and 5 from each section. Protein was extracted from these sections, mixed with 2 μg of a lysine 13C6 stable isotope labeled neuronal proteome standard, and assayed as in Experiment 1.

Results: Signal intensity increased linearly with sample volume indicating that the assay is quantitative. For example, r-squared values for signaling intensity plotted against sample volume for ATP1A1, SYN1, GNAQ, and DLG4 were 0.99, 0.94, 0.99 and 0.97, respectively. The mean coefficient of variance for repeated quantification of the 160 proteins in different layer 3 samples captured from the same individual was 8.5%, with 75% of the proteins assayed having a coefficient of variance<10%. We observed significant differences in protein expression between layers 3 and 5 and unsupervised hierarchical clustering clearly distinguished between the layers. Proteins with significantly increased expression in layer 3 included those involved in presynaptic vesicle release and the Kreb’s cycle, while the expression of glutamate receptors was largely comparable between layers 3 and 5.

Conclusions: These results demonstrate that laser capture microdissection – targeted mass spectrometry is feasible in human postmortem brain tissue, opening the door to new studies and questions in a variety of neuropsychiatric diseases. Studies to increase the number of subjects and proteins assayed, focusing on proteins with well-established differential laminar expression, are ongoing to confirm these preliminary findings of differential protein expression between layers 3 and 5 as well as further validate the approach.
Keywords: Postmortem Brain Tissue, Laser Capture, Proteomics.

Disclosure: DAL currently receives investigator-initiated research support from the Bristol-Myers Squibb Foundation, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Curridium Ltd, and Pfizer and in 2007 to 2010 served as a consultant in the areas of target identification and validation and new compound development to AstraZeneca, BioLine RX, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Hoffman-Roche, Lilly, Merck, Neurogen, and SK Life Science.

sec.title: T234. D1 Receptor Agonist DAR-0100A and Cortical Gamma Oscillations
Raymond Cho*, Nicola Polizzotto, Zachary Jessen, Christopher Walker, Ragy Girgis, Anissa Abi-Dargham, Jefferey Lieberman
University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, Texas
sec.p: Background: Cortical hypodopaminergia in schizophrenia is thought to lead to alterations in D1 receptor function, which is critical to important cognitive functions such as working memory. Cortical gamma oscillatory disturbances have also been consistently reported in schizophrenia and are thought to underlie perceptual and cognitive impairments in the disorder. Interestingly, D1 receptor agonism modulates NMDA receptor and fast-spiking interneuron activity, both of which are important to mechanisms of gamma oscillations and disturbed in schizophrenia. Thus, the administration of D1 agonists may improve gamma oscillatory activity in schizophrenia through a number of mechanisms. To test this putative relationship, we conducted a pilot study of the effects of the administration of DAR-0100A, a full and selective D1 agonist, on cortical gamma activity in schizophrenia subjects as elicited by an auditory click-train paradigm.

Methods: 11 schizophrenia subjects participated in a double-blind study of DAR-0100A effects on cortical gamma oscillations. Subjects were randomized to placebo (n=5), low-dose (0.5 mg; n=2) and high-dose (15 mg; n=4) groups. Four total doses of the study drug were administered over four consecutive days. Gamma (40 Hz) oscillations were assessed using the auditory steady-state response (ASSR) paradigm, first at baseline prior to medication administration, and then again post-administration of the final dose. The spectral power of the ASSR was determined with wavelet analyses. Independent component analysis (ICA) was conducted to extract components that exhibited ASSR activity.

Results: Two ICA components showed entrainment activity, accounting for 26% and 13% of the variance respectively. These components both showed the high-dose group exhibiting the greatest ASSR gamma percentage increases with drug administration in comparison with the placebo and low-dose groups.

Conclusions: Our findings from this pilot study provide suggestive evidence that increasing cortical D1 receptor activity in schizophrenia subjects can ameliorate cortical gamma oscillatory disturbances in the illness. There are multiple mechanisms by which these effects may be mediated: D1 receptor agonism could directly address D1 receptor hypofunction, or positively modulate NMDA receptor function or fast-spiking GABA interneuron excitability, all of which may positively impact cortical gamma oscillations. Thus D1 agonists offer a possible therapeutic mechanism for remediating multiple pathophysiologic mechanisms that underlie disturbed cortical gamma oscillations in schizophrenia and other neuropsychiatric disorders.
Keywords: schizophrenia, dopamine, gamma oscillation, D1 agonist.
Disclosure: Allon, Biomarin, Eli Lilly, F. Hoffman-La Roche, Forest, Forum, Genentech, GlaxoSmithKline, Merck, Novartis, Otsuka, Pfizer, Psychogenics, Sepracor, Takeda and Targacept.

sec.title: T235. Comparative Behavioral and Neural Effects of Tryptophan and Catecholamine Depletion in Remitted Depression
Gregor Hasler*, Philipp Homan, Alexander Neumeister, Allison Nugent, Dennis Charney, Wayne Drevets
University of Bern, Bern, Switzerland
sec.p: Background: Despite immense efforts into development of new antidepressant drugs, the increases of serotoninergic and catechominergic neurotransmission have remained the two major pharmacodynamic principles of current drug treatments for depression. Consequently, psychopathological or biological markers that predict response to drugs that selectively increase serotonin and/or catecholamine neurotransmission hold the potential to optimize the prescriber’s selection among currently available treatment options. The aim of this study was to elucidate the differential symptomatology and neurophysiology in response to reductions in serotonergic versus catecholaminergic neurotransmission in subjects at high risk of depression recurrence.

Methods: Using identical neuroimaging procedures with [18F] fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography after tryptophan depletion (TD) and catecholamine depletion (CD), subjects with remitted depression were compared to healthy controls in a double-blind, randomized, crossover design.

Results: While TD induced significantly more depressed mood, sadness and hopelessness than CD, CD induced more inactivity, concentration difficulties, lassitude and somatic anxiety than TD. CD specifically increased glucose metabolism in the bilateral ventral striatum and decreased glucose metabolism in the bilateral orbitofrontal cortex, whereas TD specifically increased metabolism in the right prefrontal cortex and the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC). While we found direct associations between changes in brain metabolism and induced depressive symptoms following CD, the relationship between neural activity and symptoms was less clear after TD.
Conclusions: In conclusion, this study showed that serotonin and catecholamines play common and differential roles in the pathophysiology of depression.
Keywords: dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin, depression.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T236. Influence of Oral Cannabidiol on the Subjective, Reinforcing and Cardiovascular Effects of Smoked Marijuana
Margaret Haney*
Columbia University, New York, New York
sec.p: Background: Cannabidiol (CBD), a cannabinoid constituent of marijuana, ranges naturally from 0 - 40% of the total cannabinoids in marijuana (Hardwick and King, 2008). Few psychoactive effects have been reported after CBD administration alone (e.g., Leweke et al., 2000, Fusar-Poli et al., 2009; but see de Souza Crippa, 2004). In some (e.g., Zuardi et al., 1982) but not all studies (Juckel et al., 2007; Roser et al., 2008), CBD administration appears to attenuate certain aspects of dronabinol (oral Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol; THC) intoxication in non-marijuana smokers. Yet many of the studies conducted have tested only one dose of CBD in combination with one dose of dronabinol, making it difficult to conclude the nature of this interaction. Further, there is no direct evidence that oral CBD alters the effects of THC by its most common route of administration: marijuana smoking. The objective of this ongoing multi-site, within-subject laboratory study is to assess the influence of CBD (0, 200, 400, 800 mg, p.o.) pretreatment on smoked marijuana’s (0.01, 5.30% THC) reinforcing, subjective, cognitive, and physiological effects; the order of CBD and marijuana dose combinations.

Methods: Non-treatment-seeking, otherwise healthy marijuana smokers (n=12/site) participate in 8 outpatient laboratory sessions conducted once weekly at Columbia University Medical Center (PI: M. Haney), Medical University of South Carolina (PI: R. Malcolm), and University of Kentucky (PI: S. Walsh). Participants are administered cannabidiol 90 minutes prior to smoking 50% of a marijuana cigarette. At select time points, participants complete mood scales and performance tasks, and their heart rate and blood pressure are measured. In order to assess CBD’s influence on marijuana reinforcement, participants have the opportunity to self-administer up to 3 additional puffs of marijuana later in the session. At the Columbia site, a subset (n=8) of participants will complete an additional session to measure plasma CBD levels following administration of the 800 mg dose. Data collection is ongoing.

Results: Preliminary data analyses (n=19) show that under placebo CBD conditions, active marijuana was (1) self-administered significantly more than placebo marijuana and (2) produced significant, time-dependent increases in ratings of “High,” and “Good Effect” as well as ratings of the marijuana cigarette (e.g., strength, liking, desire to take again) relative to inactive marijuana (p<0.05). CBD did not significantly alter any of these effects: Marijuana self-administration, subjective-effects and marijuana ratings did not significantly vary as a function of CBD dose relative to placebo capsules. CBD was well tolerated, producing no adverse effects or direct cardiovascular effects. Pharmacokinetic and cognitive data have not yet been analyzed. Data analyses for all participants and all measures will be complete by the annual meeting. Overall, these preliminary findings do not suggest that oral CBD reduces the reinforcing or positive subjective effects of smoked marijuana.

Conclusions: Overall, these preliminary findings do not suggest that oral CBD reduces the reinforcing or positive subjective effects of smoked marijuana. Although cannabidiol has been hypothesized to attenuate marijuana’s effects, this is the first study to directly assess the effects of a range of CBD doses in combination with smoked marijuana. Given the vast abuse of marijuana, and given the need for potential treatments for marijuana dependence, this study contributes important information as to the influence of CBD on a range of marijuana effects.
Keywords: cannabis, cannabinoid.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T237. Rapid Changes in Hippocampal Volume with Hydrocortisone Administration
E. Sherwood Brown*, Haekyung Jeon-Slaughter, Hanzhang Lu, Rhoda Jamadar, Sruthy Thomas, Mujeeb Shad, Daren Denniston, Carol Tamminga, Jinsoo Uh, Alyson Nakamura, Binu Thomas
University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, Texas
sec.p: Background: In animal models, stress and corticosteroid administration are associated with changes in hippocampal size and dendritic architecture. In humans, both Cushing’s syndrome and long-term prescription corticosteroid use are associated with atrophy of the hippocampus. In animal models, hippocampal changes with corticosteroids are blocked by phenytoin pretreatment, while in humans the acute effects of corticosteroids on memory can be prevented with phenytoin. The current study examines if changes in hippocampal volume are observed in controls briefly administered hydrocortisone and whether these volumetric changes can be blocked by phenytoin.

Methods: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, within-subject crossover study was conducted in 17 healthy adult volunteers (9 women, 8 men, mean age 26.7±9.7 years). Phenytoin (400 mg/d) or placebo was initiated one day prior to hydrocortisone administration (3.5 days total) while participants received hydrocortisone (160 mg/d) for 2.5 days. Participants received hydrocortisone+placebo, phenytoin+placebo, both medications together, or placebo+placebo, with 21-day washouts between conditions. Structural MRI scans and cortisol levels were obtained following each medication condition. Total brain volume and hippocampal volumes were manually traced using BRAINS2 software. Data were analyzed using crossover t-tests and Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

Results: Due to missing structural MRI data, 14 participants were included in the analysis. No significant difference in total brain volume was observed between the hydrocortisone (1319.76±161.12 mL3) and placebo (1323.24±159.78 mL3) conditions (treatment t=-0.43; p=0.678, sequence t=-1.50; p=0.161, mean difference of 0.26%). However, the hydrocortisone (6.99±0.51 mL3) condition was associated with a significant 1.69% smaller mean total hippocampal volume (left+right) than placebo (7.11±0.61 ml3) (treatment t=-2.42; p=0.032, sequence t=-1.25; p=0.233). Phenytoin+hydrocortisone was not associated with a significantly different hippocampal volume than placebo (treatment t=-1.72; p=0.113, sequence t=0.04; p=0.968, mean difference -0.69%). No change in mean total hippocampal volume was observed between the placebo and phenytoin only conditions (0.00%). Although the samples sizes were small, a gender difference was suggested by a significant 2.01% reduction in average total hippocampal volume with hydrocortisone, as compared to placebo, in women (n=9) (treatment t=-2.39; p=0.048, sequence: t=-1.41; p=0.200) and a non-significant -0.81% change in men (n=5). Change in plasma cortisol levels between the placebo and hydrocortisone conditions correlated negatively with change in hippocampal volume (r=-0.58, p=0.031), but the correlation between cortisol and total brain volume was not significant (r=0.15, p=0.617).

Conclusions: To our knowledge, this is the first report of structural brain changes with short-term exogenous corticosteroid exposure. The correlation between reductions in hippocampal volume with increase in plasma cortisol levels suggests that the changes are related to the cortisol increase. These findings suggest that reversible reduction in hippocampal volume may occur even during brief exposure to corticosteroids. As in animal models, pre-treatment with phenytoin attenuated the effects of hydrocortisone on the hippocampus suggesting that the volume changes may be mediated through glutamate-related excitotoxicity. The possible gender difference in response to hydrocortisone warrants further investigation and may represent gender specific normal and adaptive responses to stress. However, because women are more likely than men to develop stress-related disorders, such as depression, that are associated with cortisol elevations, and also more likely than men to receive prescription corticosteroids, research is needed to determine if these findings might suggest gender differences in hippocampal changes with multiple or longer exposures to corticosteroid excess.
Keywords: cortisol, hippocampus, stress, gender.
Disclosure: Research grant support from Sunovion, Forest and Alkermes.

sec.title: T238. Patients Receiving Long-term Lithium Therapy Have a Reduced Incidence of Seizure and Myocardial Infarction
Ronald Fieve*, James Prosser
Columbia University Medical Center, New York, New York
sec.p: Background: Lithium has been a standard treatment for Bipolar Disorder for more than 50 years. A variety of studies have examined the medical consequences of long-term Lithium treatment. There has been some reports providing in vitro evidence that Lithium is cytoprotective. Long-term Lithium treatment has been reported to prevent the occurrence of Alzheimer’s Disease, and some other neurological disorders as well. This study compares the incidence of cardiovascular and neurologic disease in psychiatric outpatients receiving and not receiving Lithium.

Methods: This study consists of a retrospective chart review of adult psychiatric outpatients treated at the New York State Psychiatric Institute Lithium Clinic and two affiliate lithium clinics of Columbia University Medical Center and the Foundation for Mood Disorders. These clinics specialize in the treatment of mood disorders and the majority of patients were diagnosed with either Major Depression or Bipolar Disorders. All patient diagnoses were made by a board-certified psychiatrist, and patients were assigned to Lithium treatment as appropriate for their individual diagnoses. All patients in the practice underwent yearly physical exams and blood chemistries performed by a separate medical practice. The chart review included patient demographic information, diagnosis, treatment information, and any reported medical complications. Odds ratios were calculated to assess the risk of having a disorder for patients receiving Lithium compared to patients not receiving Lithium.

Results: To date, 984 patients have been entered in the database (54.5% female, 45.3% male), ranging in age from 13 to 88 years old (mean=42.24; sd=14.9). Of these, 548 patients (55.7%) received Lithium treatment, with the duration of Lithium treatment ranging from 0.1 – 30.0 years (mean 2.75 yrs; SD 4.83 yrs.). The frequency of any neurological disease in this group was low: there were 183 unique disorders occurring in 104 patients (10.4% of all patients). The frequency of specific conditions ranged from 37 patients with a history of Migraine Headache, to zero patients with Huntington’s Chorea, Down’s Syndrome, Lewy Body Disease, and Multi-Infarct Dementia. For Seizures, the OR was 0.098 (95% CI: 0.022 – 0.429). For Myocardial Infarction, the OR was 0.294 (95% CI: 0.114 – 0.758). Odds ratios for other disorders (Huntington’s Chorea, Down’s Syndrome, Dementia, Multi-infarct Dementia, CNS Neoplasms, Stroke, Migraine Headache, Fainting, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Optic Atrophy/Neuritis, Lewy Body Disease, Alzheimer’s Disease, and Parkinson’s Disease) were all found to be equivalent to unity.

Conclusions: Patients receiving long-term Lithium treatment for psychiatric illness have a significantly lower likelihood of seizure and myocardial infarction. These results suggest that long-term Lithium treatment may protect against myocardial infarction and some neurological disorders.
Keywords: Lithium, Mood disorders, Neurological disorders, Cardiovascular disorders.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T239. Changes in Domains in a Double-blind Placebo Controlled Study of Quetiapine XR in Borderline Personality Disorder
Charles Schulz*, Susanne Lee, Donald Black, Mary Zanarini, Ann Romine, Martha Shaw, Jeff Allen, Alaa Houri
University of Minnesota Medical School, Minneapolis, Minnesota
sec.p: Background: The NIMH RDoC initiative is leading to assessment of domains in research, not just changes in DSM assessments. This can be of interest in studies of borderline personality disorder (BPD) because of its heterogeneity and because of the recent debates about BPD leading up to the publication of DSM-5. The purpose of the study is to examine the impact of the study medication, quetiapine, on the subscales of the SCL-90R to explore the areas of possible therapeutic impact.

Methods: The study was designed as a double-blind and placebo controlled trial of two doses of quetiapine XR (150 mg and 300 mg) versus placebo over 8 weeks. Titration occurred in the first 4 weeks to provide tolerability. Subjects were assessed by the SCID interview and by the Zanarini rating scale for BPD (ZAN-BPD) as the primary measure. To approach domains of BPD the SCL-90R was one of the scales.

Results: 95 subjects were enrolled at 3 academic sites. Using the ZAN-BPD, there was a statistically significant difference between the low-dose of quetiapine (150mg/day) versus placebo, but not a significant difference in the 300 mg/day group. In an examination of the SCL-90-R for the quetiapine 300 mg/day group, there was a statistically significant difference for Interpersonal Sensitivity (p=0.005), depression (p=0.004), hostility (p=0.023), and Phobic Anxiety (p=0.023.).

Conclusions: In assessing treatments of psychiatric illness, the use of domains can be very useful in selecting a pharmacological or psychosocial treatment. In this study, changes in domains of Hostility and Interpersonal Sensitivity are consistent with the meta-analysis of the symptom changes in BPD by Ingenhoven et al (2010) who demonstrated changes in anger and psychosis. These findings have the potential to provide specificity of the selection of medication when judgment indicates medication treatment.
Keywords: Borderline Personality, SCL-90R, Quetiapine, Treatment Domains.
Disclosure: Investigator initiated study sponsored by AstraZeneca.

sec.title: T240. Riluzole Likely Lacks Antidepressant Efficacy in Ketamine Non-responders
Mark Niciu*, David Luckenbaugh, Dawn Ionescu, Erica Richards, Jennifer Vande Voort, Elizabeth Ballard, Nancy Brutsche, Maura Furey, Carlos Zarate
National Institute of Mental Health, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland
sec.p: Background: In our primary analysis of a four-week riluzole extension trial after open-label ketamine in treatment-resistant major depressive disorder (TRD), there was no significant difference in depression scores between riluzole and placebo extension (Ibrahim et al., 2012). Riluzole also did not delay relapse in ketamine responders, which is consistent with a prior report of lack of efficacy in 14 ketamine responders (Mathew et al., 2010). However, as riluzole has been proposed to have adjunctive antidepressant effects in TRD, and, although glutamatergic, its mechanism of action is distinct from ketamine's, we hypothesized that riluzole has antidepressant effects in ketamine non-responders.

Methods: 52 TRD inpatients in a current major depressive episode of at least moderate depression severity [Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) score ≥22 at screening and the day of infusion) received a single open-label subanesthetic dose (0.5mg/kg) ketamine infusion over 40 minutes. 4-6 hours post-infusion, subjects were randomized double-blind to either flexible-dose (100-200mg/day) riluzole or placebo twice daily for four weeks. Dose escalations were allowed on a weekly basis, and dose reductions were permitted by one capsule (50mg/week to a minimum of 100mg/day) for intolerable side effects. The MADRS is reported here as change in total score was the primary outcome measure. Responders and non-responders were defined as ≥50% and<50% improvement, respectively, from baseline MADRS at 230 minutes (last pre-randomization time point). Factorial linear mixed models with restricted maximum likelihood estimation and an autoregressive moving average covariance structure were used to examine change in MADRS with time as a within-subjects factor and drug as a between-subjects factor. MADRS score at 230 minutes was included as a covariate. All potential interactions between time and drug were included in the model.

Results: At 230 minutes post-infusion, 32 patients were non-responders, and 16 non-responders were randomized to each arm. There were no significant differences in demographic or neuropsychiatric characteristics (including length of illness, length of current episode and number of failed antidepressant trials) between groups. The linear mixed model showed no main effect of drug [F(1,29)=0.62, p=.44] or time [F(27,231)=1.50, p=.058]. There was also no interaction between drug and time [F(27,231)=1.15, p=.29]. This small sample size, however, may leave the study underpowered to detect a small-to-medium effect. In non-responders, riluzole’s maximum effect was observed at day one (d=.39) but was lost by day six. Yet, at the end of protocol, sample sizes were even smaller due to attrition – placebo: 8/16 (50%) drop-outs; riluzole: 6/16 (38%) drop-outs. There was no statistically significant difference in drop-outs between groups (p=.72), and, with the exception of one patient randomized to riluzole who discontinued due to severe nausea, the remaining drop-outs were attributed to psychiatric indications, i.e. continued poor and/or worsening mood, anxiety or suicidal ideation. At day 28, there was only one antidepressant responder randomized to placebo (6%) and no responders randomized to riluzole (drop-outs were counted as non-responders).

Conclusions: Although potentially underpowered to detect a small-to-moderate-sized effect, riluzole is unlikely to be an effective antidepressant medication for ketamine non-responders. There are several potential limitations, however, that may preclude broader generalization to other populations: our highly-refractory cohort and insufficient trial duration.
Keywords: major depressive disorder, treatment-resistant depression, ketamine, riluzole.

Disclosure: Drs. Furey and Zarate are listed as co-inventors on a patent application for the use of scopolamine and ketamine, respectively, in major depression. They have assigned rights to the U.S. Government.

sec.title: T241. Cue-induced Reactivity Among Heroin Users Following Repeated Heroin and Placebo Administration
Jermaine Jones*, Sandra Comer
Columbia University, New York, New York
sec.p: Background: Stimuli associated with drug taking have been known to elicit craving and physiologic arousal, and may be an important trigger leading to drug use. However, it remains to be investigated if these cues, and the responses they produce, are more salient following periods of abstinence, or are sensitized or attenuated by recent drug use. In the present study we investigated physiological reactivity evoked during drug and neutral cue presentation following 4 days of heroin and 4 days of placebo availability.

Methods: Intravenous (IV; n=9) and intranasal (IN; n=7) heroin-dependent participants (n=16 total), who were not seeking treatment, were recruited for the study. After 5-7 days of stabilization on sublingual (SL) buprenorphine (8 mg, BID), participants began lab sessions during which doses of heroin (10 mg IV or 40 mg IN) or matching placebo were administered. Using a within-subjects design, all participants completed both heroin and placebo phases of testing, in random order. Participants completed 4 successive days of drug administration sessions (heroin or placebo) prior to a cue exposure session. During the cue exposure session, participants were presented with a neutral cue (opening and tasting a small bottle of water) followed by a drug cue (preparing a bag of power for injection or insufflation). During this task, galvanic skin response (GSR), skin temperature (ST), and heart rate (HR) were measured. Self-reported measurements of drug craving were also assessed using a Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The route of drug administration and nature of the drug cues presented matched the participants’ primary method of use.

Results: After 4 days of placebo drug availability, GSR significantly increased following drug cues when compared to neutral cues (p<0.05). Skin temperature significantly decreased following drug cues (p<0.05), while no significant difference in HR was observed. Following 4 days of heroin availability, only significantly lower ST during drug cue exposure was observed (p<0.05), though the increase in GSR approached significance. Self-reports of “I want heroin” were also significantly increased following drug cue presentation under both conditions (p’s<.05). The magnitude of each of these responses did not significantly differ following heroin and placebo weeks. Physiological responses were also not significantly different between IV and IN cue conditions.

Conclusions: These results support the idea that drug cues illicit a measurable and reliable physiological response, regardless of the nature of the drug paraphernalia (i.e., injection or insufflation equipment). These data also suggest that recent drug use may attenuate the sympathetic system response to these drug cues.
Keywords: Heroin, craving, Cue-Exposure, Drug Abuse.

Disclosure: This research was supported by NIDA grant R01DA031022 to Sandra Comer and K01DA030446 to Jermaine Jones. Over the past three years Dr. Comer has received compensation (in the form of partial salary support) from investigator-initiated studies supported by Reckitt-Benckiser Pharmaceuticals, Schering-Plough Corporation, Johnson & Johnson Pharmaceutical Research & Development, Endo Pharmaceuticals, and MediciNova. SDC has also served as a consultant to the following companies: AstraZeneca, Grunenthal USA, Guidepoint Global, Mallinckrodt, Neuromed, Orexo, Pfizer, and Salix.

sec.title: T242. The Pharmacokinetics (PK), Pharmacodynamics (PD), Safety, and Tolerability of JNJ-42165279, a Potent and Selective Inhibitor of Fatty Acid Amide Hydrolase (FAAH) in Healthy Subjects
Peter Zannikos, Michelle Wennerholm, Peter Van Der Ark, Nicole Vaccaro, Mark Schmidt, Stefanie Rassnick, Darrel Pemberton, James Palmer, David Bredt*
Johnson & Johnson Pharmaceutical, San Diego, California
sec.p: Background: FAAH catalyzes the degradation of fatty acid amides (FAA), including endocannabinoids which are endogenous agonists of cannabinoid receptors. Modulation of FAAH may play an important role in the treatment of pain, anxiety/depression, and metabolic disorders. in vitro studies demonstrated that JNJ-42165279 is a substrate for FAAH and is a slowly reversible covalent inhibitor of this enzyme. The pharmacology and tolerability JNJ-42165279 was assessed in healthy subjects.

Methods: A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, single and multiple oral dose rising Phase 1 study was conducted. Healthy males received 25 mg (Cohort A) or 75 mg (Cohort B) of JNJ-42165279 or placebo daily for 10 days. Healthy females (Cohort C) and subjects 65 to 85 years of age (Cohort D) received 100 mg of JNJ-42165279 or placebo for 10 days. Each cohort received JNJ-42165279 (n=6) or placebo (n=2) as an oral suspension formulation. The following were measured: concentrations of JNJ-42165279 in plasma, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), FAAH activity in leucocytes (WBCs), and anandamide (AEA), N-oleoylethanolamide (OEA), N-palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in plasma, and AEA, OEA, and arachidonic acid (AA) in CSF. Tolerability, including effects on cognition and subjective ratings, were assessed.

Results: PK: JNJ-42165279 was rapidly absorbed (median tmax, 1 to 3 h). Concentrations in plasma increased in a dose-dependent manner. Exposure on Day 10 was 1.2- to 2.4-times higher relative to Day 1. Mean terminal half-life values in plasma were approximately 12 hours. JNJ-42165279 concentrations in CSF from male subjects were measurable at 2 to 4 h after the dose on Day 7 following daily administration of 25 mg (mean, 8.95 ng/mL) or 75 mg (mean, 31.8 ng/mL). Less than 0.2% of the dose was excreted as unchanged in urine. FAAH Activity in WBCs: Across 25- to 100-mg JNJ-42165279 dose range, FAAH activity remaining in WBCs attained a mean nadir of 7.85% to 10.4% (relative to predose values) after a single dose and a mean nadir of 0.58% to 10.5% after once-daily dosing for 10 days. At 96 h after the last dose, mean FAAH activity remaining ranged from 28.3% to 58.2% of predose values. FAA in Plasma: Single doses of JNJ-42165279 in the range of 25 to 100 mg produced mean peak concentrations of AEA in plasma that were 5.5- to 10-times higher than mean predose values, whereas mean peak OEA and PEA concentrations 4.3- to 5.6-times higher. Similar changes in mean FAA concentrations were observed after daily administration of 25 to 100 mg for 10 days. Mean plasma AEA, OEA, and PEA concentrations were 1.3- to 3.1-times higher than mean predose values at 96 h after the last JNJ-42165279 dose. FAA in CSF: Daily administration of JNJ-42165279 for 7 days increased mean AEA and OEA concentrations in CSF by approximately 41-times and 5.8-times (25 mg dose), respectively, and 77-times and 7.4-times (75 mg dose), respectively, relative to predose. The concentrations of AA in CSF were unchanged. Tolerability: Few side effects were reported, all mild in intensity. The only clinical abnormalities were one three subjects taking 75 mg and two subjects taking 100 mg having slight transient increases in liver transaminases. No treatment effects were observed on the Bond and Lader Visual Analogue Scales. Subjects receiving 100 mg reported slight similarity to sedatives and dissimilarity to stimulants on the Addiction Research Center Inventory; no groups reported similarity to cannabinoids.

Conclusions: The results of this study demonstrate that JNJ-42165279 is orally available inhibitor of FAAH activity. JNJ-42165279 concentrations achieved in plasma after single doses of 25 to 100 mg were dose-dependent. The activity of FAAH in leucocytes was substantially inhibited even at the lowest dose of 25 mg. The effects were maintained after daily administration for 10 days. The inhibition of FAAH resulted in pronounced accumulation of FAA in plasma and CSF. Notably, the PD profiles revealed a more prolonged effect on FAAH inhibition in WBCs and plasma FAA elevation than expected from the half-life in plasma (approximately 12 h). These data support the continued evaluation of JNJ-42165279 to investigate if clinical benefit is derived from inhibition of FAAH and elevation of FAA.
Keywords: Pharmacokinetics, Pharmacodynamics, FAAH.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T243. Laboratory Model of Contingency Management and Transdermal Nicotine for Youth Smoking
Rajkumar Sevak*, Carmen Freire-Cobo, Edythe London
East Tennessee State University College of Pharmacy, Johnson City, Tennessee
sec.p: Background: Cigarette smoking usually begins during adolescence. Although many young smokers aim to quit, few can do so successfully without assistance. In adult smokers, combinations of behavioral (e.g., contingency management [CM]) and pharmacological (nicotine replacement therapy [NRT]) treatments have proven superior to either treatment alone. However, use of such combinations for young smokers have received little attention. Progress in this regard has been limited by the length, expense, and labor-intensive nature of clinical trials. While randomized, controlled, double-blind trials are the gold standard of clinical research, they might be reserved for the most promising treatment combinations after obtaining at least some data on safety and initial efficacy in the human laboratory. Such laboratory studies could be conducted in a more rapid, cost-effective and efficient manner than clinical trials. We conducted a “proof-of-concept” laboratory study in young smokers to assess combined effects of NRT and CM. We hypothesized that CM will enhance the effects of NRT on youth smoking.

Methods: The study was randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, between-groups and 12-days long. The laboratory sessions were scheduled on days 1, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12, each lasting 30 min. In each session, breath carbon monoxide (CO) was measured, and participants completed questionnaires on cigarette craving and withdrawal. On day 1, participants were randomly assigned to either NRT+CM or NRT+Non-contingent control [NC] group. They also received seven Nicoderm CQ® (14 mg) patches to wear for the next 7 days, one patch daily. During days 8 to 12, participants wore one patch daily and the combined effect of NRT with CM or NC was evaluated. During these days, participants had opportunities to receive payments based on their breath CO levels, in accordance with their group assignment. Participants assigned to the NRT+NC group received payments as follows: $4, $6, $8, $10 and $12 for days 8 to 12, respectively; and $10 bonus on day 12. Participants in the NRT+NC group received payments independent of their breath CO levels. The schedule of payment to participants in the NRT+CM group was as follows: during days 8 to 12, the first time a participant had a CO level consistent with abstinence (i.e.,<6 ppm), he/she received $4. With each subsequent consecutive CO sample that indicated abstinence, the amount was increased by $2. In addition, for every third consecutive CO that indicated abstinence, the participant earned a $10 bonus. Thus, if a participant’s first CO was<6 ppm, he/she earned $4; similarly, if his/her second, third, fourth and fifth breath CO level was<6 ppm, he/she respectively earned $6, $18 ($8+$10 bonus), $10 and $12. If during days 8 to 12, CO was ≥ 6 ppm, payment was withheld and the payment for the next CO<6 ppm was reset to the initial $4 level. This reset contingency was designed to discourage resumption of smoking once abstinence was achieved.

Results: Four youth smokers have completed the experiment so far in the following groups: NRT+CM (n=3) and NRT+NC (n=1). During the first week of NRT, number of cigarettes smoked per day progressively decreased in both groups similarly (52.4% and 46.2% reductions on day 7 from day 1 in NRT+CM and NRT+NC groups, respectively). On day 8, one of the three participants in the NRT+CM group smoked a cigarette, whereas other two participants did not smoke a cigarette. During days 9 to 12, no participant in the NRT+CM group smoked a cigarette (and had CO<6 ppm). In the NRT+NC group, number of cigarettes smoked per day decreased over days 8 to 12; however, the breath CO level never reached the abstinence mark (CO<6 ppm). To date, no serious adverse events have occurred.

Conclusions: The results indicate that the participants in the NRT+CM group remained abstinent longer than the participant in the NRT+NC group. These preliminary data support the hypothesis in that CM enhanced the effects of NRT on cigarette smoking in young smokers. Positive findings from the completed study may provide an efficient and economical laboratory model that can be used to expedite screening and optimization of combination therapies. The laboratory model can be used further to evaluate combined effects of other pharmacological (e.g., varenicline, nicotine spray) and other CM (e.g., fixed-rate reinforcement) approaches for reducing youth smoking behavior.
Keywords: smoking, contingency management, nicotine, human laboratory.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T244. Medication Prescription Practices for the Treatment of First Episode Schizophrenia-Spectrum Disorders: Data from the National Raise-ETP Study
Delbert Robinson*, Nina Schooler, Majnu John, Christoph Correll, Patricia Marcy, Jean Addington, Mary Brunette, Sue Estroff, Kim Mueser, David Penn, James Robinson, Robert Rosenheck, John Kane
Horstra North Shore-LIJ School of Medicine, Glen Oaks, New York
sec.p: Background: Research supports different medication treatment approaches for first episode and multi-episode schizophrenia. How much community clinicians adjust their treatment regimens for first episode patients is unknown. The ETP study, a nationwide comparative effectiveness trial that is part of the NIMH RAISE initiative, provided the basis for the first national report of U.S. community mental health center medication treatments for the crucial early phase of schizophrenia.

Methods: RAISE-ETP was conducted at 34 community care clinics in 21 states. Inclusion criteria were: age 15 to 40 years; diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, schizoaffective disorder, psychosis NOS or brief psychotic disorder; beginning first treatment for psychosis (defined as having taken antipsychotic medications cumulatively for 6 months or less) and ability to participate in research assessments in English. Exclusion criteria were: had clearly experienced more than one discrete psychotic episode; diagnosis of bipolar disorder, psychotic depression, substance-induced psychotic disorder or current psychotic disorder due to a general medical condition; presence of current neurological disorders that would affect diagnosis or prognosis; clinically significant head trauma or other serious medical conditions that would significantly impair assessment, functioning or treatment We present data on psychotropic medications being prescribed (even if not actually taken) to subjects at study entry and before any influence on treatment by study guidelines or procedures. Statistical analyses: Prescribing patterns were characterized using standard descriptive methods. We adopted a Bayesian perspective for the analyses of correlates of prescription patterns. A weakly informative prior distribution was constructed by scaling all non-binary variables to have mean 0 and standard deviation 0.5, and then placing an independent distribution from the Student t prior family (specifically, a Cauchy distribution centered at zero and 2.5 scale) on the coefficients. Multivariate analyses employed Bayesian model averaging (BMA). The bic.glm function from R package BMA was primarily used for these analyses.

Results: The sample included 404 subjects. Approximately half met DSM-IV criteria for schizophrenia. Mean cumulative lifetime antipsychotic treatment was only 46.7 (95% CI: 42.2, 51.2) days. We found 159 subjects (39.4% of the sample) who might benefit from changes in their psychotropic prescriptions. Of these 159 subjects, 8.8% were prescribed recommended antipsychotics at higher than recommended doses, 32.1% were prescribed olanzapine (often at high doses), 23.3% more than one antipsychotic, 36.5% an antipsychotic but also an antidepressant without a clear indication, 10.1% psychotropic medications without an antipsychotic and 1.2% stimulants. Multivariate analyses found evidence for sex, age and insurance status effects on prescription. Subjects with private insurance were less likely to be prescribed more than one antipsychotic than either subjects with public (selected %=52.9%) or no insurance (selected %=51.9%). First generation antipsychotic prescription was more common among the uninsured versus those with private (selected %=96.2%) or public insurance (selected %=56.4%). Younger subjects (selected %=66.4%) were more likely to receive risperidone and women received lower risperidone doses than men (selected %=52.2%). Antidepressant prescription was more likely among women (selected %=83.5%) and those with depression or anxiety symptoms (selected %=87.1%).

Conclusions: Our data suggest that primary immediate targets for improving first-episode community treatment are discouraging use of two or more antipsychotics and the prescription of, and high dose of, olanzapine. Besides prescriber educational efforts, changes in reimbursement models or care delivery may need to be considered to facilitate evidence-based treatment during the early phase of schizophrenia. Subjects with private insurance had strikingly lower rates of prescription of two or more antipsychotics than patients with public or no insurance. A large number of our subjects received antidepressants without clear indications for their use. Training to improve clinicians’ ability to diagnose schizophrenia-spectrum disorders as distinct from mood or anxiety disorders in women maybe warranted given our finding that women were more likely to be prescribed antidepressants independent of symptom indications.
Keywords: schizophrenia, antipsychotic, first episode.

Disclosure: Dr. Robinson- Part 1: has been a consultant to Asubio and Shire; Part 2: none; Part 3: none; Part 4: grant support from Bristol Meyers Squibb, Otsuka, NIH and CMS. Dr. Schooler- Part 1: Advisory boards and consultation: Eli Lilly, Janssen Psychiatry, Amgen, Shire, Graham Boechk Foundation, Lundbeck International Neuroscience Foundations, Genentech/Roche, EnVivo (Forum), Sunovion; Part 2: none, Part 3: none; Part 4: grant support from Otsuka, Neurocrine, Genentech, NIMH and CMS. Dr. Correll- Part 1: has been a consultant and/or advisor to or has received honoraria from: Actelion, Alexza; American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMS), Cephalon, Eli Lilly, Genentech, Gerson Lehrman Group, IntraCellular Therapies, Lundbeck, Medavante, Medscape, Merck, Janssen/J&J, Otsuka, Pfizer, ProPhase, Roche, Sunovion, Takeda, Teva and Vanda. Part 2: BMS, Janssen/J&J, Lundbeck, Otsuka, Pfizer, ProPhase; Part 3: BMS, Lundbeck, Otsuka, Pfizer, ProPhase; Part 4: has received grants from BMS, Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, Janssen/J&J, NIMH, National Alliance for Research in Schizophrenia and Depression and Otsuka. Ms. Marcy- Part 1: none; Part 2: Pfizer; Part 3: none; Part 4; grant support from Otsuka, NIMH and CMS. Dr. Addington- Part 1: has served as a consultant to Roche, Part 2; none, Part 3: none; Part 4: grant support from NIMH, University of Calgary Mental Health Research Fund and Mathison Center Pilot Funding. Dr. Rosenheck- Part 1: none, Part 2: none, Part 3: none; Part 4: grant support from NIMH. Dr. Kane-Part 1: has been a consultant for Amgen, Alkermes, Bristol-Meyers Squibb, Eli Lilly, EnVivo Pharmaceuticals (Forum), Forest, Genentech, H. Lundbeck. Intracellular Therapeutics, Janssen Pharmaceutica, Johnson and Johnson, Merck, Novartis, Otsuka, Pierre Fabre, Proteus, Reviva, Roche and Sunovion. Dr. Kane has been on the Speaker’s Bureau for Bristol-Meyers Squibb, Eli Lilly, Genentech, Janssen and Otsuka. He is a Shareholder in MedAvante, Inc. Part 2: Otsuka, Roche, Genentech; Part 3: Ostuka; Part 4: grant support from NIMH, CMS and Otsuka.

sec.title: T245. Buprenorphine Dampens Responses to Psychosocial Stress in Healthy Adults
Anya Bershad*, Jerome Jaffe, Harriet de Wit
University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois
sec.p: Background: The opioid system is strongly implicated in the regulation of responses to social stress. In laboratory animals, deactivation of the μ-opioid system is associated with social rejection, and activation of the system, via opioid analgesics is associated with reduced responses to isolation distress. Despite evidence suggesting a role for the opioid system in mediating responses to psychosocial stress in animal models, the effects of opioids on responses to stress have not been determined in humans. Here we examined the effects of buprenorphine, a μ-opioid partial agonist used to treat opioid dependence and pain, on subjective and physiological responses to a stressful public speaking task in healthy adults. We hypothesized that buprenorphine would reduce subjective and physiological stress responses.

Methods: Healthy adult volunteers (N=48) were randomly assigned to receive placebo, 0.2mg sublingual buprenorphine, or 0.4mg sublingual buprenorphine. They attended two sessions, during which they performed either a stressful speaking task or a non-stressful control task. Throughout the sessions, the participants reported subjective drug effects and mood, subjective task appraisal, and provided measures of salivary cortisol, heart rate, and blood pressure at regular intervals.

Results: As expected, the stress task effectively increased heart rate, blood pressure, salivary cortisol, and subjective ratings of anxiety and negative mood in the placebo group. The higher dose, but not the lower dose, increased ratings of “feel high”. In line with our hypothesis, both doses of buprenorphine significantly dampened salivary cortisol responses to stress. While the drug did not affect subjective measures of anxiety, it dose-dependently reduced how threatening participants found the tasks and increased performance satisfaction.

Conclusions: These results suggest that enhanced μ-opioid signaling dampens responses to social stress in humans, as it does in laboratory animals. Furthermore, the stress-dampening effects occur at low doses. This stress-dampening effect may contribute to the efficacy of buprenorphine during the treatment of opioid abuse and to our understanding of the mechanism underlying stress-induced relapse among opioid-dependent individuals.
Keywords: opioid, social stress, buprenorphine.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T246. Latency of Acoustic Startle in Schizophrenia: Effects of Antipsychotic Medications
Erica Duncan*, Wendy Hasenkamp, Robin Gross, Bruce Cuthbert, Amanda Green, Lisette Swails, Barbara Lewison, William Boshoven, Megan Keyes
Emory University/Atlanta VA, Decatur, Georgia
sec.p: Background: The acoustic startle reflex and its modulations have been extensively studied in schizophrenia (SCZ) and in animal models of psychiatric disease. Startle paradigms allow for the measurement of startle latency, the time required for the startle reflex to occur after the presentation of the startling stimulus. The startle reflex is mediated by a three-synapse subcortical neural circuit and is pre-attentive; hence latency of startle provides an index of neural processing speed. Longer (i.e. slower) latency has been found in SCZ compared to healthy controls (CON). A number of significant findings regarding latency have recently emerged. The measure is highly (up to 90%) heritable. Slower latency is associated with single nucleotide polymorphisms in genes that are relevant to SCZ. Slower latency predicted which subjects at high risk for SCZ actually converted to psychosis during two-year follow up. In the design of future studies, antipsychotic medication status is an important factor to consider, particularly in light of a body of literature indicating some normalization of prepulse inhibition of startle (PPI) with the second generation antipsychotics (SGA’s). Therefore we examined the effects of medication status on startle latency and PPI in SCZ subjects compared to CON subjects.
