Methods: 199 SCZ and 154 CON subjects were tested with an acoustic startle session designed to evaluate baseline startle magnitude, PPI, and latency. The eyeblink component of the startle reflex was measured via electromyography of the right orbicularis oculi muscle. The paradigm, of standard design, consisted of pulse-alone trials to evaluate baseline startle, and prepulse+pulse trials with interstimulus intervals of 30, 60 or 120 milliseconds (ms) between the prepulse and pulse stimuli. 145 SCZ subjects were on a SGA, 40 were on a first generation antipsychotic (FGA), and 14 were not treated with an antipsychotic (NOMED) at time of testing. Mixed model analyses of variance were used to compare outcome variables in subject groups, with age, race, sex, smoking status, and baseline startle magnitude as covariates.

Results: Startle latency was longer (i.e. slower) in the SCZ subjects analyzed as a single group than CON: the overall model for Diagnosis was not significant but post hoc tests indicated that latency in the 60ms trials was slower in SCZ than CON (p=0.04). Next latency was compared between the SCZ subjects in the three medication groups. The overall model was not significant for Group, but post hoc tests indicated that latency for the 60ms trials was slower in the NOMED than the SGA group (p=0.01). Finally, CON subjects were added to this model, comparing them to the three SCZ medication groups. Again the overall model did not reach significance, but post hocs indicated that for the 60ms trials NOMED subjects had slower latency than CONs (p=0.007) and were also slower than the SGA group (p=0.006). Latency in the CONs did not differ from the SGA nor the FGA subjects. Latency facilitation, the shortening of latency in prepulse+pulse trials compared to pulse alone trials, was seen in all groups. PPI did not differ between SCZ and CON subjects when the SCZ subjects were analyzed as a single group. PPI in the three SCZ medication groups was significant for the Med Group x Trial Type interaction in the overall model (F(4,242)=3.66, p=0.007) and post hocs indicated that PPI in the 30ms trials was lower in the NOMED group than in the SGA (p=0.005) and the FGA group (p=0.006). Also, PPI in the 120ms trials was lower in the NOMED than the SGA group (p=0.04). An ANCOVA on PPI including all four subject groups was not significant for Group in the overall model. However, in post hocs inhibition in the 30ms prepulse trials was lower for the NOMED SCZ subjects than the CON (p=0.03), the SGA group (p=0.009), and the FGA group (p=0.01).

Conclusions: Prior findings of prolonged startle latency in SCZ were confirmed in this large dataset. Contrary to our prior work in a smaller dataset, we now report slower latency in unmedicated SCZ subjects compared to those on SGAs. When CONs were added to the analysis, slower latency was seen in unmedicated SCZ subjects compared to CONs and to those on SGAs. Thus latency can be at least partly normalized by SGAs. Medication status is therefore a relevant factor in studies of startle latency. However, the latency differences with medication did not obscure the overall prolongation of latency seen in SCZ compared to CON. Conversely, a normalization of PPI by SGAs and FGAs emerged in this dataset, yet medication status obscured any difference in PPI between SCZ and CON subjects when the SCZ subjects were analyzed as a single group. A primary hypothesis underlying this work is that slowing of startle latency is a reflection of a generalized slowing of neural processing speed. The measure is highly heritable, and there is evidence of genetic factors. However, latency is partially normalized by medication. Hence this measure has both trait and state components.
Keywords: acoustic startle, latency, schizophrenia, antipsychotic.
Disclosure: E. Duncan has current research support from Posit Science Corporation.

sec.title: T247. Effects of Carvedilol in Recently Abstinent, Cocaine Dependent Patients: A Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo-controlled, Pilot Study
Alison Oliveto*, Janette McGaugh, Jeff Thostenson, J. Benjamin Guise, Thomas R. Kosten, Michael J. Mancino
University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, Little Rock, Arkansas
sec.p: Background: Cocaine (COC) dependence continues to be a major public health problem and is associated with cardiovascular consequences, including hypertension. Yet despite decades of research, no FDA-approved pharmacotherapy exists for this disorder. Evidence suggests that while dopamine (DA) plays a large role in the etiology of cocaine addiction, noradrenergic (NE) activity appears to play a more prominent role than previously thought, particularly in the reinstatement of psychostimulant self-administration. Increased NE activity is associated with increased DA release and enhancement of COC effects whereas decreased NE activity is associated with blunted COC effects and alleviation of withdrawal. Thus, this pilot study examined the tolerability and initial efficacy of the alpha1- and beta-adrenergic antagonist carvedilol (CRV) among COC-dependent participants in a 12-wk, double blind, placebo (PLA) controlled, clinical trial.

Methods: COC dependent participants were admitted to research beds at a residential treatment facility for two weeks and randomized by sex, race and COC withdrawal severity, to be inducted on either extended-release CRV at 80 mg/day (N=15) or PLA (N=15) during weeks 1-2. Then subjects continued on the study medication while participating on an outpatient basis during weeks 3-12, attending thrice-weekly clinic visits and weekly, individual, manual-guided cognitive behavioral therapy. Several measures were obtained once or thrice weekly, including craving, urine toxicology screens for the presence of COC metabolite, adverse events and vital signs. Participants were then tapered off the study medication and referred to local treatment providers, if desired. This protocol was approved by the UAMS Institutional Review Board.

Results: Med groups generally did not differ on baseline characteristics or retention (p>0.05). During wks 1-2, med groups generally did not differ on COC craving or vital signs, although heart rate of CRV subjects was higher relative to PLA subjects (p<0.02). During weeks 3-12, the CRV group had lower systolic and diastolic blood pressure relative to the PLA group (p<0.04), although groups no longer differed on heart rate (p>0.1). COC craving and COC urine results did not differ across groups (p>0.05), although 18.2% and 8.3% of CRV and PLA participants, respectively, did not relapse during the outpatient portion of the study. Thirteen and 7 adverse events deemed at least possibly related to study medication occurred in the CRV and PLA groups, respectively, and were generally mild. Events reported in greater frequency by CRV than PLA participants were lightheadedness (2), dizziness (2), dry mouth (3), constipation (1), anxiety (1), lethargy (1), and falling down (1). Those reported in greater frequency by PLA than CRV participants were headache (3), cold hand with tingling fingertips (1), feeling high (1), and frequent urination (1).

Conclusions: These preliminary results suggest that CRV may not only be well tolerated, but also provide some protection against cocaine-associated hypertension. Although the sample size was too low to determine efficacy to prevent relapse, CRV may at the very least have utility as a harm reduction approach in this population.
Keywords: clinical trial, cocaine-related disorders, carvedilol, relapse prevention.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T248. Novel Glutamate Mechanisms and Therapeutic Approaches to Panic Disorder
Anantha Shekhar*, Philip Johnson, Andre Molosh, Stephanie Fitz, Luc ver Donck, Marc Cuesters, Justine Kent
Indiana University School of Medicine, Indianapolis, Indiana
sec.p: Background: Panic disorder is a severe anxiety syndrome associated with the development of avoidance behaviors that are hard to extinguish (phobias). A majority of these patients also demonstrate panic attacks following sodium lactate infusions. Using robust animal models, we determined specific genes changed in key brain sites and used the information asa guide for conducting preclinical and clinical treatment studies, demonstrating a targeted approach to developing treatments based on molecular discovery in preclinical systems.

Methods: 1. Preclinical studies - Utilizing our established preclinical model which demonstrates acute panic-like responses following lactate infusions, and develops conditioned fear responses that show delayed fear-extinction; we tested if the panic-prone animals a) demonstrate disrupted neural network properties in the amygdala; b) show specific glutamate-related gene changes in key brain areas implicated in panic and phobias such as the amygdala; and c) if novel compound JNJ-40411813/ADX71149, a positive allosteric modulator of the metabotropic glutamate receptor 2 (mGluR2), would demonstrate therapeutic efficacy in this model. 2. Clinical study – We analysed the outcome data from a subset of 5 patients who reported residual panic symptoms during a previously completed efficacy study of adjunctive JNJ-40411813 versus placebo in double-blind, doubly-randomized study in subjects with Major Depressive Disorder with anxious distress.

Results: 1. Preclinical studies - The panic prone rats compared to their inactive controls demonstrated normal acquisition of fear conditioning. However, during the extinction trials, the panic prone animals showed significant delay in extinction. Next, using whole-cell patch clamp recordings from pyramidal neurons in the basolateral region of amygdala, we demonstrated that the panic prone state induced a significant increase in excitability compared to control rats. Gene array results demonstrated unique gene expression changes in the amygdala of panic-prone rats that result in enhanced synaptic excitation, specifically a down regulation of the mRNA for mGluR2. Finally pretreatment of these animals with the mGluR2 positive allosteric modulator JNJ-40411813 dose-dependently blocked the lactate-induced panic-like responses and had significant efficacy in phobia amelioration. 2. Clinical study – All five subjects with baseline panic symptoms showed complete remission of panic symptoms after being treated with the JNJ compound.

Conclusions: These data suggest that unique gene and electrophysiological changes in the limbic circuits caused by reduced mGluR2 modulation and enhanced excitability appears to result in acute panic-like responses to lactate, as well as poor ability to extinguish conditioned fears, resulting in vulnerability to phobias. Treatment with the mGluR2 allosteric modulator JNJ-40411813 was effective in treating panic symptoms both in the preclinical models and in a small clinical sample.
Keywords: Anxiety, agoraphobia, amygdala, extinction.

Disclosure: Luc verDonck is an employee of Janssen; Marc Cuesters and Justine Kent are employees of Johnson & Johnson; some of the preclinical studies were supported by a grant from Janssen to Anantha Shekhar.

sec.title: T249. Characterization of Prescription Opioid Use and Maternal and Fetal Concentrations of Prescription Opioids During Pregnancy
Constance Guille*, Roger Newman, Lindsay DeVane, Laura Goetzl, Sammanda Ramamoorthy, Kimberly Leslie, Kathleen Brady
Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, South Carolina
sec.p: Background: Prescription opioids (PO) are prescribed to an astonishingly high number of pregnant women: 14-21% of women living in the U.S. receive these medications during pregnancy (Bateman, 2014; Desai, 2014). The overall benefit of these medications is questionable when considering the maternal risks associated with PO use (e.g., PO misuse, abuse, unintentional overdose, death) (Volkow, 2009) as well as fetal risks associated with in utero PO exposure (e.g., fetal malformations, low birth weight, prematurity, neonatal abstinence syndrome) (ACOG, 2012). Despite the significant consequences and high prevalence of PO use during pregnancy, very little is known about how women use these medications (i.e., short or long-term use, misuse) or why they use these medications (i.e., indication for use, other medical and psychiatric co-morbidities). Even less is known about the maternal and fetal concentrations of these medications during pregnancy. Characterization of PO use as well as the maternal and fetal concentrations of these medications during pregnancy is needed to inform the development of interventions aimed at minimizing the negative maternal and fetal impact of PO use during pregnancy.

Methods: Electronic data from clinical services, including prescription medications, rendered by obstetric providers was captured and stored in a clinical data repository. The database was queried to determine the use of POs in a sample of 2,394 pregnant women receiving prenatal care in an outpatient obstetrics practice from 2013 to 2014. Electronic medical records of women prescribed 2 or more months of POs were reviewed for misuse of medication defined as: (1) requesting an early refill of a PO medication; and (2) obtaining PO medication from someone other than the main prescriber (obstetrician). Lastly, maternal and fetal concentrations of POs were obtained as part of an on-going drug-use surveillance program for women voluntarily terminating their pregnancy during the first or second trimester.

Results: 12.4% (298/2394) of pregnant women were prescribed at least one opioid medication during pregnancy. Of those prescribed an opioid, 29.2% (87/298) were regularly provided with POs throughout pregnancy (e.g., at least 2 or more prescriptions). On review of 30 women taking POs throughout their entire pregnancy, 76% (23/30) of women had evidence of PO misuse over the course of pregnancy. The most common form of PO misuse was requesting an early refill with 65.2% (15/23) of women requesting a refill on average 5.2 (SD: 2.6) days in advance. Over one third (34.8% (8/23)) of women obtained concurrent POs from another source, 37.5% (3/8) obtained a PO from another outpatient prescriber, and 62.5% (5/8) received a PO from the emergency room. The indication for chronic use of PO throughout pregnancy could not be identified in 23.3% (7/30) of pregnant women. A psychiatric diagnosis was identified in 73% (22/30) of women, which were primarily characterized as a mood or anxiety disorder, 65% (17/22) and 45% (10/22), respectively. Analysis of samples from the drug concentration surveillance program initially focused on methadone (other PO are currently in analyses). At this time, samples from 7 women whose pregnancies were voluntarily terminated revealed both R- and S- methadone in substantially higher concentration in placental tissue (range 485 to 3724 ng/g) than in maternal plasma (55 to 258 ng/ml). In corresponding fetal tissue from 4 patients, the drug concentration ratio of fetal to maternal plasma varied from 0.62 to 3.13.

Conclusions: Our findings underscore the high rate of PO use and misuse during pregnancy. The absence of a primary pain indication for many of the pregnant women using POs and high comorbidity of psychiatric illness may suggest that POs are inappropriately used to moderate mood and anxiety disorders. As an initial step to minimize the negative impact of POs during pregnancy, providers should identify clear and appropriate indications for use of POs as well as monitor PO misuse throughout pregnancy. As methadone and other opioids are substrates for placental drug transporters, the degree of fetal drug exposure is likely influenced by definable genetic and environmental factors. The identification of these factors should complement the development of recommendations for safe and appropriate PO use in pregnancy.
Keywords: Pregnancy, Prescription Opioids, Depression, Anxiety.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T250. The National Pregnancy Registry for Atypical Antipsychotics: Effects of Fetal Exposure on Risk for Major Malformations and Extrapyramidal Symptoms
Lee Cohen*, Adele C. Viguera, Kathryn A. McInerney, Molly Kwiatkowski, Shannon Murphy, Elizabeth Lemon, Sonia Hernández-Díaz
Harvard Medical School/Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts
sec.p: Background: Atypical antipsychotics are widely used by reproductive-age women to treat a spectrum of psychiatric illnesses. Despite widespread use of this class of agents in women of childbearing potential, reproductive safety data across these medicines are sparse. The National Pregnancy Registry for Atypical Antipsychotics (NPRAA) at Massachusetts General Hospital was established in 2008 to address this knowledge gap. Website: www.womensmentalhealth.org/pregnancyregistry Toll-free number: 1-866-961-2388.

Methods: Potentially eligible enrollees include pregnant women between 18-45 years old who are capable of providing informed verbal consent. Women are eligible for inclusion if they have used an atypical antipsychotic at any point during pregnancy (exposed); the comparison group is comprised of women who have not been exposed to these agents. Three phone interviews are conducted: (1) baseline, proximate to the time of enrollment, (2) 7 months gestation, and (3) 2-3 months postpartum. Medical record release authorization is obtained for obstetric, labor and delivery, and the newborn pediatric medical records. Following receipt of medical records, a trained research assistant abstracts relevant information regarding primary and secondary outcomes including: (1) rates of major malformations in infants, (2) birth weight, (3) gestational age at delivery, (4) miscarriage rates, and (5) delivery complications. Data on maternal health outcomes during pregnancy, including weight gain across pregnancy and evidence of gestational hypertension/diabetes, are also obtained. Additional neonatal information regarding extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and withdrawal symptoms has been systemically collected from newborn pediatric medical records. Potential major malformations are identified and relevant records are sent to a dysmorphologist blinded to drug exposure for adjudication. A Scientific Advisory Board reviews interim data and determines release criteria for Registry findings.

Results: As of August 2014, total enrollment in the Registry was 452 women: 329 women in the exposed group and 123 women in the comparison group. The overall drop-out rate of subjects in the exposed and comparison groups combined was 13%. The proportion of study subjects for whom medical records were obtained was 83%. A total of 200 women (284 infants) completed the study and were eligible for inclusion in the analysis. Of 200 live births with first trimester exposure to atypical antipsychotics, three (N=3) major malformations were confirmed. Of the 84 control group live births, one (N=1) major malformation was confirmed. The absolute risk of major malformations was 1.5% for infants exposed to an atypical during the first trimester and 1.2% for unexposed infants. The risk ratio for major malformations was 1.26 (0.13, 11.85) comparing exposed to unexposed infants, not reaching statistical significance.

Conclusions: The NPRAA gathers prospective data regarding risk for critical outcomes following use of atypical antipsychotics during pregnancy. The Registry offers a systematic way to collect reproductive safety information which informs the care of women who may use these agents to sustain psychiatric well-being. With increased patient and clinician awareness about the NPRAA, reporting of increasingly reliable risk estimates for outcomes including risk for major malformations in infants is anticipated. This preliminary analysis indicates a level of risk that may be reassuring for both clinicians and women trying to make risk/benefit treatment decisions about using atypical antipsychotics during pregnancy. These preliminary findings suggest that atypical antipsychotics taken as a class do not appear to confer the level of teratogenic risk seen with major teratogens such as valproic acid.
Keywords: Atypical antipsychotics, Pregnancy, Registry, Bipolar disorder.

Disclosure: Sources of funding for the National Pregnancy Registry for Atypical Antipsychotics include Pfizer (2009-2011), AstraZeneca, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Sunovion Pharmaceuticals, Inc., and Ortho-McNeil Janssen. Research support for Lee Cohen includes that from Bristol-Myers Squibb, National Institute on Aging, National Institute of Health, National Institute of Mental Health, and Sunovion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. Consultancies for Lee Cohen include Noven Pharmaceutical and PamLam LLC, and consultancies for Sonia Hernandez-Diaz include Glaxosmithkline Biologicals and AstraZeneca.

sec.title: T251. Opioid Antagonism Alters Attention to and Recognition of Emotional Expressions in Healthy Adults
Margaret Wardle*, Anya Bershad, Kevin Yan, Harriet de Wit
University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, Texas
sec.p: Background: Studies in laboratory animals suggest the opioid system is critical to social functioning. In laboratory animals, μ-opioid agonists enhance positive responses to social stimuli, as measured by an increase in social play, but also appear to partially substitute for social contact, reducing motivation for social interaction. μ-Opioid antagonists, on the other hand, reduce responses to normally rewarding social stimuli, while increasing seeking of social interaction, as indicated by increased distress vocalizations during isolation, and increased choice of social rewards. To date, few studies have examined the role of opioids in social functions in humans. One technique for studying social reactivity in humans is to study responses to emotional facial expressions, which are critical social stimuli. Thus, we tested the effect of naltrexone (NTX), a nonselective opioid antagonist, on attention to, identification of and psychophysiological responses to happy, angry, fearful and sad expressions. We examined initial attentional capture by positive expressions as a measure of motivation to seek positive social stimuli, and attentional engagement, speed of identification and psychophysiological responses to positive expressions as measures of pleasure from positive social stimuli. We hypothesized that NTX would increase initial attentional capture, but reduce attentional engagement, slow identification and reduce positive psychophysiological responses to positive emotional faces.

Methods: Healthy adults (N=34) participated in a three-session, within-participant, double-blind study in which they received oral NTX 25mg, 50mg or placebo. At each session they self-reported drug effects and physical symptoms, and completed two tasks: 1. An attention task, consisting of 2-second presentations of pairs of faces (neutral and emotional), during which initial fixation of gaze (attentional capture) and length of gaze (attentional engagement) were measured, 2. An identification task consisting of dynamically developing emotional expressions during which speed of identification, and responses in facial muscles sensitive to emotional state were measured.

Results: NTX increased self-reported fatigue and nausea. It increased initial fixation to both positive and negative emotional faces compared to placebo, but did not alter length of gaze. NTX also slowed identification of emotional expressions, especially sad and fearful expressions, but did not alter psychophysiological responses to emotional expressions.

Conclusions: The finding that NTX increased initial attention to emotional faces is consistent with our hypothesis that NTX would increase seeking of social stimuli, although this effect was not specific to positive social stimuli. However, we found no support for our hypothesis that NTX would alter emotional responses to positive social stimuli, based on measures of attentional engagement or psychophysiological responses to faces. Instead, NTX slowed identification of emotional expressions, particularly fear and sadness. The unexpected findings may reflect species differences, limitations of our measures, or complex actions of NTX. NTX acts at the κ, and δ opioid receptors in addition to μ receptors, and κ-opioid antagonism can have anxiolytic effects. Our finding that NTX reduces recognition of fear and sadness may be one mechanism underlying these effects. Our findings that NTX alters responses to social stimuli in humans is important in relation to its clinical use in opioid and alcohol addiction, as social support plays an important role in addiction treatment. Future studies should examine how these effects relate to functioning in actual social situations.
Keywords: Opioid system, Social stimuli, Psychophysiology, Naltrexone.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T252. Estimates of Serotonin or Norepinephrine Transporter Occupancy Do Not Predict Antidepressant Response in a 12 Week Trial
Michael Owens*, Boadie Dunlop, Susan Plott, Faketa Zejnelovic, W. Edward Craighead, Helen Mayberg, Charles Nemeroff
Emory University, Atlanta, Georgia
sec.p: Background: The use of PET imaging of monoamine transporter occupancy is extremely valuable in initial dose-finding of novel medications beginning clinical trials. Moreover, seminal studies from Meyer and colleagues at the University of Toronto have revealed that standard, effective doses of common SSRIs provided ∼80% occupancy of brain serotonin transporters (SERT). There are limited data on whether poor response or remission is related to the magnitude of occupancy, especially for individual subjects. We have previously reported the use of a relatively simple ex vivo assay that utilizes unadulterated serum from subjects treated with monoamine transporter antagonists to estimate CNS transporter occupancy. The assay maintains the free:plasma protein bound drug ratio that exists in vivo. We sought to examine whether SERT occupancy explained poor response or remission in a group of depressed subjects receiving escitalopram or duloxetine.

Methods: As part of the large PReDICT study (Dunlop et al., 2012; http://www.trialsjournal.com/content/13/1/106), 344 never treated depressed subjects were randomly assigned to receive 12 week treatment of either CBT, escitalopram (10-20 mg/day) or duloxetine (30-60 mg/day). Serum was collected pretreatment (baseline), after 2 weeks and after 12 weeks. Serotonin and norepinephrine transport assays were performed using subject serum with no additional reagents other than 10 μl of [3H]-monoamine on intact HEK293 cells engineered to express the human SERT or NET.

Results: 251 subjects ultimately completed the trial. The data presented below represent preliminary analyses of the first 2/3rds of subjects to complete the study. 80% of subjects receiving escitalopram (N=59) and duloxetine (N=56) completed the study, with 67% of each group receiving the maximum dose at week 12. Non-response (escitalopram 27%, duloxetine 29%), response (73%, 71%) and remission (49%, 52%) rates for the two medications was similar. Data from all subjects revealed an ultimate Bmax for SERT occupancy of 88% for escitalopram and 90% for duloxetine with Kd values of 34 nM (serum drug concentration) and 84 nM, respectively. At 12 weeks, SERT occupancies (mean±SD throughout) did not differ between escitalopram-treated (65±14%; N=58) and duloxetine-treated (62±20%; N=54) subjects. NET occupancy was: escitalopram (2±20%; N=54), duloxetine (38±25%; N=51). SERT occupancy, whether for individual medications or as a direct function of SERT occupancy irrespective of which medication, did not predict non-response (SERT occupancy=64±19%; N=31), response (64±17%; N=81) or remission (63±16%; N=57) rates. Similarly, NET occupancy following duloxetine treatment did not predict non-response (34±25%; N=15), response (40±26%; N=36) or remission (41±22%; n=28) rate. Occupancies early in treatment at the end of week 2 also did not predict response at week 12.

Conclusions: Unlike our previous publications using human volunteers or previously treated depressed subjects, mean SERT occupancies were ∼10-15 occupancy percentage points below what we have previously observed with similar dosing. In this cohort, we found no evidence that there are differences in antidepressant response at 12 weeks as a function of SERT or NET occupancy and that non-response is not related to under dosing. This has significant implications for clinical decision making. Grant Support NIH: P50 MH077083 (HSM) 1R01MH080880 (WEC).
Keywords: SSRI, transporter occupancy, predictors of response, biological marker.

Disclosure: Drs. Owens and Nemeroff are patent holders of this technology (US 7,148,027 B2), however this technology has not been licensed to any commercial entity. Dr. Owens serves as a consultant to H. Lundbeck and receives compensation for these services. The terms of this arrangement have been reviewed and approved by Emory University in accordance with its conflict of interest policies. Dr. Nemeroff consults to Eli Lilly and Lundbeck.

sec.title: T253. Effects of Guanfacine in a Human Laboratory Model of Cannabis Withdrawal and on THC-induced Cognitive Impairment
Christopher Verrico*, Christopher Rodgman, Thomas Kosten, Thomas Newton
Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas
sec.p: Background: Substance abuse costs the U.S. over $600 billion annually and treatment can help reduce these costs. Cannabis is the most widely used illicit drug, and treatment admissions for cannabis are increasingly common. In fact, more people sought treatment for cannabis than for any other illicit substance in 2012 (SAMHSA, 2014). Cannabis use disorder (CBUD) is associated with persistent impairments of executive functions and a withdrawal syndrome during periods of abstinence (DSM-5, 2011). Core features of CBUD, executive deficits and withdrawal symptoms link closely with increased difficulty quitting and poor treatment outcomes. Thus, attenuating cannabis-induced executive dysfunction and withdrawal symptoms may especially be important early in treatment. In rodents, administration of a cannabinoid-1 receptor (CB1R) antagonist precipitates withdrawal symptoms following repeated exposure to CB1R agonists, such as Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). Precipitated THC withdrawal results in adrenergic receptor (AR) hyperactivity (Hart, 2005). The α2-AR agonist clonidine reduces AR activity (Carter, 1997), and reverses precipitated THC withdrawal (Lichtman, 2001). In non-treatment seeking humans, the α2-AR agonist lofexidine (2.4 mg/day) improved sleep and decreased relapse in a laboratory model, but worsened performance on cognitive tasks (Haney, 2008). Excessive catecholamine release in prefrontal cortex (PFC) impairs executive functions; AR hyperactivity specifically impairs executive functions by engaging α1- and β2-AR (Arnsten, 2011). Guanfacine, the most selective α2A-AR agonist clinically available, more potently enhances cognition than clonidine without sedative or hypotensive effects in monkeys (Arnsten, 2012). Guanfacine also prevents stress- (Morrow, 2004) but not THC-induced (Jentsch, 1998) activation of the dopamine system in PFC. We hypothesized that guanfacine would reduce withdrawal severity and attenuate THC-induced effects on executive functions.

Methods: Candidates recruited from the Houston metropolitan area through newspaper advertisements completed an initial telephone screen to assess basic eligibility. Potential participants signed consent forms that described all aspects of the study before the conduct of in-person eligibility screens. Institutional Review Boards at both the Baylor College of Medicine and the Michael E. DeBakey VA Medical Center (MEDVAMC) approved all procedures. A 2–4 week outpatient period separated the two-inpatient treatment periods. During both of the inpatient periods, participants admitted to the MEDVAMC one day before (Day 0) and discharged one day after (Day 8) administration of study medications. Dronabinol (THC) administration at 0900, 1100, and 1300 was open label on Day 1 (10 mg x3) and single blind on Day 7 (0, 10, & 20 mg). Guanfacine/placebo administration at 0800 on Days 2-7 was double blind and counter-balanced across participants during the two-inpatient treatment periods; on Day 2 participants took 1 mg of guanfacine, 2 mg on Day 3, and 3 mg on Days 4-7. On Days 0-8 at 0800 participants completed sleep, craving, and withdrawal questionnaires. On Day 0, and 60 min after receiving the third dose of THC on Days 1 and 7, participants completed the Hopkins verbal learning test-revised (HVLT), the dual n-back task, and the continuous performance test-II (CPT).

Results: To date, we have conducted 35 in-person eligibility screens of healthy subjects, of whom 15 were ineligible, and nine have not initiated the study. Eleven subjects have initiated at least one study day; one subject dropped out after completing one day and one subject dropped out after completing two days. Nine subjects completed at least one study phase with one subject never returning to complete the second phase. All of the subjects had reported only cannabis use prior to study enrollment and this was confirmed by urine toxicology, which we tested for the presence of cocaine, amphetamine, opiate, benzodiazepine, and cannabis metabolites. The four male (African American) and four female (one African American and three non-Hispanic Caucasian) subjects who initiated both study phases ranged in age from 21 to 54 years (35.7±12: mean±SD). On average, they reported initiating cannabis use at 13.7 (±1.9) years old and smoking cannabis for 24.3 (±13.2) years. The 4-weeks prior to the eligibility screen, participants reported smoking 3.3 (±2.2) grams of cannabis or 7.2 (±5.2) blunts and/or joints on 27.4 (±5.1) of the past 28 days. Five participants reported drinking alcohol (1.8±0.8/d) and five smoked cigarettes (9.0±9.9/d). Compared to baseline (Day 0) performance, THC administration (10 or 20 mg) did not significantly affect accuracy (correct/total trials) on the HVLT, dual n-back task, or the CPT. Compared to the effects of THC (20 mg) during the placebo treatment phase, guanfacine significantly increased accuracy on the visual n-back trials. Compared to the effects of placebo on cannabis withdrawal symptoms, guanfacine significantly improved measures of sleep and cannabis craving.

Conclusions: Impaired executive functions and withdrawal severity at baseline among individuals seeking treatment for CBUD reportedly predicts early dropout from treatment (Mason, 2012). Our data further define the significance of adrenergic dysregulation during the early stages of cannabis abstinence and suggest that treatments aimed at normalizing noradrenergic imbalances in executive and stress systems associated with cannabis use and withdrawal may help patients initiate and maintain long-term abstinence. Guanfacine was well tolerated and no unanticipated AEs were reported. The beneficial effects of guanfacine on withdrawal symptoms, cannabis cravings, and executive functions during the critical first week of abstinence suggests that it could potentially improve treatment outcomes. Particularly intriguing is the ability of guanfacine to improve executive functioning following THC administration, which could potentially help individuals deal with relapse if it occurs by dampening executive deficits that contribute to recidivism. These data suggest that guanfacine warrants further testing in treatment-seeking community-dwelling volunteers.
Keywords: cannabinoid, marijuana, guanfacine.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T254. ABCB1 Gene Variants and Antidepressant Treatment Outcome: A Meta-analysis
Barbara Breitenstein, Thomas Kirmeier*, Tanja Maria Brückl, Marcus Ising, Bertram Müller-Mhysok, Florian Holsboer, Darina Czamara
HolsboerMaschmeyer NeuroChemie GmbH, Munich, Germany
sec.p: Background: Major Depression (MD) is a leading cause of disability worldwide and a major contributor to the global burden of disease. Many patients fail to remit even after several consecutive treatment trials with antidepressants. Pharmacogenetics is an emerging field claiming that inherited factors are influencing drug-response. One promising example in MD and antidepressant response is the P-glycoprotein 1 (P-gp1), a gene product of the ABCB1 gene, functioning as a ‘custodian molecule’ regulating the blood-brain-barrier transition of several antidepressants. Following the initial findings of Uhr et al. (2008) that describe the influence of certain gene variants of ABCB1 on P-gp1 substrate-dependent MD remission-rates, many studies attempted to replicate the relevance of ABCB1 in antidepressant treatment response. While there is strong evidence in favor of the discovery of Uhr et al., there are also a number of failed studies not predicting the value of ABCB1 in therapy outcome. Here we report a systematic review and analysis of existing literature on ABCB1 and P-gp1 substrate-dependent treatment outcome in MD.

Methods: In this meta-analysis, we systematically summarized 16 pharmacogenetic studies focused on the association of six different ABCB1 variants (rs2032583, rs2235015, rs2235040, rs1045642, rs2032582, and rs1128503) and antidepressant treatment outcome in patients with MD (overall n=2695). Z-based meta-analysis was performed using Stouffer’s method, i.e. association p-values were transformed into corresponding Z-values. Direction of association was taken into account by multiplying the Z-values by+1 or -1, respectively. These terms were then weighted with the square-root of the sample-size within each study and a global Z-value was calculated. This global Z-value was divided by the square root of the sum of all squared weights to derive the meta-analysis Z-score. Meta-analysis was conducted for different scenarios: including all samples, excluding the original Uhr et al. sample, only inpatient samples, only outpatient samples, only Caucasian samples and samples with no/only hypnotic/anxiolytic co-medication allowed during the study period versus unrestricted prescription of co-medication. Bonferroni’s method was performed to correct for the number of tested SNPs, resulting in a threshold of 0.0083 (0.05/6). All calculations were performed using R.

Results: Analyzing the six selected gene variants of ABCB1 for their relevance as predictors for treatment response, the intronic SNP rs2032583 showed a nominally significant association (p=0.035) across all studies (n=2037 patients) and among all inpatients (n=485) withstanding correction (p=1.5x10-05).For rs1045642, rs2032582, and rs1128503, no associations were identified.

Conclusions: Considering a total sample of sixteen published studies from 2002-2014, the original finding from Uhr et al. could be replicated supporting the relevance of rs2032583 as predictor for the treatment of MD. Limitations of this meta-analysis are the heterogeneity in statistics, small sample size, and incalculable evidence of publication bias due to unavailable effect sizes. The current data underscore the importance of integrating the ABCB1 gene test into the clinical decision process.
Keywords: ABCB1, antidepressant response, pharmacogenetics, major depression.

Disclosure: HMNC GmbH holds an option for the above mentioned patents. T.K. and B.B. are employees of HMNC GmbH. M.I. and B.M.M. are consultants of HMNC GmbH. F.H. is CEO of HMNC GmbH. T.B. and D.C. have no potential conflicts of interest to declare.

sec.title: T255. Acute Administration of MDMA Influences Reward-driven Behavior and Its Underlying Neural Circuitry
Vani Pariyadath*, Gazi Rashid, Erin Kolbrich-Spargo, Thomas Ross, David Gorelick, Marilyn Huestis, Elliot Stein
National Institute of Drug Abuse, National Institutes of Health, Baltimore, Maryland
sec.p: Background: The use of MDMA (3,4-methylenedioxy-N-methylamphetamine) or “ecstasy” is associated with risk taking behavior, notably high-risk sexual behavior. However, it is currently unknown whether these behavioral effects of MDMA are a consequence of an increase in risky choices or a change in reward-driven behavior. To better understand the effects of MDMA on reward-related decision-making, as well as the underlying neurobiological mechanisms, we modeled risky decision-making following acute MDMA administration.

Methods: Eighteen ecstasy users performed the Rogers’ gambling task during functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) after receiving a placebo, low (1.0 mg/kg), or high (1.6 mg/kg) dose of MDMA, along with 18 controls, in a double-blind, mixed between-within subjects design. The Rogers’ task requires participants to choose between variable (“experimental”) and fixed (“control”) gambles, following which they are given feedback regarding their choices. Behavioral analyses were carried out using the R statistical package. The AFNI fMRI package was used to analyze activation at the time of feedback, and also functional connectivity during the Rogers’ task.

Results: Relative to controls, ecstasy users were more likely to choose the risky option even without MDMA on board. However, acute administration of MDMA did not consistently influence the likelihood of choosing the experimental over control gambles, regardless of the (1) size, (2) probability of winning, or (3) difficulty of making the choice. This suggests that MDMA does not influence risky choices, as measured by the Roger’s task. Instead, participants demonstrated an increase in behavioral adaptation to winning – specifically they were less likely to switch following a winning outcome for experimental options, with increasing plasma MDMA concentration. We hypothesized that this change in reward-driven behavior was either a consequence of a change in reward-related learning rate, in the positive reward prediction error, or in unexpected uncertainty (stemming from outcomes that violate top-down expectations). To test these hypotheses, we focused our analysis on regions known to process learning rates (amygdala, cuneus), reward prediction errors (ventral striatum), and unexpected uncertainty (posterior cingulate cortex or PCC, middle temporal cortex, insula, hippocampus). We found a main effect of MDMA on feedback-related activity within the PCC, hippocampus, and insula, but not in other regions of interest. Critically, a regression analysis revealed that the activity in the PCC explained MDMA effects on win-switch behavior. Finally, we examined functional connectivity between the PCC and reward -related regions, and found that MDMA administration influences the connectivity between the PCC and the caudate, orbitofrontal and anterior cingulate cortices.

Conclusions: Taken together, these data suggest that MDMA’s influence on risk-related behavior may be a consequence of a shift in reward-centered processing of risky options, potentially mediated through its impact on PCC function and connectivity, coupled with pre-existing differences in risk processing. This work was supported by the NIH/NIDA Intramural Research Program.
Keywords: MDMA, fMRI, risk, decision-making.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T256. Attenuation of Ketamine-induced Impairment in Verbal Learning and Memory in Healthy Volunteers by an AMPA Receptor Potentiator
Mohini Ranganathan*, Martin Bednar, Nicholas DeMartinis, Francois Gaudreault, Brynn Huguenel, John Krystal, Jessica Mancuso, Laura Zumpano, Deepak D'Souza
Yale University, West Haven, Connecticut
sec.p: Background: Schizophrenia is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide. Current treatments do not fully address cognitive impairment associated with schizophrenia (CIAS). Several lines of evidence indicate that N-methy-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) hypofunction may contribute to the pathophysiology of schizophrenia, and specifically to CIAS. One strategy to ameliorate NMDAR hypofunction is to stimulate alpha-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors (AMPAR). AMPAR opening depolarizes neuronal membranes to relieve the Mg2+block of colocalized NMDAR, which increases NMDAR-mediated Ca2+gating that ultimately generates changes in the synaptic morphology and function thought to underlie learning and memory. Consistent with these theories, the AMPAR positive allosteric modulator (“potentiator”) PF-04958242 attenuates spatial working memory deficits induced by the NMDAR antagonist ketamine in a rat radial arm maze task and a nonhuman primate spatial delayed response task. The primary aim of the reported study was to assess whether PF-04958242 attenuated ketamine-induced impairment in verbal learning and memory in healthy human volunteers. Secondary aims included assessing if PF-04958242 modulated ketamine-induced impairments in working memory and spatial working memory and the clinical symptoms associated with ketamine.

Methods: Healthy male subjects (n=29) participated in this randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 2-period, 2-way crossover study. During each of the two periods in this study, subjects received a single oral loading dose of PF-04958242 (0.35 mg) or placebo on Day 1. This was followed by a single daily dose of PF-04958242 (0.25 mg) or placebo for 4 subsequent days (Day 2-5).The effect of PF-04958242 on ketamine-induced cognitive impairment and associated subjective effects were assessed during a pharmacological challenge (racemic ketamine 0.23 mg/kg bolus over one min; and 0.58 mg/kg/hour for ∼ 70 min.) 1 hour after PF- 04958242 or placebo administration on Day 5. Subjects were housed on an inpatient unit from Day 0 (pre-dose) to Day 6 (post-ketamine challenge) of each test period. The two periods were separated by a 14-day washout period. The cognitive battery consisted of the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test-Revised (HVLT-R) and tasks from the computerized test battery Cogstate. Ketamine-induced psychotomimetic effects were captured on a modified version of the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) and the Clinician Administered Dissociative Symptom Scale (CADSS). The primary efficacy endpoint, mean score of immediate recall trials 2 and 3 in HVLT R on Day 5 (HVLT-R-IR2-3), was analyzed in subjects completing both treatment periods (and without major protocol deviations) with a linear crossover model including period, sequence, and treatment as fixed factors, baseline score as a continuous covariate, and subject as a random effect. Baseline was defined as the last pre-dose measurement taken on Day 1 for each period separately.

Results: A total of 29 subjects were randomized and 22 completed the study. The mean age of subjects was 33.9±6.8 years. The PF-04958242 plasma exposures were within the expected range for testing the study hypotheses. Ketamine treatment resulted in a mean impairment of 2.96 words on the HVLT-R-IR2-3. Ketamine also induced transient psychotomimetic effects. Treatment with PF-04958242 demonstrated a statistically significant attenuation of ketamine-induced cognitive impairment, resulting in placebo-adjusted mean reduction in ketamine-induced impairment of 0.58 words on HVLT-R-IR2-3 with a 2-sided 90% confidence interval (CI) of (0.04, 1.12) words. In exploratory analyses of secondary endpoints, PF-04958242 attenuated ketamine mediated impairment on the 2-back and spatial working memory tasks, but not on the 1-back task or one card learning task. There were no differences in PF-04958242 vs. placebo on ketamine-induced PANSS or CADSS scores. Overall, PF-04958242 was well tolerated with no serious adverse events. The most common adverse events (AEs) attributed to PF-04958242 were mild gastrointestinal disorders. Non-treatment-related AEs were consistent with the well-known AE profile of ketamine and were observed evenly across PF-04958242 and placebo groups.

Conclusions: Treatment with PF-04958242 for 5 days significantly attenuated the ketamine-induced cognitive impairment in verbal learning and memory (HVLT-R-IR2-3) in healthy volunteers, and resulted in similar effects on working memory tasks in exploratory analyses. These results suggest clinical translation of the findings with PF-04958242 in rat and nonhuman primate models of ketamine-mediated cognitive disruption. PF-04958242 was well tolerated, consistent with prior clinical studies, and did not appear to exhibit any consistent differences in its safety profile in combination with ketamine.
Keywords: memory, ketamine, AMPA, schizophrenia.

Disclosure: Deepak Cyril D’Souza, Mohini Ranganathan, and Brynn Huguenel havein the past 3 years or currently receives research grant support administered through Yale University School of Medicine from Pfizer Inc. Martin Bednar, Nicholas DeMartinis, Francois Gaudreault, Jessica Mancuso, and Laura Zumpano are all employees of Pfizer, Inc.

sec.title: T257. Influence of Intranasal Oxytocin on Fear Consolidation in Healthy Humans
Eric Bui*, Scott Orr, Rebecca Ojserkis, Naomi Simon, Elizabeth Hoge
Harvard Medical School/Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts
sec.p: Background: Oxytocin, a neuropeptide produced in the hypothalamus has been involved in the activation of fear extinction-based neural circuits and fear responses. Fear conditioning (measured by the differential response to a conditioned stimulus CS+paired with an aversive stimulus and a neutral stimulus CS-) provides a useful model in which to study the effect of pharmacological agents on fear acquisition and extinction. Although recent data in healthy humans suggest that treatment with intranasal oxytocin may facilitate extinction recall, to date, little is known about the effects of oxytocin on memory consolidation processes. Memory consolidation blockade may be helpful in secondary prevention of posttraumatic stress disorder. The present study aims to examine the influence of intranasal oxytocin compared to placebo on consolidation of fear acquisition in a classical fear conditioning paradigm.

Methods: Healthy volunteers (mean (SD) age=35.6 (15.5); 47% (n=14) women) underwent a 2-day fear conditioning paradigm. On day 1, after fear conditioning procedure was completed, they were randomized to receive intranasal oxytocin 30 IU (n=14) versus pill placebo (n=16). On day two, they completed fear extinction procedures. They were assessed with measures of anxiety (Beck Anxiety Inventory, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, Anxiety Sensitivity Index), depression (Beck Depression Anxiety), and worry (Penn State Worry Questionnaire) on day one, just prior to undergoing the experimental paradigm. At baseline, the two groups did not differ on any of the socio-demographic or clinical characteristics. We hypothesized that treatment with intranasal oxytocin would be associated with a reduced consolidation of fear memory as evidenced by a smaller differential skin conductance response (SCR) during the first two extinction trials, compared to placebo. In order to reduce heteroscedasticity, SCR values were square-root transformed each. Repeated measure analysis of variance (ANOVAR) and t-test comparisons were used to examine differences between the oxytocin vs. placebo groups in the magnitude of their differential skin conductance response during early extinction.

Results: Despite randomization, individuals receiving oxytocin exhibited greater orienting response than individuals receiving placebo (t=2.29, p=0.03). In the habituation phase, there was an effect of group, with the oxytocin group exhibiting a larger differential skin conductance response (F(1,28)=6.89, p=0.014) than placebo group; the main effect of Trials was not significant (F(4, 112)=0.74, p=0.57), nor was the interaction (F(4, 112)=1.57, p=0.187). During the fear acquisition phase, there was a nearly significant main effect of Trials (F(4, 112)=2.1, p=0.085) with an increase of differential skin conductance response over time, but no significant main effect of drugs (F(1, 28)=0.29, p=0.60), nor Drug X Trials interaction (F(4, 112)=0.70, p=0.59). There were no significant group differences in differential skin conductance response at the end of conditioning (t=-0.53, p=0.60). On day 2, there were no significant differences between the oxytocin and the placebo groups on the first two extinction trials (mean (SD)=0.005(0.394) vs. 0.146(0.314), t=-1.092, p=0.28). Similarly, during early extinction, a ANOVAR failed to show a main effect of Trials (F(4, 112)=1.58, p=0.18), Drug, or Drug X Trials interaction.

Conclusions: Our results suggest that oxytocin administered in double blind fashion immediately after fear conditioning may be associated with a smaller, albeit not significant, differential skin conductance response at the beginning of extinction. Although, our study may have been underpowered, the effect size was small. Impairments in memory reconsolidation have been identified as a key component of PTSD pathophysiology and these preliminary findings does not support the use of oxytocin for secondary PTSD prevention.
Keywords: oxytocin, fear conditioning, memory.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T258. Discovery and Development of EMB-001 for the Treatment of Substance Use Disorders
Nicholas Goeders, Glenn Guerin, Carol Gloff, Gary Connor, Doug Feltner, Michael Detke*
Indiana University, Carmel, Indiana
sec.p: Background: EMB-001 is a combination of two FDA-approved drugs: metyrapone, a cortisol synthesis inhibitor, and oxazepam, a benzodiazepine. Both have been approved by the FDA and other regulatory authorities for five decades; oxazepam for various anxiety disorders (acute and chronic use) and metyrapone, administered at 3000 – 4500 mg for one day only as a test for hypothalamic-pituitary ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) function. Metyrapone is also approved in Europe for chronic administration in Cushing’s syndrome, in which there is chronic over-production of cortisol. There is a complex relationship between stress, anxiety, the HPA (hypothalamo-pituitary-adrenal) axis and psychomotor stimulant reinforcement. The hypothesis we have been exploring is whether a combination of drugs working by different stress-related mechanisms may have the potential to reduce substance use disorders, at doses that minimize the risks (safety, tolerability, abuse potential) of each individual drug.
Methods: We summarize here a range of preclinical and clinical data demonstrating the potential utility of EMB-001 for the treatment of substance use disorders.

Results: We have shown (Goeders, 2008) that metyrapone and oxazepam are each effective alone for reducing cocaine self-administration in rats, but that the EMB-001 combination is effective at doses of each component that are ineffective when given alone. In a subsequent dose-finding study, we replicated our original study and confirmed that the effective doses used in the EMB-001 combination are lower than the effective doses of each drug alone (new data not previously disclosed). We have also reported that EMB-001 reduces nicotine self-administration in rats Goeders 2012), and that EMB-001 attenuates cocaine and methamphetamine cue reactivity (animal model of relapse) in rats (Keller, 2013). Although metyrapone has not been approved for chronic administration in the United States, results from repeat dose clinical trials are reported in five published papers (O’Dwyer 1995; Murphy 1998; Eriksson, 2001; Jahn, 2004; Rogoz 2004). The drug has been found to be generally safe and well-tolerated in doses of 500-4000 mg/day given for 2-8 weeks, for the treatment of major depressive disorder (four studies) or alcohol consumption among heavy drinkers (one study). Very few SAEs or discontinuations due to AEs were reported. Adverse events were consistent with the metyrapone label: dizziness, headache and nausea were usually the most common. In part because of these data, a pilot human clinical study of the combination of metyrapone and oxazepam in cocaine dependence was conducted (Kablinger, 2012) and showed a significant reduction in cocaine use at the higher dose tested (1500 mg/d metyrapone, 20 mg/d oxazepam). The combination in this clinical trial was generally safe and well-tolerated. IND-enabling toxicology studies using twice daily oral dosing for 90 days have been completed in rats and dogs, the IND was submitted, and the FDA has allowed it to proceed.

Conclusions: Preclinical data demonstrate that EMB-001 is effective and well tolerated in animal models of drug addiction. A pilot human study also showed efficacy in cocaine dependence. Future plans are as follows: A Phase 1 combined single ascending dose and multiple ascending dose study is planned to begin in late 2014. This study will be conducted in otherwise healthy cigarette smokers. The primary goals are to assess the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic profile of EMB-001. A secondary goal is to assess for potential efficacy in reducing nicotine/cigarette use. If successful, this study will enable further development of EMB-001 for various substance use disorders. Plans are underway to seek funding for Phase 1b/2 studies in cocaine use disorder, as well as a Phase 2 study in smoking cessation.
Keywords: cocaine, nicotine, metyrapone, oxazepam.

Disclosure: All of the authors except Glenn Guerin are now, or have been, paid employees/consultants/advisors of Embera Neurotherapeutics, which is developing EMB-001 for the treatment of substance use disorders.

sec.title: T259. Pentraxin-3 - A Novel Biomarker for Major Depression
Danika Prochaska, Angelos Halaris*, Brittany Garlenski, Debra Hoppensteadt, Jawed Fareed
Loyola University Medical Center and Hines VA Medical Center, Maywood, Illinois
sec.p: Background: According to the National Institute of Mental Health, in 2012 16 million United States adults experienced an episode of depression. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is one of the most prevalent psychiatric conditions and is associated with some of the highest levels of morbidity and mortality in mood disorders. From causation to treatment, research has sought to identify the mediators involved in MDD. Recently, our understanding of MDD has expanded to include the relationship between inflammation and depression. Inflammatory biomarkers, such as cytokines and C-Reactive Protein (hsCRP), have been shown to be elevated in MDD patients. This link between inflammation and MDD raises questions about causation as well as long-term consequences, notably atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease. If compounds, such as hsCRP, can be proven to be specific and valid biomarkers of MDD, then new avenues for diagnosis and treatment that uniquely target inflammation can be explored. hsCRP is a member of the pentraxin protein family, a group of acute phase reactants involved in immune response. hsCRP is a short-chain pentraxin produced in the liver and upregulated by cytokines during early inflammation. In contrast to hsCRP, Pentraxin 3 (PTX-3) is the only identified long-chain pentraxin and it is produced locally by neutrophils and macrophages. While there is extensive literature on the role of hsCRP in MDD, there is little information on the potential role of PTX-3 in MDD. The objective of this study was to assess whether PTX-3 is significantly elevated in patients with MDD and whether this inflammatory biomarker changes with antidepressant treatment. We measured PTX-3 levels in MDD patients and compared it to age/sex-matched healthy controls at baseline, as well as at specific intervals throughout treatment. Additionally, we assessed whether PTX-3 levels were correlated with hsCRP, which has previously been shown to be elevated in MDD.

Methods: In two consecutively run studies a total of 90 MDD patients who met inclusion criteria were enrolled. MDD patients and healthy controls (N=44) were evaluated with structured interview and a battery of standard depression and anxiety scales, pertinent family and medical history, blood chemistries, urinalysis, and toxicology screens. Baseline blood levels of biomarkers, such as hsCRP and PTX-3, were obtained upon enrollment. In the first study MDD patients received Escitalopram (Lexapro) with a flexible dose range between 10-60 mg/day determined at the discretion of the physician. In the second study, MDD patients were treated mono-therapeutically with Quetiapine (Seroquel) with a flexible dose range between 50-350 mg/day also at the discretion of the physician. Patients returned for follow-up assessments and blood measurements at weeks 2, 4, 8, and 12. During the study, the patients did not receive any other form of therapy. At the conclusion of the study, correlations between pre- and post-treatment biomarkers and rating scales, as well as correlations between MDD and HC biomarkers were assessed to further our understanding of the role of inflammation in MDD.

Results: Based on biomarker analyses completed at this point, the following results have been obtained: -A statistically significant elevation in PTX-3 at baseline was found in the MDD patients versus the healthy controls (p=0.013) -A statistically significant elevation in hsCRP at baseline was found in the MDD patients versus the healthy controls (p=0.003) -No significant change was found in PTX-3 levels with treatment -No significant change was found in hsCRP levels with treatment -Baseline PTX-3 levels did not significantly correlate with HAM-D scores -Baseline PTX-3 levels did not significantly correlate with HAM-A scores -Baseline hsCRP levels did not significantly correlate with HAM-D scores -Baseline hsCRP levels significantly correlate with HAM-A scores (p=0.012) -A statistically significant negative correlation was found in baseline hsCRP and PTX-3 in MDD patients (correlation coefficient=-0.439, p=0.012).

Conclusions: We conclude that baseline PTX-3 levels may be another useful biomarker in clarifying the relationship between MDD and inflammation. Furthermore, the negative correlation identified between baseline hsCRP and baseline PTX-3 suggests that there may be an interaction between these two pentraxin family reactants. Clearly the proportion of monomeric and pentameric hsCRP in MDD is a potential confounding factor requiring further investigation. With hsCRP being a short-chain pentraxin, and PTX-3 being a long-chain pentraxin, we postulate that a breakdown mechanism or feedback inhibition may be occurring. To our knowledge, this is the first study to correlate hsCRP and PTX-3 in MDD patients.
Keywords: Pentraxin-3, CRP, Major Depressive Disorder, inflammation.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T260. The Acute Effects of MDMA in Social Contexts
Matthew Kirkpatrick*, Harriet de Wit
University of Southern California, Keck School of Medicine, Los Angeles, California
sec.p: Background: The drug±3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, “ecstasy”, “molly”) is reportedly used because it increases feelings of sociability and interpersonal closeness and enhances social interaction. However, in most laboratory studies the participants are tested under relatively isolated social conditions, which may not simulate the effects of this drug in the naturalistic social setting.

Methods: Healthy experienced MDMA users participated in three laboratory sessions in which they received MDMA (0.5 or 1.0 mg/kg or placebo; double blind) in one of three social conditions: solitary (SOL, tested alone; N=10), in the presence of a research assistant (RAP; N=11) or in the presence of another participant who also received the drug (OPP; N=11). Participants were randomly assigned to the three social conditions. Cardiovascular measures and subjective effects were assessed before drug administration and repeatedly thereafter. In the RAP and OPP groups, measures of social interaction were also obtained.

Results: The effects of MDMA differed across the three conditions on several measures. The drug produced the greatest effects in the OPP condition, including higher ratings of “feel drug”, “dizzy” and “confident”, and greater increases in cardiovascular measures, compared to the SOL or RAP conditions (p<0.05 for all comparisons). Regardless of group condition, MDMA increased ratings of attractiveness of another person (Main Effect of Dose: F(2,57)=3.6, p<0.05) and increased social interaction in the RAP and OPP groups (Main Effect of Dose: F(2,253)=8.3, p<0.001).

Conclusions: These findings support a growing body of evidence showing that effects of drugs are greater when the drug is used in the presence of other drug users. It remains to be determined how MDMA and social context interact to modify its acute subjective, behavioral, and reinforcing effects.
Keywords: MDMA, social interaction, mood, humans.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T261. Intranasal Oxytocin Selectively Modulates Social Perception, Approach Behavior, and Craving in Human Alcohol Abusers
Jennifer Mitchell, Dawn Weinstein, Peter Arcuni, Joshua Woolley*
San Francisco Veterans Affairs Medical Center, San Francisco, California
sec.p: Background: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is associated with immense societal and individual costs, yet only three compounds are approved for its treatment. While somewhat effective, all cause unpleasant side effects, compliance is often low, and relapse is common. Novel treatments are desperately needed. Emerging preclinical and clinical evidence suggests that in addition to its well-known prosocial effects, administration of the neuropeptide oxytocin can decrease alcohol self-administration and symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. Because alcohol abuse impairs social abilities that in turn predict treatment success, a therapeutic agent that both improves social perception and promotes abstinence could be particularly effective. We investigated the effects of oxytocin administration to heavy drinkers on social perception, approach bias for alcohol and appetitive cues, and cue-induced alcohol craving. As oxytocin effects often depend on individual differences in psychosocial factors, we also explored the relationships between oxytocin effects and factors relevant to AUD. Our objective is to determine if oxytocin could be a useful therapeutic option for the social deficits, automatic implicit biases, and cravings associated with AUD.

Methods: Intranasal oxytocin (OT) and placebo (PL) were administered to 32 non-treatment seeking heavy drinkers (drinks/week: 27, % female: 41) in a randomized, double-blind, crossover study with testing days at least one week apart. Social perception, alcohol and appetitive cue approach bias, and cue-induced craving were quantified following OT and PL administration. Social perception was measured with the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (RMET) in which subjects label mental states of subtle affective facial expressions in black and white photos of the eye-region of faces. Approach biases were measured with a computerized approach-avoidance task in which subjects are shown alcohol and appetitive images in landscape and portrait orientations, and instructed to pull a joystick to enlarge, or push it to reduce, image size depending upon orientation. The difference in RT between push and pull determines the approach bias (e.g., a positive push-pull=approach bias). Cue-induced craving was determined by administering the Alcohol Use Questionnaire before and after exposure to each subject’s alcohol beverage of choice for 180 seconds. Craving is reported on a scale from 1-7. As psychosocial factors can moderate OT effects, we explored the relationship between validated measures of severity of alcohol abuse (AUDIT), locus of control (LOC), future time horizon (STPI: future), and attachment style (ECR-R) with our behavioral outcomes. Behavioral data were compared between OT and PL conditions using paired t-tests and Cohen’s d values for mean difference. Pearson’s correlations were used to assess relationships between our behavioral tasks and psychosocial measures.

Results: Social Perception: OT significantly improved performance on easy RMET items (mean(SEM), PL: 83.4%(1.9), OT: 88.2%(.7), p=.018, d=.64), but not on difficult RMET items. There were no significant correlations between OT effects on RMET and psychosocial measures. Approach Bias: We found no approach bias to alcohol imagery on the PL test day, and this was unchanged by OT administration. There were significant correlations between OT-induced change in alcohol approach bias (OT–PL) and LOC (p=.028, r=.387) and STPI: future (p=.04, r=.365) scores such that OT decreased approach to alcohol cues in individuals with an externalized LOC and a greater focus on the present. In contrast to alcohol imagery, there was a robust approach bias for appetitive food images on the PL test day, which was significantly reduced by oxytocin (PL: 62.8(25.8), OT: □31.2(23.3), p=.016, d=.64). There were no significant correlations between OT effects on appetitive approach and psychosocial factors. Craving: Exposure to an alcohol cue reliably induced alcohol craving (before: 2.4(.2), after: 3.1(.3), p<.001, d=1.09), but OT did not significantly alter craving. However, we found significant correlations between OT-induced change in craving and both AUDIT (p=.05, r=.35) and ECR-R: anxiety (p=.009, r=-.45) scores such that OT reduced cravings in individuals with less severe drinking habits and greater attachment anxiety.

Conclusions: These results show that a single dose of intranasal oxytocin can improve social perception and attenuate approach bias to appetitive cues in heavy drinkers. Furthermore, oxytocin can attenuate approach bias to alcohol cues and reduce alcohol craving in a subset of alcohol abusing subjects. In line with growing evidence that OT effects depend on both individual differences and contextual factors, our data suggest that OT may not be a one size fits all therapeutic approach for AUD, instead helping patients with particular traits. As our tasks selectively measure different aspects of addictive behavior and symptomology, it follows that OT may affect the distinct behavioral processes targeted by each task differently. In designing an OT intervention for AUD, it may be necessary to identify what psychosocial factors and symptomology, as well as what underlying causes of drug seeking behavior, will selectively benefit from OT. Further work is needed to replicate and extend these promising findings.
Keywords: oxytocin, alcohol abuse, social perception, cue reactivity.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T262. Alpha-1 Adrenergic Receptor (ADRA1A) Genotype Influences Magnitude of Acute Cocaine-induced Subjective Effects in Cocaine-dependent Individuals
Daryl Shorter*, David Nielsen, Sara Hamon, Ellie Nielsen, Thomas R. Kosten, Thomas F. Newton, Richard De La Garza
Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas
sec.p: Background: The psychostimulant mechanism of action of cocaine is based upon its ability to inhibit reuptake of the dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine transporters, producing an increase in synaptic levels of these neurotransmitters. Cocaine reward is mediated primarily through the mesocorticolimbic dopamine (DA) system; however, both preclinical and clinical evidence suggests that stimulation of the noradrenergic system contributes to cocaine reward and reinforcement. Activation of the noradrenergic system is likely influenced by the genetic subtype of the α1A-adrenoceptor. The gene ADRA1A coding for α1A-adrenoceptor has a functional polymorphism rs1048101 in exon 2 coding for the substitution of an arginine (ARG) for a cytosine (CYS) at codon 347 of the C-terminus, that may alter the activity of this receptor and influence critical functions for prevention of relapse in cocaine dependence including vigilance, impulsivity, and working memory. In a recent study, our group found that disulfiram, which attenuates NE activity through its ability to inhibit dopamine-beta-hydroxylase, significantly reduced the percentage of cocaine positive urines among T allele carriers (TT/TC) for rs1048101 of ADRA1A (Shorter et al., 2013). In CC homozygotes for ADRA1A, however, disulfiram showed no difference from placebo in regards to reduction of cocaine positive urines. These findings suggest preferential response to noradrenergic medications based upon α1A-adrenoceptor genetic subtype. However, the impact of receptor subtype on subjective responses to cocaine have yet to be elucidated. We examined whether a functional variant of the ADRA1A gene influences cocaine-induced subjective effects in a group of cocaine-dependent individuals. We hypothesized that CC homozygotes for rs1048101 would report higher ratings of cocaine-induced subjective effects in the laboratory.

Methods: This study was a within-subject, double blind, placebo-controlled inpatient human laboratory evaluation of 65 non-treatment seeking, cocaine-dependent (DSM-IV) subjects, aged 18 to 55 years. Participants received both placebo (saline, IV) and cocaine (40mg, IV), and subjective responses were assessed 15 minutes prior to receiving an infusion and at 5-minute intervals for the subsequent 20 minutes. We then genotyped the rs1048101 variant of the α1A-adrenoceptor (ADRA1A) and evaluated whether the Cys to Arg substitution at codon 347 in exon 2 (Cys347Arg) influenced the magnitude of the subjective effects produced by cocaine.

Results: Thirty (46%) subjects were found to have the major allele CC genotype and 35 (44%) carried at least one T allele of rs1048101 (TT or TC genotype). The data show that individuals with the CC genotype exhibited significantly greater responses for ‘desire’ (p<0.05), ‘high’ (p<0.05), ‘any drug effect’ (p<0.05), ‘like cocaine’ (p<0.05), and ‘likely to use cocaine if given access’ (p<0.05).

Conclusions: We found that homozygous individuals for the C allele of rs1048101 in the ADRA1A gene (ARG conformation) reported significantly elevated ratings of drug desire, high, and liking in response to acute cocaine administration in the laboratory, while those carrying at least one T allele of rs1048101 reported lower subjective effects. This study indicates that ADRA1A genotype could be used to identify individuals for whom acute cocaine exposure may be more rewarding and by inference may result in greater difficulty in establishing and/or maintaining abstinence from cocaine.
Keywords: ADRA1A, subjective effects, cocaine, dependence.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T263. The Relationship Between Stress-induced Craving and Intravenous Alcohol Self-administration Behavior in Non-dependent Drinkers: Impact Of Binge-drinking History
Bethany Stangl*, Jonathan Westman, Molly Zametkin, Kristin Corey, Lauren Blau, Laura Kwako, Rajita Sinha, Vijay Ramchandani
National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland
sec.p: Background: Craving, particularly in response to exposure to stress and alcohol associated cues, can potentially trigger alcohol seeking behavior. These craving responses have been predictive of relapse to excessive alcohol use and abuse, and this relationship is well supported in dependent drinkers. However, the relationship between stress and alcohol cues and alcohol craving and subsequent consumption in non-dependent drinkers is less clear. The objective of this study was to characterize acute stress and alcohol-cue reactivity and craving and their relationship with operant IV alcohol self-administration (IV-ASA) in non-dependent drinkers, using a guided imagery script challenge, as well as to compare these relationships in binge vs. non-binge drinkers. IV-ASA was assessed using the Computer-Assisted Self-infusion of Ethanol (CASE) method that allows individuals to self-administer alcohol while controlling the breath alcohol concentration (BrAC) using a physiologically-based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) model-based algorithm.

Methods: Healthy non-dependent drinkers (N=12) were stratified into two groups that consisted of binge drinkers (N=6) and non-binge drinkers (N=6) using the Timeline Follow Back (TLFB) questionnaire. All participants completed three cue reactivity scripts followed by IV-ASA sessions. Each session began with an exposure to a 5-min audio recording of personalized guided imagery scripts to induce acute stress, alcohol craving, and a neutral-relaxing state. This was immediately followed by a 120-min free-access IV-ASA session in which participants could push a button to receive IV ethanol infusions. IV-ASA measures included peak (PEAK) and average (AVG) breath alcohol concentration (BrAC), number of button presses (NBP) and total ethanol (EtOH) infused during the sessions. Serial blood samples were collected and analyzed for cortisol (CORT) and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Subjective measures included the Subjective Units of Distress Scale (SUDS) and Drug Effects Questionnaire (DEQ).

Results: Results demonstrated that the imagery script exposures successfully induced reactivity, with significant increases in SUDS scores (p<0.05) and a trend-level increase in cortisol (p=0.07) following the stress-cue script compared with neutral-cue scripts. Participants also showed higher IV-ASA, indicated by significantly higher NBP (p<0.05) and a trend for greater EtOH (p=0.08) following the stress-cue script in comparison to the neutral-cue script. The subjective measure of DEQ “want more alcohol” was also positively correlated with self-administration measures (all ps<0.04).There was a strong positive correlation between self-administration measures (PEAK, AVG, ETOH) and in the stress condition and maximum ACTH and cortisol levels (all ps<0.02). These same positive correlations were also found in the alcohol condition (all ps<0.04). There was no relationship between these measures in the neutral-relaxing condition. Comparison of measures of cue-reactivity, craving and IV-ASA measures between binge and non-binge drinkers revealed robust differences. Binge drinkers had significantly greater ASA measures (PEAK, AVG, NBP) in comparison to non-binge drinkers in response to stress and alcohol cues relative to neutral cues (all p values<0.05). Binge drinkers showed approximately two-fold higher IV-ASA following stress-cues compared to neutral cues, while non-binge drinkers did not show any difference across cue-type.

Conclusions: These results demonstrate a significant temporal relationship between stress and alcohol cues and self-administration behavior, subjective response, and physiological measures in non-dependent drinkers. Overall, non-dependent drinkers demonstrate increased stress reactivity and craving following acute stress cue exposure and this translates into increased alcohol self-administration. In particular, the data suggest that binge drinkers have a stronger response to both acute stress and alcohol cues in comparison to non-binge drinkers, as reflected in greater alcohol self-administration behavior. These data may provide important information on the relationship between stress and alcohol seeking behavior that may underlie risk for alcohol-related problems. Comparison of the association between subjective perceptions of stress and craving between binge and non-binge drinkers may provide important information on potential triggers for excessive alcohol use in this sample of non-dependent drinkers.
Keywords: Stress, Alcohol-seeking behavior, Cue Reactivity, IV Alcohol.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T264. Voluntary Alcohol Intake and Food Intake: Interaction With Dietary Fat
Michael Lewis*, Micki Atzram, Junqi Zheng
Hunter College CUNY, New York, New York
sec.p: Background: Several lines of research support the interaction of alcohol abuse and dependence with food intake and nutritional systems.
