Alcohol, a calorically rich food as well as a drug of abuse, is consumed excessively after food deprivation and moderate alcohol administrations can increases food consumption. In addition microinjection of the orexigenic neuropeptides such as galanin increase alcohol intake and alcohol consumption increases these neuropeptides in hypothalamic feeding sites. Galanin’s orexigenic effects are especially potent with high fat foods. The research reported here examined the effects of exposure to low and high fat diets on EtOH consumption.

Methods: Experimental rats were placed on either a low fat or high fat powered chow diet for 2 weeks prior to EtOH access. Controls were maintained on equi-caloric and equi-nutrient diet during this period. Fat content of the diets was: low fat diet=4.1% fat, high fat diet>20% fat, control diet 11%. All animals were then given access to three days of 1, 3, 5 and 7% EtOH and water in a two-bottle choice.

Results: Deprivation of dietary fat for two weeks before access to alcohol did not increase voluntary alcohol consumption during the exposure to increasing alcohol concentration. However, exposure to a diet high in fat increased alcohol consumption during this period and after stable alcohol consumption.

Conclusions: Although deprivation of fat did not affect later alcohol intake, intake of excess fat did increase alcohol intake. The latter finding is in agreement with previous findings that show that exogenous fat administration increases alcohol intake. These data further support the extensive interaction of alcohol intake and feeding/nutritional systems and suggest the motivation underlying alcohol abuse and dependence is intimately related to these systems.
Keywords: alcohol, fat, intake, deprivation.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T265. Influence of Gonadal Hormones on Behavioral Sensitivity to Low-dose Ketamine
Mohamed Kabbaj*, Krsitin Shoepfer, Samantha Saland
Florida State University, Tallahassee, Florida
sec.p: Background: Considerable sex bias in the risk for depression is well-established. Extending beyond prevalence and presentation, sex differences in antidepressant efficacy have also been identified that point to a role for gonadal hormones in moderating treatment response. Despite its clear importance, the precise nature of hormonal influence on antidepressant efficacy is unclear and understudied. We recently reported that female rats are more sensitive to the fast-acting antidepressant ketamine (KET) when compared to male rats, and that gonadal estrogen (E2) and progesterone (P4) are required for this heightened response.

Methods: The effect of KET (2.5 mg/kg) on sucrose preference was systematically investigated in intact and gonadectomized adult male and female rats treated or not with equivalent levels of E2, P4, E2+P4 or testosterone (T).

Results: Consistent with our previous findings, results showed that the pro-hedonic effect of 2.5 mg/kg KET was abolished in ovariectomized female rats, but could be reinstated following cyclic E2+P4 treatment. However, KET was ineffective in male rats regardless of treatment condition. When addressing the alternative possibility that T may decrease the sensitivity of male rats to the effects of KET, we found that neither T depletion in male rats nor its supplementation in female rats influenced patterns of responding following KET treatment when compared to placebo-treated intact male and female rats. In summary, while ovariectomy abolished sex differences in the sensitivity of male and female rats to low-dose KET, treatment with equivalent levels of testicular and ovarian hormones revealed sexually-dimorphic effects, where only E2+P4 treatment in OVX female rats was found to modulate sensitivity to the hedonic effects of KET.

Conclusions: These findings suggest that E2 and P4 may act upon organizational differences in the brain to increase the sensitivity of female rats to the effects of KET on reward- and depression-related behaviors.
Keywords: Ketamine, Depression, Sex Differences, Gonadal Hormones.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T266. Sex Differences Occur within the Glutamate System in Major Depression and Suicide
Monsheel Sodhi*, Angel Gray, Amy Deep-Soboslay, Thomas M. Hyde, Joel E. Kleinman
University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, Illinois
sec.p: Background: Converging evidence from basic and clinical research reveals the existence of altered structure and activity within the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) in major depression (MDD) (Heller et al., 2013). These data indicate that there is a cognitive impairment in patients with MDD. Recent clinical breakthroughs show that an acute low dose of an antagonist of the NMDA subtype of glutamate receptor, ketamine, has rapid antidepressant efficacy in treatment-resistant patients with MDD (Berman et al., 2000). MDD has a strong heritable component and has been associated with genetic variation within the glutamate system. MDD is also associated with environmental stress and adverse life events. Gene expression is a readout of both genetic (inherited) and environmental precipitants of MDD. The genes regulating the glutamate system are likely to be disrupted in MDD and investigation of postmortem brain is imperative to uncover important genetic abnormalities that contribute to the pathophysiology of MDD and suicide. Studies of the expression of selected glutamate receptors in the DLPFC have been conducted in small postmortem cohorts of MDD subjects and controls, using a variety of methods. These previous studies have yielded mixed results but nevertheless suggest that there may be dysfunction of the glutamatergic genes in MDD and suicide. In the current study, we have tested the hypothesis that glutamatergic gene expression is disrupted in MDD and suicide.

Methods: A large cohort of postmortem subjects has been tested. Gene expression levels were measured using RNA extracted from the gray matter of the dorsal lateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC, BA46). Two groups of postmortem subjects were included in this study: (1) patients diagnosed by DSM-IV criteria with major depressive disorder (n=80), but no other psychiatric co-morbidities; (2) a comparison group (n=34) with no history of psychiatric or neurological disorders. Within the group of MDD subjects, 51 had died by suicide. Specimens were obtained from the Clinical Brain Disorders Branch at the National Institute of Mental Health. Applied Biosystems assays were used for all gene expression analyses (https://products.appliedbiosystems.com/). Of the 23 glutamate receptor genes tested, two (mGluR6 and mGluR8) were not expressed at detectable levels in the human DLPFC. Analyses of 6 housekeeping genes revealed that 5 of these (GUSB, B2M, PPIA, HMBS, and TFRC) were stably expressed in the samples tested. The geometric mean of their expression levels was used for normalization. The relative expression levels of test transcripts were calculated using the Relative Standard Curve Method. Multivariate analyses and analyses of covariance were performed using SPSS v.22. Data were corrected for multiple comparisons using the false discovery rate method.

Results: Our data reveal increased expression of genes encoding every glutamate receptor subunit or subtype in the DLPFC in the MDD group compared with controls (F=2.93, df=21, 86, p=0.0002) and also when MDD suicide, MDD non-suicide, and the controls were compared (F=2.05, df=21, 86, p=0.001). Post hoc tests of individual genes revealed that there was a significant sex by diagnosis interaction for the expression of 12 genes. These differences in gene expression were specific to the female subjects. When analyzed the sexes were analyzed separately, expression levels of 13 genes, GluN1, GluN2A-D, GluA2-4, GluK2, mGluR1, mGluR4-5 and mGluR7 were all increased in the female patients with MDD (F=3.13, df=21, 30, p=0.002) but none of these were altered in the male groups. Expression levels of GluN1, GluN2A-D, GluA2-4, GluK2, mGluR4-5 and mGluR7 were increased in female MDD subjects who died by suicide (F=1.85, df=42, 58, p=0.03), but only GluK3 expression levels were increased in the male MDD suicides (F=7.92, df=2, 58, p=0.001).

Conclusions: Our data suggest that there is a generalized disruption of the regulation of glutamate receptors in the DLPFC of females with MDD, with similar changes in female patients who died by suicide. Only GluK3 gene expression was altered in the male suicides. These data suggest that females with MDD are more vulnerable to disruption of glutamatergic gene expression than males with MDD. These gene expression differences may contribute to the differences in symptoms exhibited by female patients, such as their increased frequency of suicide attempts. The data from this study indicate that in addition to the NMDA receptor, AMPA, kainate and metabotropic GluRs may be targets for the development of rapidly acting antidepressant drugs. SELECTED REFERENCES: Berman RM, Cappiello A, Anand A, Oren DA, Heninger GR, Charney DS et al. Biol Psychiatry 2000; 47(4): 351-354. Carrier N, Kabbaj M. 2013;70:27-34. Heller AS, Johnstone T, Peterson MJ, Kolden GG, Kalin NH, Davidson RJ. JAMA Psychiatry. 2013;70(11):1181-9.
Keywords: postmortem, NMDA, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, gene expression.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T267. Sex Differences in Oxytocin’s Effects on Motivated Behavior
Luyi Zhou, Ronald See, Carmela Reichel*
Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, South Carolina
sec.p: Background: Sex differences clearly exist in psychostimulant addiction patterns. However, the underlying neurobiology and potential addiction therapies have typically only been studied in males. Oxytocin has gained increasing attention as a possible treatment for multiple neuropsychiatric disorders, including addiction. Oxytocin impacts natural and drug reward due to extensive innervation of central reward pathways. Here, we examined sex differences in cocaine and sucrose seeking and locomotor activity following systemic oxytocin treatment. In order to compare systemic and central effects, we also examined sex differences in reinstated cocaine seeking following intracerebroventricular (ICV) administration of oxytocin.

Methods: Male and female rats underwent an activity test for basal and cocaine induced locomotor activity after oxytocin (0.1-3 mg/kg, ip) or vehicle injection. Rats underwent 2 weeks of cocaine or sucrose self-administration followed by extinction and reinstatement tests after systemic (0.1-3 mg/kg, ip) or central (3 ug, icv, bilateral) oxytocin or vehicle treatment.

Results: Females exhibited reduced activity to lower doses of oxytocin than males during basal and cocaine-induced locomotor activity. Oxytocin (ip) reduced reinstated cocaine and sucrose seeking in both males and females, but females were more sensitive to lower doses of oxytocin relative to males. This effect was most evident in sucrose reinstated behavior. Interestingly, while central oxytocin reduced cocaine primed reinstatement in both males and females, it only reduced cue driven cocaine seeking in males.

Conclusions: Oxytocin impacted motivated behavior and locomotor activity similarly in both sexes; however, females were overall more sensitive to oxytocin. Based on these findings, a central action on the oxytocin receptor is necessary for the attenuation of cocaine seeking in males and females in response to a cocaine prime. However, in response to conditioned cues, only central actions on the oxytocin receptor were relevant in males. This sex difference for cue-induced cocaine seeking may relate to the well-known sex differences in the role of oxytocin on peripheral organ sites of actions in females, relative to males.
Keywords: Self administration, motivated drug taking, relapse, neuropeptides.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T268. HDAC4 Regulation in Women with PTSD: Evidence from Human and Animal Models
Alicia Smith*, Stephanie Maddox, Lynn Almli, Brian Diaz, Karen Conneely, Varun Kilaru, Elisabeth Binder, Kerry Ressler
Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, Georgia
sec.p: Background: Women are twice as likely to develop post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) after a traumatic experience. Though the reasons for this are not entirely clear, estrogen has been linked to impaired fear inhibition and can moderate risk alleles in genes implicated in PTSD. Epigenetic studies have provided additional insight into the molecular mechanisms that contribute to PTSD at specific genes and across the genome. In this study, we evaluated whether peripheral epigenetic patterns predict PTSD in a sex-specific manner.

Methods: Blood samples were collected from 410 subjects (57.8% female) from the Grady Trauma Project (Atlanta, GA). The Modified PTSD Symptom Scale (PSS) was used to determine PTSD diagnosis. DNA methylation was interrogated using the HumanMethylation450 BeadChip, and RNA expression was measured using the Illumina HT-12 BeadChip. Genotyping was performed using the OmniExpress or OmniQuad BeadChips. For all genes expressed in blood, we examined the association between each CpG site and PTSD using linear models that adjusted for cell proportions and age as covariates. A false discovery rate of 5% was used to correct for multiple tests. Mice receive 5 training trials of an electric shock paired with a tone at an average inter-trial interval of 5 minutes for fear conditioning (FC). Homecage controls are naive to FC. The animals were killed 2 hours after the FC session with an overdose of isoflurane anesthesia. Punch biopsies of the amygdala were taken and homogenized for gene expression studies. All experiments were approved by Emory University and Grady Memorial Hospital Institutional Review Boards following Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee standards in accordance with Yerkes Primate Research Center regulations.

Results: CpG sites in histone deacetylase 4 (HDAC4) and NEDD4 binding protein 2 (N4BP2) associate with PTSD (FDR<.05; p>4.8x10-7) in women, but not in men (p>.05). The function of N4BP2 is not clear, but HDAC4 is involved in long-term memory formation and regulates key genes involved in behavior. It does so through interaction with specific proteins including estrogen receptor alpha (ESR1), suggesting a potential mechanism underlying this sex-specific association. DNA methylation of CpG sites in HDAC4 associate with its expression (2.2x10-6<p<.049), and sequence variants in HDAC4 also associate with PTSD in women (.0052<p<.048). We next examined the regulation of HDAC4 expression in mouse amygdala following auditory Pavlovian fear conditioning. Ovariectomized (OVX) female mice had higher levels of HDAC4 expression in the amygdala after fear conditioning when compared to OVX-homecage control females (p=0.01). Interestingly HDAC4 expression did not differ from OVX-homecage controls after fear conditioning when estrogen was replaced (OVX+E; p>0.05), supporting the link between the hormonal environment and HDAC4 regulation.

Conclusions: Sex-specific genetic and epigenetic predictors of PTSD are becoming more commonly recognized and help to explain the genetic heterogeneity underlying clinical PTSD. These data suggest that regulation and expression of HDAC4 may contribute to fear memory consolidation and the development of PTSD in women.
Keywords: PTSD, genetic, HDAC, sex-specific.

Disclosure: Dr. Smith receives or has received research support from the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, Schering Plough Pharmaceuticals, NARSAD, the Conquer Cancer Foundation and NIH. Dr. Binder has filed a patent application as inventor of “Means and Methods for Diagnosing Predisposition for Treatment Emergent Suicidal Ideation (TESI)” (European application 08016477.5; international application PCT/EP2009/061575), and a patent application as inventor of “FKBP5: A Novel Target for Antidepressant Therapy” (international publication WO2005/054500). Dr. Ressler has received funding from the Burroughs Wellcome Fund, NIH, and he has an unrelated role as cofounder of Extinction Pharmaceuticals for development of N-methyl-D-aspartate– based therapeutics.

sec.title: T269. Sex-dependent Effects of Cannabis-induced Analgesia
Ziva Cooper*, Ursula Rogers, Margaret Haney
Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York, New York
sec.p: Background: Preclinical studies have demonstrated that cannabinoid-mediated antinociceptive effects vary according to sex. We recently demonstrated that male and female cannabis smokers matched for current cannabis use differ in their subjective response to cannabis The current study was designed to determine if the analgesic effects of cannabis also varied between male and female cannabis-smokers matched for current use. Under double-blind, placebo-controlled conditions, the analgesic effects of smoked cannabis were assessed using the Cold-Pressor Test (CPT), an experimental laboratory model of pain.

Methods: Data from two double-blind, within-subject studies were used for this analysis (N=49). Both studies were designed to assess the analgesic effects of cannabinoids in non-treatment seeking cannabis smokers and measured the subjective ratings of drug quality and drug effect of a single strength of cannabis (3.27 or 5.60% THC, depending on the study) relative to placebo cannabis (0.00%). Data from equal numbers of male (N=17) and female (N=17) participants matched for frequency of cannabis use (days/week) and amount of cannabis smoked per day (joints/day) were pooled. For the CPT, participants immersed their hand in cold water (4°C) for up to three minutes, and the amount of time to report pain (pain sensitivity) and withdraw the hand from the water (pain tolerance) was recorded. Subjective pain ratings were also measured immediately after each CPT. Analgesia and subjective drug effects data were collected before (baseline) cannabis smoking and at several time-points after smoking. The time-course for cannabis’ analgesic and subjective effects were analyzed according to cannabis condition (active and placebo) and sex.

Results: Male and female participants did not differ in cannabis smoking frequency (males=6.8±0.4, females=6.4±1.3 days/week), number of joints smoked per day (males=7.3±5.7, females,=9.4±8.5), or age (males=28±7 years, females=29±6 years), although males weighed significantly more than females (males=77.5±13.7 kg, females=67.7±12.2 kg, p<0.05). Cannabis-induced analgesia significantly differed between men and women (p<0.01): Among men, active cannabis significantly increased pain threshold and tolerance relative to placebo cannabis (p<0.0001), whereas active cannabis failed to increase pain threshold or tolerance in women. Active cannabis decreased the subjective ratings for the ‘bothersomeness’ of the painful stimulus for both men and women relative to placebo cannabis (p<0.001). Active cannabis also increased subjective ratings of cannabis ‘High,’ ‘Liking,’ and ‘Take Again’ relative to placebo cannabis in men and women (p<0.001), an effect that did not differ between sexes.

Conclusions: These results indicate that when matched for current cannabis smoking, men and women differ in cannabis-induced analgesia with men exhibiting a significantly greater analgesic response than women. These sex-dependent differences in analgesia were present despite comparable ratings of cannabis-elicited subjective effects in men and women. Thus, sex-dependent differences in cannabis’ analgesic effects are an important consideration for future investigations of the potential therapeutic effects of cannabinoids for pain relief.
Keywords: Cannabis, Cannabinoids, Sex differences, analgesia.
Disclosure: Nothing to Disclose.

sec.title: T270. Improving Psychopharmacology Education and Practice: The Quandary of Getting Data and Information to the Teachers
Ira Glick*, Richard Balon, Sidney Zisook
Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, California
sec.p: Background: The current situation regarding the teaching of psychopharmacology is complicated secondary to (1) decreased funding for psychiatric education in general and specifically with marked decreases of industry support, (2) increased neuroscience and clinical articles as well as the number of journals including print and web have increased, (3) decreased reading by students and there is a sharply decreased number of published texts, (4) increased emphasis on teaching psychotherapy and requirements to teach ‘non-clinical’ competencies, such as systems-based learning, often come at the expense of curricular time for psychopharmacology, (5) decreased numbers of academics who have the expertise and time to teach psychopharmacology and finally (6) strong anti-industry and anti-drug treatment biases in the fields.
Methods: Over the past two decades, we have done follow-up surveys of users and programs of the psychopharmacology curriculums for both the medical students and psychiatric residents.

Results: Many programs were unaware of the existence of these teaching tools. The time required for teaching and the potential costs were key barriers to utilization. Where the curriculums were purchased; they were used – either as a whole or in part – depending on the size of the program. They were judged to be very effective in improving learning. There were strong biases and prohibitions to communicating the existence of the teaching tools e.g. teachers could not use their organizational list-serves to let their teaching colleagues know of recent updates.

Conclusions: The teaching and learning of cutting-edge medical student and psychiatric residents psychopharmacology has become increasingly challenging. Novel and creative approaches to prepare and reward faculty to teach, and motivate students to learn, the intricacies of psychopharmacologic management are needed.
Keywords: Training, schizo, depression, education.
Disclosure: Glick - Small equity in Johnson & Johnson.
